questions.text:
An unresponsive child is brought to the emergency room. His BP is not recordable and pulse rate is 40 per minute. CPR is initiated. Despite proper oxygenation and ventilation, his SpO2 is 70% and pulse rate is not improving. What is the dose of epinephrine that needs to be given to the child?

CPR - Cardio-pulmonary resuscitation
questions.solution:
In a child who continues to have bradycardia despite initiating CPR, the dose of epinephrine that needs to be given is 0.01 mg/kg of 1:10,000 solution (0.1 mL/kg of 1:10,000). 

Epinephrine can be given intravenously or via the intraosseous route if the intravenous route is not accessible. It is repeated every 3-5 minutes. If intravenous or intraosseous access cannot be obtained, then it can be administered via the endotracheal route at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg of 1:1,000 solution (0.1 mL/kg of 1:1000).

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was brought with complaints of premature development of breast buds. The sagittal MRI of the brain revealed a hypothalamic hamartoma. All of the following are used in the treatment of this patient, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of central precocious puberty. GnRH antagonists are not used in the treatment of this patient.

Precocious puberty is defined as the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years in girls.

There are two types of precocious puberty:

  • Central/GnRH-dependent precocious puberty
  • Peripheral/GnRH-independent precocious puberty

Hypothalamic hamartomas are a neuronal migration defect that is the common cause of organic central precocious puberty. These lesions are believed to cause precocious puberty through the endogenous pulsatile release of GnRH, either independently or in concert with the GnRH-secreting neurons of the hypothalamus. 

Treatment of central precocious puberty:

  • GnRH agonists (depot-forms or implants) are the treatment of choice for tumor-induced central precocious puberty.
  • Inj. depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) 100–200 mg, IM every 2–4 weeks to induce regression of these premature changes and cessation of menstruation.
  • Cyproterone acetate exerts antiandrogenic and antigonadotropin effects and is effective in treatment.
  • In patients with hypothalamic hamartoma and associated intractable gelastic or psychomotor seizures, stereotactic radiation therapy (gamma knife surgery) is more effective and has fewer risks than neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient came to the hospital with a history of headaches, seizures, memory loss, and mood changes.  The given image is obtained by doing an MRI scan. Which of the following drugs is useful in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the MRI scan finding are suggestive of glioblastoma. Temozolomide is used as a first-line agent for the management of glioblastoma. It is used for newly diagnosed cases along with radiotherapy and also used for maintenance therapy.

Temozolomide belongs to the triazene group of alkylating agents and is administered orally. The oral bioavailability of temozolomide is nearly 100%. It forms a methylating metabolite and kills cells in all phases of the cell cycle.

Glioblastoma is the most malignant astrocytic tumor - WHO grade IV. It spreads along the white matter tracts and crosses the midline via the corpus callosum, giving rise to the so-called butterfly glioma. 

Other options:

Option A- Streptozocin belongs to the nitrosourea group of alkylating agents and has a high affinity of islets of Langerhans. It is used in the treatment of pancreatic islet cell carcinoma and carcinoid tumors.

Option C- Ifosfamide belongs to the nitrogen mustard group of alkylating agents and an analog of cyclophosphamide. Ifosfamide is used in germ cell tumors of testes and sarcomas. It has maximum neurotoxicity which can be treated with methylene blue. It has a urothelial damaging capacity like cyclophosphamide which can be treated with MESNA (sodium-2-mercaptoethanol sulfonate).

Option D- Chlorambucil belongs to the nitrogen mustard group of alkylating agents and is an orally administered drug. It is almost exclusively used in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

questions.text: Pseudouridine and ribothymidine are present as nucleotides in _____.
questions.solution:
Pseudouridine and ribothymidine are present as nucleotides in transfer RNAs (tRNAs).

Transfer RNA is a type of RNA that helps to transport amino acids from the cell cytoplasm to the ribosome, where protein synthesis is taking place. Since they are soluble in nature, they are also known as soluble RNA (sRNA). They undergo internal base-pairing (represented by the black dotted lines in the image below) to form the secondary cloverleaf structure.

Each part of the cloverleaf structure serves a different purpose. The parts of the cloverleaf include:

  • Anticodon loop
  • Acceptor arm
  • D loop
  • The ribothymidine pseudouridine cytidine (TΨC) loop
  • Variable loop

The image given below shows the cloverleaf structure of tRNA.

The anticodon loop shown is where the anticodon triplet codons are present that make a tRNA specific. This anticodon will base pair with the complementary codon on the mRNA (messenger RNA) strand undergoing translation.

The acceptor arm is at the 3' end. This 3' end of the tRNA has the CCA sequence. The hydroxyl group on the A of the CCA sequence gets charged by accepting the amino acid specific to the codon (on the mRNA) that pairs with the anticodon loop. This then gets added to the elongating polypeptide chain. 

The D loop, TΨC loop, and variable loop are involved in defining the specific tRNA and ensuring accurate codon-anticodon base pairing.

Thus, a specific tRNA exists for each of the 20 amino acids that are commonly present in proteins. This tRNA acts as a mediator between the cytosolic amino acids and the mRNA strand undergoing translation.

Other options:

Option B: rRNAs (ribosomal RNA) are found within ribosomes and do not contain these modified bases.

Option C: hnRNA (heterogenous nuclear RNA) is processed to produce mRNA, which also lacks these modified bases.

Option D: snRNPs (small nuclear RNAs complexed with protein) are involved in splicing and also lack ribothymidine and pseudouridine.

questions.text: You are a microbiology resident teaching the staining technique shown in the image below to medical students. What is the order of the steps to be followed in this technique?

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine solution, decolorisation, carbol fuchsin
Crystal violet, decolorisation, iodine solution, carbol fuchsin
Carbol fuchsin, iodine solution, decolorisation, crystal violet
Crystal violet, carbol fuchsin, iodine solution, decolorisation

questions.solution:
The given microscopy image shows Gram staining, and the order of Gram staining is as follows:

  • Primary staining with para-rosaniline dye (crystal violet, methyl violet, or gentian violet)
  • Application of dilute iodine solution
  • Decolorisation with an organic solvent (ethanol, acetone, aniline)
  • Counterstaining with the dye of contrasting color (carbol fuchsin, safranine, neutral red)

The suggested theories in Gram staining are that a gram-positive organism retains the primary basic dye due to its acidic protoplasm. Also, a thick peptidoglycan layer present in gram-positive bacteria helps in retaining the dye-iodine complex. The lipid content in gram-negative bacteria is very high, which makes it permeable to secondary dye after decolorization with organic solvents like acetone.

Therefore, gram-positive bacteria retain the primary stain and appear violet. Gram-negative bacteria appear red because they get decolorized and take up the counterstain.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with chronic tonsillitis presented to the OPD with complaints of a gritty sensation in her throat. On palpation and probing, you confirm the sensation. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the clinical scenario, the patient having chronic tonsillitis with a gritty sensation in the throat suggests a possible diagnosis of tonsilloliths. 

Tonsilloliths are complications of chronic tonsillitis and are mostly seen in adults. They are calcium and magnesium-rich calculi of the tonsils that occur due to the blocking of crypts and retention of debris. They give rise to a gritty sensation in the throat and can be confirmed with palpation or probing. They may enlarge and ulcerate through the tonsil. Tonsilloliths are treated by removal of stone or tonsillectomy.

Other options: 

Option A: Intratonsillar abscess is a complication of acute tonsillitis where pus is accumulated in the tonsils. It presents with inflamed, tender tonsils with significant pain and dysphagia. They can be treated with antibiotics, drainage, or tonsillectomy at a later date. 

Option C: Tonsillar cyst is an asymptomatic yellowish swelling over the tonsil due to blockage of a tonsillar crypt. It is treated by incision and drainage.

Option D: Lingual tonsil abscess is a severe complication of acute tonsillitis as it can cause laryngeal edema. Jugulodigastric nodes are commonly involved. Dysphagia, excessive salivation and painful tongue protrusion are some of the clinical findings seen in this condition.

questions.text:
A patient who has motor paralysis had his CSF tested. It shows albuminocytologic dissociation. What is this finding characteristic of?

CSF - cerebrospinal fluid
questions.solution:
A patient with motor paralysis showing elevated CSF protein levels without pleocytosis (otherwise known as albuminocytological dissociation) is characteristic of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS).

GBS is an autoimmune disease that usually occurs following antecedent respiratory or gastrointestinal infection and manifests as ascending motor paralysis with or without sensory disturbance. The patient may complain of rubbery legs and the weakness develops within hours to a few days. 

The lower limb is affected more commonly. Deep tendon reflexes reduce or disappear. Lower cranial nerves are also frequently affected, causing difficulty in maintaining the airway. Autonomic involvement can cause fluctuations in blood pressure and cardiac arrhythmias.

There are many types of Guillain–Barre syndrome:

  • Demyelinating
    • Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP)- most common type
  • Axonal
    • Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN)
    • Acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN)
  • Regional GBS syndromes: Miller–Fisher syndrome (MFS)

Diagnosis is made upon clinical presentation. CSF findings of elevated protein without pleocytosis help to rule out other similar conditions. Treatment includes initiating intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIg) or plasmapheresis. IVIg is the initial therapy preferred, as it has a better safety record. In severe cases, patients may require ventilatory support.  

Other options :

Option A: Pseudotumor cerebri is also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension. CSF is normal but there is an elevated opening pressure. It causes persistent headaches and papilledema. 

Option B: Multiple sclerosis is characterized by chronic inflammation and demyelination that causes multiple neurological symptoms such as optic neuritis, muscle spasticity, and facial weakness. The presence of oligoclonal bands on protein electrophoresis is diagnostic. 

Option D: The most common cause of subarachnoid hemorrhage, other than trauma, is a saccular aneurysm. CSF can be bloody or xanthochromic (yellow-stained) due to the production of bilirubin from lysed hemoglobin.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: The deficiency of the enzyme involved in step 3 of the process illustrated below results in _____.
questions.solution:
The enzyme involved in step 3 (glycogen branching) is the branching enzyme. The deficiency of this enzyme would result in Andersen’s disease.

Andersen's disease is a type IV glycogen storage disease characterized by hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of polysaccharides with few branch points. Death usually ensues around 5 years of age.

questions.text: What is the origin of the muscle marked as "X" in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The anconeus is the muscle marked as "X" in the image above. The anconeus originates from the posterior surface of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. 

The anconeus is the short triangular muscle. The anconeus is located in the posterior part of the elbow joint, part of the extensor compartment of the arm. It inserts into the lateral aspect of the olecranon and the proximal one-fourth of the posterior surface of the shaft of the ulna.

It receives its nerve supply from the radial nerve with a root value of C6, C7, and C8.

It is an extensor of the elbow. It receives its vascular supply from branches of the posterior interosseous recurrent artery.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is planned for a prostatectomy by Freyer's approach. Which of the following indicates this approach in the given image?
questions.solution:
The approach marked as "3" depicts Freyer's approach. It is also known as the transvesical approach.

In this approach, the bladder is opened and the prostate is enucleated by putting a finger into the urethra, pushing forward towards the pubes to separate the lateral lobes, and then working the finger between the adenoma and the false capsule. Even though rarely performed today, this technique is considered in surgeries that require a prostatectomy combined together with the removal of a bladder stone.

Other approaches marked in the above image:

1- Transurethral approach (TURP) is the most commonly used approach

2- The retropubic approach is called the Millin approach.

4- Perineal approach is also called the Young operation.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is diagnosed with metastatic ER-positive breast cancer. Tamoxifen therapy was started but the tumor still showed progression. She has been switched to a new drug that acts on the estrogen receptors and has to be taken only once a month. Which of the following is the new drug administered to her?
questions.solution:
Fulvestrant is the new drug administered in this case. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of (estrogen receptor) ER-positive breast cancer, resistant to tamoxifen therapy. 

Fulvestrant is an estrogen antagonist which is indicated in postmenopausal women with hormone-positive breast cancer, which is progressive even after first-line therapy such as tamoxifen.

It is a pure estrogen antagonist with no agonist action. Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen-receptor down regulator (SERD).

It binds to ERα and ERβ with high affinity but represses transactivation. It causes intracellular proteolytic degradation of ERα while protecting ERβ from degradation. This effect on ERα protein levels is responsible for fulvestrant’s efficacy in tamoxifen-resistant breast cancer.

It is longer acting and is administered once a month (250- 500mg) intramuscularly. It is generally well tolerated. Nausea, asthenia, and headache are common side effects. It is given as initial biweekly loading doses in the 1st month followed by once-monthly injections. Steady-state levels are achieved in the first month.

Other options:

Option A: Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that decreases estrogen synthesis and is widely used now in the treatment of breast cancer in postmenopausal women. Estrogen is locally produced from androgen by the action of the aromatase enzyme. Locally synthesized estrogens play an important role in the development of breast cancer because they are estrogen-dependent for proliferation. 

Options B and C: Selec­tive aromatase inhibitors block the conversion of the hormone androstenedione into estrone by inhibiting the aromatase enzyme. They include:

Reversible aromatase inhibitors:

  • Letrozole (Dose: 2.5 mg Once a day per oral)
  • Anastrozole (Dose: 1 mg Once a day per oral)
  • Vorozole

Irreversible aromatase inhibitors:

  • Exemestane (Dose: 25 mg once a day per oral after meals)
  • Formestane

These agents can also be used as the first-line treatment of breast cancer or as second-line drugs after tamoxifen therapy. They are highly efficacious and superior to tamoxifen in adjuvant use for postmenopausal women. They can either be used following tamoxifen therapy for 2–5 years or as initial agents. They do not increase the risk of uterine cancer or venous thromboemboli.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain. A barium swallow image is shown below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: It is associated with hiatus hernia
Most commonly seen in middle third of esophagus

questions.solution:
The given barium swallow showing a thin submucosal circumferential ring at the squamocolumnar junction is suggestive of Schatzki's ring. The true statement regarding the condition is, that it is associated with hiatus hernia.

Schatzki’s ring is a thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction. Schatzki's ring is a non-malignant condition and is often associated with a hiatal hernia. The patient experiences brief episodes of dysphagia during the hurried ingestion of solid foods.

The presence of a ring in the esophagus, with or without hiatal hernia, can be visualized on barium swallow.

For symptomatic patients who do not have reflux, the best form of treatment consists of esophageal dilation for relief of the obstructive symptoms. In patients who have proven reflux and a mechanically defective sphincter, an antireflux procedure is done to obtain relief and avoid repeated dilation.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with a fistula-in-ano was managed with the following technique. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this technique?

choices.text: It maintains drainage and induces fibrosis
Should be left in place for 3 months

questions.solution:
The given image shows the seton technique. The seton should be non-absorbable, non-degenerative, and comfortable.

The Seton technique is used in the management of fistula-in-ano. A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. Setons can be classified as draining or cutting. 

In loose/draining seton method, the seton is placed to maintain drainage and create scar tissue around the sphincter so that its edges do not retract after cutting.It is left in place for 3 months. Seton's technique induces fibrosis and has very good evidence of healing. 

For fistulas that involve more than 30% of the sphincter or those which are distal to the dentate line, loose placement of seton through the track helps to facilitate drainage of any sepsis and to preserve the sphincter.

Cutting seton has been used as a staged fistulectomy, especially in high trans-sphincteric fistulas. This is achieved by gradually tightening at regular intervals to promote fibrosis and to slowly cut through the involved sphincter muscle, thus helping in eliminating the fistula while maintaining the continuity of the sphincter.

The other techniques used in the management of anal fistulas are:

  • Fistulotomy involves opening the fistula tract and possibly dividing the sphincter muscle. It is very effective for simple fistulas with minimal sphincter involvement. 
  • Fistulectomy involves completely cutting out the fistulous tracts.
  • Endorectal advancement flap- involves closure of the internal opening of the tract, debridement of the tract, and mobilization of anorectal mucosa to cover the defect. It is usually done for complex fistulas. 
  • LIFT- Ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract involves identification of the internal opening with suture ligation of the intersphincteric portion of the fistula. The tract and infected gland are then excised and the wound is debrided with curettage. It can be done for both simple and complex fistulas.

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a self-inflating bag and mask. It can be safely used in a 60-year-old patient with angioedema.

A patient with angioedema is likely to have a difficult airway because of the edema in the throat obscuring vision, effective laryngoscopy, and intubation. Bag mask ventilation can be used as a rescue technique to provide oxygenation and ventilation in patients with difficult airways until tracheal intubation is achieved. 

Bag and mask ventilation is used as the first step in airway management to provide positive pressure ventilation. The bag in this apparatus is a self-inflating bag. A patent airway and a good seal are essential to facilitate bag and mask ventilation.

The face mask can be used in two techniques: The one-handed technique is the most commonly used technique. This is achieved by ensuring a tight seal with the left-hand thumb and index finger forming a 'C' around the collar of the mask. The third and fourth digits are placed on the ramus of the mandible, and the fifth digit placed below the angle of the mandible helps in jaw thrust. The two-handed technique is used in cases of difficult airways and it requires assistance.

Signs of effective ventilation:

  • Chest rise on squeezing the bag
  • Condensation in the clear mask
  • Pulse oximetry
  • Capnography

Mask ventilation is usually contraindicated in patients with an increased risk of regurgitation (option D). It should be used with caution in patients with severe facial trauma (option C) and in patients in whom head and neck manipulation must be avoided i.e those with an unstable cervical spine fracture (option B).

questions.text: A child presents with chronic diarrhea,  weight loss, and fatigue. On examination, he was pale, with decreased height for age score. The life cycle of the causative organism is given in the image below. Which of the following is not a known complication of this disease?
questions.solution:
The life cycle given above denoting adult worms in the large intestine with them having a slender anterior end and a 'whip-like' thick posterior end is suggestive of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm). Focal seizures or cerebral involvement is not a known complication of trichuriasis. 

Trichuriasis is caused by T. trichiura (whipworm), which inhabits the cecum and ascending colon.

Clinical features include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth, and developmental defects. The disease may result either due to the mechanical effect of the worms or an allergic reaction to the parasite.

Trichuris trichiura causes rectal prolapse in children (characteristic feature) because the rectum loses its internal support as the worms bury their thin heads into the intestinal lining, loosening the elastic epithelium, and weakening the surrounding muscles; also, there is rectal edema because of the infection. All these factors finally lead to rectal prolapse. In heavy infection with T. trichiura, sigmoidoscopy may show white bodies of worms hanging from the inflamed mucosa, the so-called coconut cake rectum. 

Other complications include dysentery, diarrhea, tenesmus, iron deficiency anemia, and poor growth. The poor growth is typically secondary to poor nutrition and consequently causes cognitive delay.

Fecal smears show a barrel-shaped ovum of T. trichiura. The eggs of T. trichiura do not have a terminal spine. They are barrel-shaped and have mucus plugs at both ends. They get bile-stained and float in the saturated salt solution. An image showing the egg of trichuris is given below.

 

Albendazole 400 mg orally for 3 days is the drug of choice.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about the direct Coombs test.

choices.text: Detects complement on patient's red cells
Detects antibodies on patient's red cells
Foreign red cells with known antigenicity used
Unbound antibodies in patient's sample are removed

questions.solution:
Foreign red cells with known antigenicity are used in the indirect Coomb's test, not the direct Coomb's test.
 
In the direct Coomb's test or direct antiglobulin test, the patient's red blood cells are mixed with a serum that contains antibodies against human immunoglobulin or complement. If agglutination occurs, it indicates that either immunoglobulin or complement is present on the surface of the patient's red cells. It is used in the diagnosis of immunohemolytic anemia, as it detects the presence of complements or antibodies on the red blood cells. 
 
The principle of the direct Coomb's test is to detect antibodies that are directly bound to the red cells. This can be done by washing a collected blood sample in saline to remove the unbound antibodies that can confound the result.
 
In the indirect Coomb's test or indirect antiglobulin test, foreign red cells with known antigenicity are added to the patient's serum. Antiglobulin reagent is then added and is observed for agglutination. Indirect Coomb's test detects unbound antibodies to red cells, which may be present in the patient’s serum.

questions.text: An immunologist is conducting research studies with laboratory mice. He noticed a phenomenon known as Schultz-Dale phenomenon. Which type of hypersensitivity does this phenomenon follow?
questions.solution:
Schultz–Dale phenomenon or anaphylaxis in-vitro is a type I hypersensitivity reaction. 

The Schultz-Dale phenomenon refers to an in-vitro contraction of isolated intestinal muscle strips from a sensitized mouse that has been exposed to antigens, demonstrating an immediate hypersensitivity reaction. The reaction is specific and can be elicited only by the antigen to which the animal is sensitive. Tissues from normal animals can be passively sensitized by treatment with serum from sensitized animals.

Other types of tests for anaphylaxis:

Cutaneous anaphylaxis:

In this test, a small shocking dose of an antigen is administered intradermally to a sensitized host. A local wheal-and-flare response is observed. The central area of puffiness due to edema is called the wheal, while the surrounding hyperemia and erythema is the flare. The application of this procedure is used in testing for hypersensitivity and in identifying the allergen responsible for atopic diseases. 

Passive cutaneous anaphylaxis (PCA):

This test is an extremely sensitive in-vivo method for the detection of antibodies. A normal animal is injected with a small volume of the antibody intradermally. After 2-24 hours, the antigen is injected intravenously along with a dye such as Evans blue. Immediate blueing is observed at the site of intradermal injection due to vasodilatation and increased capillary permeability (wheal-and-flare reaction). The human IgG antibody (heterocytotropic) can be detected with this test but, not the human IgE antibody (homocytotropic).

questions.text: An ENT surgeon is examining a child as a part of a routine health check-up. Her otoscopic findings are given in the image below. Which of the following is not true regarding the structure marked by the arrow?

choices.text: It has a thin fibrous layer
Situated above the lateral process of malleus
Its periphery is called annulus tympanicus
It is also called Shrapnell’s membrane

questions.solution:
The image shows a normal tympanic membrane and the part marked in the image is pars flaccida. The statement C about annulus tympanicus is wrong. Annulus tympanicus is a part of pars tensa, not pars flaccida.

The normal tympanic membrane is shiny and pearly grey in color. It is thin and semitranslucent. It is concave to the external auditory canal with the maximum concavity at the umbo.

Pars flaccida is also known as Shrapnell’s membrane. It has a thin fibrous layer and appears slightly pinkish. It is situated above the lateral process of malleus between the anterior and posterior malleal folds and the notch of Rivinus. 

Pars tensa forms most of the tympanic membrane. In the peripheral region, pars tensa forms a thick fibrocartilaginous structure called annulus tympanicus. The central part of pars tensa is indented inwards at the tip of the malleus and is known as the umbo. A bright cone of light can be seen radiating from the umbo to the periphery in the anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane. 

Invagination of the tympanic membrane either to pars tensa or pars flaccida results in retraction pockets.

Tos classification: This is used to grade the retraction in pars flaccida or attic retraction

  • Stage 1: The pars flaccida is dimpled but not in touch with the malleus.
  • Stage 2: The tympanic membrane is in contact with the neck of malleus and the entire extent of retraction can be visualized.
  • Stage 3: The retraction is not visible fully, and there may be partial erosion of bony attic wall. 
  • Stage 4: The retraction is definite erosion of the bony attic wall and the full extent of retraction is not visible.

Due to difficulty in distinguishing the latter two, it is grouped as stage 3/4.

Sade classification: This is used to grade the retraction in pars tensa

  • Stage 1: The tympanic membrane is retracted but not in touch with the incus
  • Stage 2: The tympanic membrane is in contact with the long process of the incus
  • Stage 3: Middle ear atelectasis - the tympanic membrane is in contact with the promontory, but not adherent. It can be raised from the promontory with suction
  • Stage 4: Adhesive otitis media - the tympanic membrane is adherent to the promontory

questions.text: A young male patient came to the hospital with complaints of right-sided loin pain. The urine microscopy image is shown below. Which of the following is used in the treatment of these renal calculi?
questions.solution:
Urinary microscopy of the patient shows hexagonal crystals, which are suggestive of cystine stones. D-penicillamine can be used for treating cystine stones.

The basis of using D-penicillamine here is that it reacts with cystine to form a soluble salt that reduces the formation of cystine. It is a potentially toxic drug and should only be used if hydration and alkalinization fail.

Other options:

Option A: Acetohydroxamic acid may be considered for the treatment of struvite stone. It is a urease inhibitor. Urease enzyme generates ammonia from urea, elevating the pH of the urine and favoring the production of triple phosphate stones. However, it has to be used with caution due to the potential side effects.

Option B: Neutral orthophosphates halt the growth of existing oxalate calculi.

Option C: Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, can be used to decrease uric acid production. Hence, it can be used in the treatment of uric acid renal calculi.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A primigravida comes to the primary health center for a routine antenatal visit and enquires about consumption of iron tablets. Which of the following is recommended for pregnant women during the antenatal period based on Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme?

choices.text: 100 mg of elemental iron for 100 days
60 mg of elemental iron for 100 days
60 mg of elemental iron for 180 days
100 mg of elemental iron for 180 days

questions.solution:
According to Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme, 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid are given daily for a minimum of 180 days during pregnancy. It is to be started from the fourth month of pregnancy and to be continued for 180 days, post-partum.

Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme (2018) is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. It follows a 6x6x6 strategy. Here, 6 groups of beneficiaries are assisted by 6 interventions and 6 institutional mechanisms.

The six distinct groups of beneficiaries are children of 6-59 months of age, children of 5-9 years, adolescents, women in the reproductive age group, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. 

The six interventions are:

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation prophylactically
  • Deworming
  • Behavior change communication campaign
  • Using digital methods and point of care treatment
  • Provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

questions.text: All of the following stimulate the release of the hormone that is deficient in patients with central diabetes insipidus except ________.
questions.solution:
Vasopressin is the hormone that is deficient in patients with central diabetes insipidus. All of the following stimulate vasopressin release except alcohol, which decreases vasopressin secretion.

Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a condition in which there is the absence of or poor response to anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). This results in reduced permeability of the distal tubules and collecting ducts to water. This furthermore leads the kidneys to excrete large amounts of dilute urine that clinically manifests as polyuria and polydipsia. 

DI can be:

  • Central DI - due to vasopressin deficiency or
  • Nephrogenic DI - due to failure of kidneys to repond to ADH

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents a hard swelling in the neck which moves up with deglutition. The biopsy on the frozen section is given below. All of the following are true about this carcinoma, except that _____.

choices.text: It is associated with RAS mutation.
It usually presents as solitary nodule.
It can be diagnosed by FNAC.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient from a hilly area (iodine-deficient) and the biopsy specimen showing capsular invasion by tumor follicles confirms the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma. Follicular carcinoma cannot be diagnosed by FNAC.

FNAC cannot distinguish between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma. Capsular invasion must be present to diagnose follicular carcinoma, which can be seen only on biopsy.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: An elderly lady presented with a history of trivial fall while climbing the stairs. She has pain in the right hip and is unable to walk. Which of the following lines is disrupted in the radiograph of this patient given below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray are suggestive of fracture neck of the femur. This condition leads to disrupted Shenton's line as seen in the given radiograph.

Shenton's line is an imaginary curve drawn on the pelvic radiograph, extending along the inferior margin of the femoral neck to the superior margin of the obturator foramen. Disruption of this curve is seen in fracture neck of femur.

Fracture neck of femur is an intracapsular fracture. It is commonly seen in elderly women following a trivial fall. Osteoporosis is thought to be a major contributing factor at this age. Other risk factors include: comobordities (diabetes, chronic kidney and liver disease), and medications (corticosteroids, proton pump inhibitors). 

Plain radiograph may show the following features:

  • Fracture in the neck of femur
  • Break in the medial cortex
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent
  • Displacement of the greater trochanter
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in Shenton's line (as shown in the image below)

 

Clinical features of fracture neck of femur include: 

  • Painful movements of the hip joint
  • Shortening and external rotation of the affected limb
  • Tenderness in the hip 
  • Active straight leg raising is not possible

Classifications of fracture neck of femur: 

  • Garden classification: It is based on the degree of displacement of the fracture.

 

  • Pauwels classification: It is based on the angle of inclination of the fracture with respect to the horizontal plane.

 

Complications include non-union and avascular necrosis of the femoral head. 

Other options:

Options A and B- Hilgenreiner's line is a horizontal line drawn along the lower borders of the triradiate cartilages of the pelvic bone. Perkin's line is a line drawn perpendicular to Hilgenreiner's line along the lateral margin of the acetabular roof. Both these lines are used in the diagnosis of developmental dysplasia of the hip joint.

Option D- Iliopectineal line is drawn along the arcuate line of the ilium and the superior border of the superior pubic ramus, extending up to the pubic symphysis. It is disrupted in fractures of the acetabulum and the pubic ramus.

questions.text:
A patient presents with LMN-type facial weakness, as shown in the image below. The patient also complains of impaired taste sensation and inability to tolerate loud sounds. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

LMN- lower motor neuron
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of Bell's palsy. Immediate decompression is not required in Bell’s palsy and does not appear to have any benefit in this condition. 

Bell's palsy is an acute, idiopathic, and unilateral facial paresis that is caused by lower motor neuron lesions of the facial nerve. It is most often associated with HSV-1 infection.

It causes

  • unilateral facial palsy,
  • hyperacusis due to loss of stapedial reflex, and
  • impaired taste sensation due to the involvement of chorda tympani fibers.

It is diagnosed by excluding other causes. Most patients recover from Bell's palsy without treatment. A course of oral steroids and anti-viral drugs are given to increase the chance of recovery. Symptomatic measures include using artificial tears and manual closure of the upper eyelid during sleep to prevent corneal drying.

questions.text: What are the components of the modified Goeckerman regimen used for the management of patients with psoriasis?
questions.solution:
The modified Goeckerman regimen used in the management of patients with psoriasis comprises UVB plus coal tar.

Goeckerman regimen was invented for the treatment of mild to moderate psoriasis. Although the mode of action of the therapy is unknown, it is found to be associated with:

  • Decreased serum levels of inflammatory cytokines
  • Significant reduction in PASI - Psoriasis Assessment of Severity Index
  • Improvements in anxiety, depression, and quality of life scores
  • The longest remission times are seen when compared to any other treatment for psoriasis with a mean of 22 months

In this therapy, the application of crude coal tar (CCT) for 5 hours/day, is followed by exposure to narrow-band UVB (NB-UVB).

The short-term side effects seen are folliculitis and phototoxic reactions.

This treatment is almost obsolete now. Pre-treatment with acitretin before starting the Goeckerman regimen decreases the number of days needed for the lesions to clear. But, if a patient does not respond to this regimen, the diagnosis of psoriasis should be reconfirmed by a skin biopsy.

Management of psoriasis includes:

  • Topical treatment:
    • corticosteroids - most common
    • vitamin D analogs like calcitriol
    • topical retinoids
    • immunomodulators like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus
    • coal tar
    • keratolytic like salicylic acid and urea
  • Intralesional steroids to resistant plaques
  • Light therapy - UVB, PUVA
  • Systemic therapies like methotrexate, cyclosporine, and mycophenolate mofetil
  • Biological therapies:
    • TNF inhibitors: Infliximab, Etanercept, Adalimumab
    • IL12/ 23 inhibitor: Ustekinumab
    • Selective IL-23 inhibitor: Tildrakizumab
    • IL-17 inhibitors: Secukinumab, Brodalumab
    • Phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitors: Apremilast

Complications of psoriasis include secondary infection, poor cosmetic appearance, risk of lymphoma, and psoriatic arthritis.

Other option:

UVB plus anthralin combination is known as Ingram regimen.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a recent history of myocardial infarction was started on aspirin.  Which of the following statements is true about the drug used?

choices.text: Low dose aspirin acetylates the COX enzyme of platelets
Alkalinization of urine decreases its rate of excretion
Antiplatelet action is seen at higher doses

questions.solution:
Low-dose aspirin acetylates the cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme of platelets which is responsible for its antiplatelet action.

Aspirin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug that acts by irreversible cyclooxygenase inhibition. Anti-inflammatory action is exerted at high doses (325-650 mg every 4 to 6 hours) and anti-platelet action is exerted at low doses of 40–80 mg/day.

Aspirin and salicylates are acidic in nature. Alkalinization of the urine increases the rate of excretion of aspirin. Aspirin clearance does depend on its plasma concentration since at lower plasma concentrations it has first-order kinetics, where the rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration, but at higher plasma concentrations it has zero-order kinetics where the rate of elimination is independent of its plasma concentration.

Aspirin can be used as an analgesic, antipyretic and anti-inflammatory drug in rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, rheumatic fever, in the prevention of pre-eclampsia, and in post-myocardial infarction and post-stroke patients.

The most important adverse effect of aspirin is gastric mucosal damage and peptic ulceration. In children with viral illnesses, the drug may cause Reye's syndrome, a rare form of hepatic encephalopathy. It is a hepatotoxic drug and toxicity occurs when the dose exceeds 15g/day in adults. In patients with aspirin resistance, there is a failure of aspirin to produce its normal platelet inhibitory functions. Aspirin intolerance is a part of Samter's triad (nasal polyposis, intrinsic asthma, and aspirin intolerance).

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with pain, redness, and swelling of her left cheek. Which of the following features is least consistent with a diagnosis of cellulitis?
questions.solution:
Pinna is not involved in facial cellulitis, but it is involved in facial erysipelas, which is called Milian's ear sign.

Cellulitis is a painful, diffuse infection of the dermis and the subcutaneous tissue. It is characterized by poorly demarcated areas of marked edema, dilated superficial capillaries, and extravasation of red blood cells and inflammatory cells into the dermis.

The image given below shows poorly demarcated areas of edema and erythema in cellulitis.

Common pathogens involved:

  • Streptococci: Major causative organism
  • Staphylococcus aureus: Occasional cause of cellulitis, commonly causes erysipelas
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b: Common cause of facial cellulitis in children less than 2 years old
  • Groups B and G streptococci: In case of a venous or lymphatic compromise

Lower limbs are the commonest site of cellulitis and any wound, including tinea pedis or bacterial infection, is a possible site of entry. The face is the next common site of infection.

Clinical features:

  • Constitutional symptoms like fever and malaise
  • Local symptoms like erythema, heat, swelling, and tenderness
  • In cellulitis, the edge of the lesion is diffuse, while in erysipelas, the edge of the lesion is well demarcated and raised

The given image shows how the edges of the lesion in cellulitis are diffuse.

The given image shows well-demarcated and raised edges of erysipelas.

The given image shows the involvement of pinna, Milian's ear sign, in facial erysipelas.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas-

  • Infection of the superficial epidermis.
    • It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin.
      • The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Staphylococcus

Staphylococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Furuncle/boil- Infection of the hair follicle.

The given image shows a furuncle:

 

b. Carbuncle: A cluster of several furuncles:

The given image shows a carbuncle:

 

c. Bullous impetigo: Results in large blisters called bullae, usually seen in areas with skin folds such as armpits, groin, buttocks, etc.

The given image shows ruptured bullous impetigo:

 

d. Cellulitis: It is a rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually associated with wounds, incisions, burns, etc.

The given image shows cellulitis following an abrasion. The red streaks indicate the involvement of the lymphatics:

 

e. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliating toxin that causes peeling of the skin.

The given image shows SSSS:

 

Note: The conditions shown above are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus. It is important to remember that they may also be caused by other bacteria. Cellulitis is more commonly caused by Streptococcus.

questions.text: A newborn baby born to a mother with Grave's disease had aplasia cutis congenita as shown in the image below. Which of the following anti-thyroid drugs is most likely to be associated with causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows aplasia cutis congenita of the newborn depicting the absence of scalp hair and skin along with calvarial defects. This is commonly associated with methimazole.

Methimazole crosses the placenta to a greater degree than propylthiouracil and has been associated with fetal aplasia cutis. It is also associated with methimazole embryopathy, which includes esophageal or choanal atresia. Thus, when available, propylthiouracil should be used in the first trimester followed by the usage of methimazole during the second trimester.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site involved in discoid lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
Discoid lupus erythematosus is a benign inflammatory disorder of the skin, most frequently involving the face and scalp. 

It is characterized by well‐defined red, scaly patches of variable size, which heal with atrophy, scarring, and pigmentary changes. The circumscribed or discoid form is the most frequent type of disease and occurs particularly on the cheeks, bridge of the nose, ears, side of the neck, and scalp.

The image below shows a localized discoid lupus erythematosus of the scalp with follicular plugging.

questions.text: Which of the following is a rare cause of death in people with extensive burn injuries?
questions.solution:
Fat embolism is a rare cause of death in burns patients.

  • Causes of death in burns patients:
    • Neurogenic shock 
    • Secondary shock due to fluid loss
    • Toxaemia is due to the absorption of various metabolites from burnt tissue
    • Sepsis can occur 4-5 days after burn injury 
    • Biochemical disturbances
    • Acute renal failure
    • Gastrointestinal ulcer and hemorrhage
    • Edema of the glottis and pulmonary edema
    • Pyemia, gangrene, tetanus
    • ARDS
    • Fat embolism (rare)

questions.text: An elderly lady is experiencing gradually worsening memory problems for the past 4-5 years, which now affect her daily activities. Recently, she lost her way back home from the church that she has been visiting for the past 30 years. No personality changes, rigidity, or gait disturbances were observed. Which of the following drugs is not recommended for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of insidious loss of episodic memory followed by slowly progressive dementia is suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease. Benztropine (anticholinergic) is not recommended for this patient.

The characteristic feature of Alzheimer's is the degeneration of cholinergic neurons leading to reduced levels of acetylcholine. Therefore, anticholinergic drugs like benztropine are not used. Benztropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist that blocks acetylcholine receptors and is used in the management of Parkinsonism.

Treatment of Alzheimer's disease includes:

  • NMDA antagonist: Memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: Donepezil, Galantamine, Rivastigmine

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue,  breathlessness, paresthesias, and a  stomping gait. The peripheral blood smear shows a megaloblastic picture. The lifecycle of the causative organism is shown below. Which of the following can be responsible for this deficiency?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture is suggestive of Vitamin B12 deficiency which can be caused by the broad or fish tapeworm - Diphyllobothrium latum.

Diphyllobothrium latum infection usually causes vitamin B12 deficiency by absorbing large quantities of vitamin B12 and interfering with the ileal absorption thereby making it unavailable to the host.

The first intermediate host is a freshwater crustacean, while the second intermediate host is freshwater fish. The definitive hosts are man, dog, and cat. The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex.

The adult worm lives inside the small intestine and lays operculated eggs. These freshly passed eggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules. This hexacanth embryo with 6 hooklets inside the egg is called oncosphere.

The pernicious anaemia caused by the infection is called bothriocephalus anaemia.

Treatment is praziquantel in a single dose of 10 mg/kg. In severe B12 deficiency, parenteral vitamin B12 should be given. 

Other options:

Beef tapeworm (option A) is Taenia saginata and pork tapeworm (option B) is Taenia solium. Both of them live in the adult small intestine. Man is the definitive host for both species while cattle and pigs are the intermediate hosts for T. saginata and T. solium respectively. 

Manifestations include:

  • Intestinal taeniasis is characterised by vague abdominal discomfort, indigestion, nausea, diarrhoea and weight loss. 
  • Cysticercosis in subcutaneous tissues (nodules), muscles (acute myositis), and brain (neurocysticercosis)

The below image shows the life cycle of T. saginata and T. solium

 

Dwarf tapeworm (option C) is the common name for Hymenolepis Nana which manifests as nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and irritability in severe cases and the life cycle is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A mother has brought her 6-week-old child for vaccination, and she wants to know if there are any new vaccines that her child should take according to Mission Indradhanush. Which of the following vaccines was introduced recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus vaccine was recently introduced in Intensified Mission Indradhanush.

Rotavirus vaccine is a live, attenuated vaccine administered orally. The different Rotavirus vaccines available are Rotarix, RotaTeq, Rotavac, and Rotasiil. It can be given as a 3-dose schedule starting at 6 weeks of age with a minimum interval of 4 weeks between the doses.

Usually, catch-up immunization is not recommended due to the difficulty in ascertaining the age of the children, and giving the first dose of vaccine beyond 12 weeks of age is associated with an increased risk of intussusception. 

Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to fully immunize children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush, to achieve the same goal by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month.

The diseases are as follows:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hepatitis B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

Diseases included recently:

  • Rotavirus (vaccine given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age)
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • Haemophilus influenzae type B disease (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese encephalitis

questions.text:
A patient with chronic diarrhea and weight loss was evaluated for malabsorption syndromes. Small-intestine biopsy showed PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria. What is the probable diagnosis?

PAS - Periodic acid schiff
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Whipple's disease. Histology shows characteristic PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria. The causative bacilli (Tropheryma whipplei) can be seen both inside the macrophages and extracellularly on biopsy.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily causes malabsorption along with the central nervous system and cardiac problems.

The disease has an insidious onset, characterized by arthralgias, weight loss, chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is made through a biopsy which shows PAS-positive macrophages in the small intestine. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction are other sensitive investigations.

The treatment regimen includes ceftriaxone or meropenem. It is followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 12 months.

 

Other options:

Option A- Celiac disease is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy. A small intestinal biopsy will show characteristic villus blunting, crypt hyperplasia, and inflammation with increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. Serology will show the presence of antibodies against tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deamidated anti-gliadin antibodies. This disease responds well to a gluten-free diet. 

Option C- Tropical sprue also manifests as chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and nutritional deficiencies. Histologic findings are similar to those of celiac disease. However, it does not respond to a gluten-free diet.

Option D- Small bowel bacterial overgrowth occurs when there is an abnormal increase in the bacterial count in the intestine. It occurs in conditions affecting the motility of the intestine, like scleroderma. Duodenal aspirate shows bacterial overgrowth. Breath hydrogen testing with lactulose can also diagnose the condition.

questions.text: In a patient planned for an open appendectomy, succinylcholine is administered intravenously, prior to intubation. What type of muscle relaxant is it?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine is a type of depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant. 

Depolarizing agents depolarize the membrane by opening channels like acetylcholine. But succinylcholine has a longer duration of action because it persists longer at the neuromuscular junction.

This is because of the resistance to acetylcholinesterase. This results in longer-lasting depolarization that also results in a brief period of repetitive excitation that can cause fasciculations and then a phase I block (blocking of neuromuscular transmission and flaccid paralysis). As the concentration of succinylcholine increases, the action switches to a non depolarising phase II block from phase I.

    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins constitutes a part of the acyl carrier protein?
questions.solution:
The vitamin that constitutes a part of the acyl carrier protein is pantothenic acid.

Fatty acids are synthesized by the fatty acid synthase enzyme complex. The individual enzymes required for fatty acid synthesis are linked in this multienzyme polypeptide complex that consists of an acyl carrier protein (ACP). ACP contains vitamin B5/pantothenic acid.

Fatty acid synthesis occurs in the cytosol. It involves the formation of palmitate from acetyl-CoA. This process occurs in the liver, kidney, brain, lung, breast, and adipose tissue. Acetyl-CoA and CO2 act as the substrate and palmitate is the end product.

The image given below shows the steps involved in fatty acid synthesis.

Pantothenic acid/vitamin B5 constitutes a part of the coenzyme A, which functions in the transfer of acyl groups.

Pantothenic acid as coenzyme A is involved in:

  • Fatty acid oxidation
  • TCA cycle (succinyl CoA and acetyl CoA)
  • Cholesterol synthesis (HMG CoA)
  • Acetylation reactions

The intestinal gut flora synthesizes vitamin B5 and hence deficiency is rare. Gopalan's burning foot syndrome is a rare disorder that occurs due to deficiency in pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) and the clinical features include paresthesia (burning type of pain as the name suggests) in lower extremities, staggering gait due to impaired coordination, and sleep disturbance.

questions.text: You are asked to opine on the age of an adolescent boy allegedly involved in a crime. He claims to be a juvenile and pleads for a trial in the juvenile court. Based on the X-ray shown below, the likely age of the boy is:
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the appearance of pisiform but no fusion of base of 1st metacarpal. Therefore, the age is more than 10 years and less than 17 years. Among the given options, the age of the boy is likely to be <17 years.

The base of all metacarpals appears at 2-3 years of age and fuses at 15 -17 years of age. Since it is not fused in this case, the age is less than 17 years. If it has fused the likely age is more than 15 years.

Pisiform ossification center appears at 10-12 years of age (options C and D). Since it is present in this case, the age of the child is more than 10 years. If it had not appeared, the likely age is <12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18-19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5-6 years of age and fuses at 17-18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18.

  • Lunate, Scaphoid, trapezoid, Trapezium – 4 years in females and 5 years in males
  • Pisiform – 9 or 10 years in females and 12 years in males

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fever and painful enlargement of her thyroid gland. She also gives a history of having an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) 2 days ago. A biopsy of the thyroid gland showed findings as seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The painful enlargement of the thyroid gland with a history of URTI and the image above showing granulomatous inflammation in the thyroid gland are suggestive of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis.

This condition is also known as painful subacute thyroiditis, de Quervain thyroiditis, and migratory thyroiditis (this is because the pain can shift to different locations in the thyroid). It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections. Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been clinically implicated in this condition and this condition occurs due to virus-induced host tissue damage that stimulates a cytotoxic T-lymphocyte response to one or more thyroid antigens that damages thyroid follicle cells. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years and women are generally affected three times more often than men. Histopathology shows the presence of granulomas in the thyroid gland.

Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever and examination reveals a small goiter that is very tender.

It has three distinct phases:

  • Thyrotoxic phase
  • Hypothyroid phase
  • Recovery phase

It is treated with large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids, and/or beta-blockers to relieve the observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid phase is prolonged - levothyroxine can be used.

Other options: 

Option A: Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis (postpartum thyroiditis) is typically painless. It often occurs after pregnancy and is characterized by lymphocytic inflammation in the thyroid.

Option B: Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that presents as painless enlargement of the thyroid associated with some degree of hypothyroidism in middle-aged women.

Option D: Riedel's thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by a nonpainful, rapidly growing thyroid mass with extensive fibrosis involving the thyroid and contiguous neck structures.

questions.text:
An HIV patient presents with fever, cough, chest discomfort, and shortness of breath for 1 week. On chest CT, a halo sign is seen. On LPCB preparation, septate hyphae and conidiophores are seen. On the culture of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, black colonies with galactomannan assay positive are obtained. Which of the following drugs is preferred in this condition?

(LPCB- Lactophenol cotton blue)
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of acute invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. Voriconazole is the preferred drug in this condition. 

Invasive aspergillosis occurs due to infection with Aspergillus species. Most cases of invasive aspergillosis involve the lungs. The clinical features include fever, cough which may be productive, chest discomfort, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath.

It is often seen in immunocompromised or debilitated due to prolonged treatment with antibiotics, steroids, and cytotoxics.

Other manifestations of aspergillus species are allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, and superficial infections of the eye, external ear, and nasal sinuses.

Diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis is made when the following findings are observed:

  • A positive culture from the affected organ
  • Aspergillus antigen detection of galactomannan
  • Narrow, septate hyphae with branching at 45o and conidiophores
  • Halo sign on CT scan

The image below shows septate hyphae with 45o branching and conidiophores:

The image below shows the halo sign on the CT scan:

Other options:

Option A: Itraconazole can be used for the treatment of chronic aspergillosis if there is resistance or failure of voriconazole.

Option C: Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for mucormycosis and is the gold standard for induction treatment for cryptococcal meningitis when used in combination with 5-flucytosine. It can be used as a secondary treatment for invasive aspergillosis.

Option D: 5- fluorocytosine is useful in invasive candidiasis, and cryptococcal meningitis if combined with Amp B.

questions.text: A patient from the Mediterranean region was given primaquine to protect against malaria when going on an overseas trip. The patient rapidly developed hemolytic anemia. The defect in which of the following pathways leads to the above condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of the development of hemolytic anemia following oxidative stress is suggestive of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD). G6PD is a part of the hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt pathway.

When glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is defective, both G6PD and the subsequent enzyme in the HMP shunt pathway (6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase) do not produce NADPH. As a result, the red blood cells have insufficient NADPH, to keep glutathione in its reduced, protective form. Under such conditions, a strong oxidizing agent such as primaquine causes damage to the red cell membrane, which causes the cells to lyse, leading to hemolytic anemia.

Other options:

Options A and D: The red blood cells do not oxidize fatty acids, nor do they carry out gluconeogenesis.

Option B: Mutations in glycolysis (such as pyruvate kinase) can lead to anemia, but that occurs in the absence of oxidizing agents as well.
