questions.text: An approved vaccine for a non-lethal disease A has been administered in a village containing many cases of the disease. Which of the following parameters would decrease following the administration of the vaccine?
questions.solution:
Incidence of disease would decrease following the administration of a vaccine.

Incidence refers to the number of new cases occurring in a specific population in a given period of time. It is a health indicator that is subject to variation. An increase in incidence suggests an ineffective control of the disease or a change in the etiology or environment. The introduction of vaccines helps to bring down the incidence of diseases. 

As the condition is non-fatal, the mortality rate, the survival rate, and the case fatality rate are unaffected.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A physiologist is studying the structure of a skeletal muscle sarcomere. He takes a cross-section of sarcomere at a level that appears dark as shown by the arrow in the image below. What will he find?
questions.solution:
The cross-section of sarcomere at a level that appears dark as shown by the arrow marks the A band. It consists of myosin surrounded by actin. 

Sarcomere is the area between two dark Z-lines. It is composed of thick filaments like myosin and thin filaments like actin, tropomyosin, troponin. 

The difference in the refractive index of various muscle fibers leads to cross-striations when viewed under a microscope. The various levels of section of the sarcomere and the myofilaments they are composed of are as follows: 

Sections Myofilaments
I band Only actin
A band (exculding H zone) Actin and myosin
AI junction Actin and myosin
H zone Only myosin
M line Thick filament linked with accessory proteins

Note: Pseudo-H zone is referred to the lighter areas around the M-line including the M-line.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon, while operating, found a primary carcinoma affecting the aryepiglottic folds. The clinical records of the patient mention complaints of dysphagia, but no hoarseness, and lymph node involvement with palpable upper and mid jugular nodes. What is the most likely cancer he is operating on?
questions.solution:
The surgeon is most likely operating on a supraglottic carcinoma.

Laryngeal carcinoma is one of the most common causes of head and neck cancers and is caused by smoking and alcohol abuse. The primary sites are supraglottis, glottis, and subglottis.

Supraglottic carcinoma occurs in the epiglottis, false cords, and aryepiglottic folds. Lesions are often asymptomatic until they are quite large and the first sign would be a neck swelling due to cervical node metastasis. Lymph node metastasis occurs early and level II (upper jugular) and III (middle jugular) lymph nodes are the most commonly involved. As the tumor increases in size, patients complain of alteration in phonation, hoarseness, otalgia, and dysphagia. In the case of epiglottic cancers, bilateral metastases can be seen. 

Other options: 

Option A: Glottic carcinoma presents with hoarseness of voice as its earliest symptom. Lesions of the vocal cords affect its vibratory capacity. Therefore they are diagnosed early and have a better prognosis. Lymphatic spread is rarely seen. 

Option B: Subglottic carcinoma is seen extending from the glottis to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. It involves prelaryngeal, pretracheal, paratracheal, and lower jugular lymph nodes. Stridor or features of laryngeal obstruction is the early features of the disease. Hoarseness is a late feature of subglottic carcinoma. 

Option D: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma causes nasal symptoms like obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, and epistaxis. There are also otologic symptoms due to eustachian tube obstruction causing conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. Cranial nerves may be involved and can cause ophthalmoneurologic features like squint, diplopia, and facial pain. Cervical node metastasis is also commonly seen.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented with complaints of headache, projectile vomiting, and blurring of vision. On investigating, the presence of Homer-Wright rosettes and a well-circumscribed mass over the cerebellum were seen. According to the WHO grading of brain tumors, this tumor belongs to ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of headache, projectile vomiting, and blurring of vision in a 1-year-old boy with the presence of Hommer-wright rosettes and a well-circumscribed mass over the cerebellum is suggestive of medulloblastoma and medulloblastoma corresponds to WHO grade IV brain tumor.

Medulloblastomas are the most common primary malignant CNS tumor in children. It is often undifferentiated and corresponds to WHO grade IV. It accounts for 20% of brain tumors in children. It occurs predominantly in children and exclusively in the cerebellum (by definition).

It has 3 variants:

  • The classic subtype, tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes and expression of synaptophysin is seen.
  • The desmoplastic/nodular variant is characterized by internodular areas of stromal response, marked by collagen and reticulin deposition (i.e., desmoplasia), and “pale islands” or nodules that have more neuropil and show greater neuronal differentiation.
  • The large cell/anaplastic variant shows large, undifferentiated anaplastic cells.

Dissemination through the CSF is a common complication and drop metastases are commonly seen in medulloblastoma. Drop metastases refer to the dissemination of the tumor through the CSF to anatomically lower sites like the spinal cord.

Treatment involves surgical resection which may be followed by radiotherapy.

Grade II

Diffuse astrocytoma

Pilomyxoid astrocytoma

Papillary/ cellular/Clear-cell ependymoma
Grade III

Anaplastic astrocytoma

Anaplastic ependymoma
Grade IV

Malignant pineoblastoma and medulloblastoma

questions.text: A multigravid woman with a previous classical cesarean section presents, in the current pregnancy, with dull aching pain and a sense of something giving way at the height of the contraction. Examination reveals loss of uterine contour and palpable fetal parts. She also has vaginal bleeding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this scenario is uterine scar rupture. 

Uterine rupture is defined as the separation of all uterine layers beyond 28 weeks of gestation. Scar rupture in this patient is most likely due to a previous history of classical Cesarean section. The scar in the classical C section is weak which is more prone to rupture during future pregnancies. 

Uterine rupture can occur spontaneously, due to scar rupture, or iatrogenically. Spontaneous causes of uterine rupture are rare. They occur due to previous damage to the uterus as seen in dilation and curettage, manual removal of placenta, Couvelaire uterus, or in grand multiparous women. Women who have had surgical management of uterine malformations are also at risk. Scar rupture occurs in women who have had previous uterine surgery such as a cesarean section, myomectomy, cornual resection of ectopic pregnancy, or hysterotomy. The incidence is lowest with lower segment cesarean section and highest with classical section. Iatrogenic rupture can occur due to excessive administration of oxytocin, use of prostaglandins, forcible external version, or trauma to the abdomen. 

Clinical features include stoppage of uterine contractions, suprapubic pain, maternal breathlessness and tachycardia, bradycardia in the fetus, acute onset scar tenderness, and in severe cases, shock and hypotension are observed. 

Other options: 

Option A - Placental abruption would also present with acute abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. However, palpable fetal parts is suggestive of uterine rupture.

Option B - Placenta previa would present with painless bleeding per vagina. 

Option D - Scar dehiscence is disruption of part of the scar (not the entire length) with intact fetal membranes and minimal bleeding per vagina. There is no disruption of the visceral peritoneum, and the fetus, placenta, and umbilical cord remain within the uterine cavity.

questions.text: A middle-aged man was recently started on DOTS regimen. If the patient does not take pyridoxine concomitantly, which of the following abnormalities can be expected in his investigations?

choices.text: Ring sideroblasts in bone marrow aspirate

questions.solution:
Ring sideroblasts in bone marrow aspirate are the investigation abnormality that can be expected in a patient who fails to take pyridoxine along with the DOTS regimen. 

DOTS regimen is used to treat tuberculosis. It contains isoniazid which is implicated in interfering with vitamin B6 metabolism and leads to impaired heme synthesis. This causes ineffective erythropoiesis as well as retention of the iron within the mitochondria of erythroblasts. This retention can be seen, in bone marrow aspirates, in the form of nucleated red cells with iron granules distributed around the nucleus. This morphology is termed ringed sideroblasts and they are characteristic of sideroblastic anemia (shown below).

Peripheral smear in sideroblastic anemia would show classic erythrocyte dimorphism (microcytic RBCs intermixed with normal red cell population). MCV would also be decreased. Even though there is ineffective erythropoiesis, the iron overload causes an increase in serum iron concentration and a normal TIBC level. 

Sideroblastic anemia caused by isoniazid is reversible upon the stoppage of the drug.

Other drugs causing the reversible form of this anemia include:

  • pyrazinamide
  • cycloserine
  • chloramphenicol
  • alcohol

It can also be seen in myelodysplastic syndrome. Sideroblastic anemia can also be congenital. The congenital form is transmitted by X-linked or autosomal recessive form of inheritance. 

Other options: 

Option A: Heinz bodies are red cell inclusion bodies that are seen in glucose-6-phosphate-dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presented with primary amenorrhea, short stature, and cognitive impairment. You notice the following characteristic finding in her.  Which of the following drugs is likely to benefit this patient's short stature?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a webbed neck are characteristic of Turner syndrome and somatropin is likely to benefit this child's short stature.

Somatropin refers to the growth hormone (GH) preparations that match the native GH. FDA-approved indications for growth hormone (GH) treatment include growth hormone deficiency, Turner Syndrome, chronic renal failure before transplantation, small for gestational age / short stature, idiopathic short stature, Noonan syndrome, Prader-Willi Syndrome, AIDS-related wasting, and malabsorption associated with the short-bowel syndrome.

It can cause adverse effects such as pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension), type 2 diabetes mellitus, carpal tunnel syndrome, slipped capital femoral epiphysis, and transient gynecomastia. GH therapy is contraindicated in patients with acute critical illness, active malignancy, and non-proliferative and proliferative retinopathy.

Other growth hormone agonists that can be used are mecasermin (recombinant insulin-like growth factor 1) and tesamorelin (GH-releasing hormone).

Turner syndrome (45, XO) is a mendelian disorder characterized by ovarian dysgenesis, lymphedema, web neck, short stature, and cognitive impairment.

Other options: 

Options A & B: Bromocriptine and cabergoline are dopamine receptor agonists that are used in patients with prolactinomas.

Option D: Pegvisomant is a GH-receptor antagonist that is used to treat acromegaly.

questions.text: Fertilization takes place within how many days of ovulation?
questions.solution:
Fertilization takes place within 0-1 day of ovulation. It occurs in the distal portion of the fallopian tube, the ampulla.

Fertilization involves the following steps: 

  • Chemoattraction of the sperm to the ovum. It occurs due to substances produced by the ovum
  • Spermatozoa undergoes the following changes to fertilize the ovum: 
    • Capacitation: It involves epithelial interactions between the sperm and the mucosal surface of the fallopian tube. During this process, the glycoprotein coat and seminal plasma proteins are removed.
    • Acrososmal reaction: It involves the release of enzymes such as acrosin, required to penetrate the zona pellucida. 
  • Adherence of the sperm head to the cell membrane of the ovum
  • Release of the sperm nucleus into the cytoplasm of the ovum

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with complaints of infertility and secondary amenorrhea after 25 years of age. She also had galactorrhoea. Her urine pregnancy test was negative and her prolactin level was 45 ng/mL. The gynecologist prescribes a drug that reduces prolactin levels. What is the mechanism of action of the drug prescribed to her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts hyperprolactinemia. D2 receptor agonists are used as the drug of choice to reduce prolactin levels in hyperprolactinemia.

Cabergoline is a long-acting D2 agonist. Its t1/2 is >60 hours. It undergoes significant first-pass metabolism in the liver.

Cabergoline is the preferred drug for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia because of its greater efficacy and lower side effects. Therapy is initiated at a dose of 0.25 mg twice a week or 0.5 mg once a week. The dose can be increased to 1.5-2 mg two or three times a week as tolerated; the dose should be increased only once every 4 weeks. Doses of 2 mg per week or less should normalize prolactin levels in about 80% of patients. Cabergoline induces remission in a significant number of patients with prolactinomas. At higher doses, it is used in some patients with acromegaly, alone or in conjunction with (somatostatin) SST analogs. 

Adverse effects:

  • Hypotension
  • Nausea

Bromocriptine is shorter-acting when compared with cabergoline.

questions.text: You are evaluating a case of hyperpigmentation. The patient reports having undergone bilateral adrenalectomy a few years back for Cushing's disease. MRI shows an enlargement of the pituitary adenoma. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of hyperpigmentation, history of bilateral adrenalectomy and MRI showing enlarged pituitary adenoma points to the diagnosis of Nelson's syndrome. 

Nelson's syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible.

The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases CRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the original pituitary tumor or formation of a new one.

Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of:

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Excessive ACTH secretion
  • Corticotroph adenoma

Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain performed at regular intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid replacement, as they do not produce cortisol.

The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need for bilateral adrenalectomy these days.

Option B: Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome, also known as progressive supranuclear palsy is a neurodegenerative disease. It affects the brainstem and basal ganglia. 

Option C: Hamman-Rich syndrome also known as acute interstitial pneumonia, is a rare and severe form of idiopathic interstitial lung disease.

Option D: Job syndrome, also known as hyper-IgE syndrome is an autosomal dominant immunodeficiency disorder. It occurs as a result of STAT3 mutation leading to deficiency in the IL-17 producing T cells. This results in impaired recruitment of neutrophils to sites of infection.

questions.text: An elderly man is brought by his daughter complaining that he forgets his way back home multiple times. She says that he is also not able to do his routine activities like taking a shower, making a sandwich, or using an oven which he was doing before. Suspecting Alzheimer's disease, what is the pathological finding that is likely to be seen?

choices.text: Loss of myelin in the base of the pons

questions.solution:
The pathological finding in Alzheimer's disease is the presence of neurofibrillary tangles.

The main microscopic abnormalities in Alzheimer's disease are neuritic plaques containing amyloid β, and neurofibrillary tangles containing hyperphosphorylated tau proteins. Neurofibrillary tangles are present in the cytoplasm of neurons, displacing or encircling the nuclei. On H&E staining, they are seen as basophilic fibrillary structures. They are better visible in immunohistochemistry and silver staining. The number of tangles correlates with the degree of dementia. 

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles.

Neuritic plaques are focal, spherical collections of dilated, tortuous, axonal, or dendritic processes (dystrophic neurites) often around a central amyloid core. It may be surrounded by a clear halo.

The image below shows a picture of amyloid neuritic plaques.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a common cause of dementia in the elderly. The presentation in AD follows a characteristic pattern, starting with defective memory and progressing to language and visuospatial deficits. This is followed by dysfunction in executing activities.

Grossly, the brain shows variable cortical degeneration that is most pronounced in the medial temporal lobe, inferolateral temporal cortex, and the nucleus of Meynert. Cortical atrophy is marked by gyral narrowing and sulcal widening.

Other options - 

Option B: Alpha-synuclein proteins are seen in multiple system atrophy which presents with features of parkinsonism, cerebellar ataxia, and autonomic failure. It is also seen in patients with Parkinson's disease.

Option C: Loss of myelin in the base of the pons and portions of the pontine tegmentum is seen in central pontine myelinolysis, which arises 2 to 6 days after rapid correction of hyponatremia.

Option D: Spongiform transformation of the cerebral cortex, caudate, and putamen is seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Extracellular deposits of aggregated abnormal PrP called Kuru plaques may occur in the cerebellum. It presents as rapidly progressive dementia. It is often associated with involuntary muscle jerks on sudden stimulation known as startle myoclonus.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the organism shown in the image?

choices.text: It can cause abortion in pregnant women
Toxin produced is absorbed through all routes except the skin
Priapism occurs with the bite of this insect

questions.solution:
The given image shows the Spanish fly, which is green in color with shiny wings. It produces cantharidin which is readily absorbed from all surfaces including the skin.

Cantharidin is an animal poison produced by cantharides (Spanish fly or blister beetle). The insect as such or the powder of dried body has the toxic (active) principle.

The routes of absorption include skin and all other mucosae. Within 2-3 hours of coming in contact with the skin, the poison produces burning pain, redness, and vesication. Taken orally, symptoms manifest within 30 minutes to 2 hours.

Features of this poisoning are severe thirst, dysphagia, priapism, swelling of genitals, tenesmus, and convulsions resulting in coma and death. Priapism occurs with the bite of the Spanish fly. Abortion can occur in pregnant women.

Treatment is symptomatic and if ingested, stomach wash needs to be done.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is being evaluated for complaints of seizures and visual disturbances. His magnetic resonance image (MRI) of the brain is as shown. The transmission of the causative agent, in this case, is an example of?
questions.solution:
The MRI brain is showing multiple cysticerci within the brain suggesting neurocysticercosis caused by Taenia solium. The transmission of Taenia solium is an example of cyclo-zoonoses. 

Zoonoses are diseases and infections which are naturally transmitted from a vertebrate to man. They can be transmitted from either animals or other humans.

Cyclo-zoonoses is a type of zoonotic transmission that requires >1 vertebrate host species to complete the developmental cycle of the agent. They do not require any invertebrate hosts. Examples are the human taeniases, echinococcosis, and pentastomid infections.

Cysticercosis is a condition that occurs due to the infection by the larval stage of T. solium. Neurocysticercosis is the most serious and most common form of cysticercosis. 

Clinical features of neurocysticercosis include seizures, increased intracranial pressure, hydrocephalus, psychiatric disturbances, meningoencephalitis, transient paresis, and visual disturbances. 

Diagnosis:

  • Biopsy - the microscopy of the lesion shows invaginated scolex with suckers and hooks. It provides a definitive diagnosis
  • Imaging techniques -  
    • X-rays - may demonstrate calcified cysticerci in the subcutaneous tissues, muscles and skull
    • Computed tomography scan - best method to demonstrate dead calcified cysts
    • MRI - demonstrates non-calcified cysts, ventricular cysts, spinal cysticerci
  • Serology -  
    • Antibody detection - by ELISA in the serum or cerebrospinal fluid
    • Antigen detection - by ELISA. Their presence indicates recent infection
  • Ophthalmoscopy - to detect ocular cysticercosis

Treatment: Excision, praziquantel, albendazole. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Zoonoses

Classification based on their reservoir hosts into:

  • Anthropozoonoses
  • Zoo-anthroponoses
  • Amphixenoses

Classification based on life cycle if infecting agent is:

Mode

Example

No essential developmental/ propagative changes during transmission.

Rabies , Trichinosis, Brucellosis

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors. Inside the invertebrate, the infective agent develops / multiplies. After an extrinsic period of incubation, the infective agent is transmitted to another vertebrate host.

questions.text:
A young woman was brought to the emergency department after she had an episode of syncope. Her heart rate was 50 beats per minute. ECG was taken immediately and is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?

AV - atrioventricular
questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms of syncope with bradycardia are suggestive of a Stokes-Adams attack. ECG findings of the atrioventricular block with RBBB suggest the diagnosis of Mobitz type II block.

In the given ECG, the PR segment remains the same in each successive cycle. However, some P waves are not followed by QRS complexes, which means that some of the P waves are blocked. This is typical of Mobitz type II block. The other finding present is a right bundle branch block that is seen as a wide QRS and rsR' pattern in V1 - V3.

Stokes Adam's attack refers to the syncopal attack resulting from bradycardia or asystole.

Atrioventricular (AV) blocks can be of three types based on ECG appearance:

  • First-degree AV block occurs due to the slowing of conduction within the AV node. 
    • The ECG will show a fixed prolongation of PR interval that is more than 200ms.
  • Second-degree AV block occurs due to the intermittent failure of impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. They can be of two types:
    • Mobitz type I/Wenckebach block is seen as a progressive lengthening of the PR interval followed by an absence of one QRS complex (non-conducted P wave).
    • Mobitz type II block occurs due to an infranodal pathology. Here the PR intervals are fixed, but, there are intermittent non-conducted P waves. 
  • Third-degree AV block/complete heart block (CHB) occurs when none of the impulses from the atria is conducted to the ventricles.
    • The ECG shows complete AV dissociation, which means that there is no relation between the P waves and QRS complexes.

AV node block can occur due to myocardial infarction, fibrosis, sclerosis, and cardiac infiltrative diseases. Iatrogenic causes include cardiac valvular surgery and drugs like digoxin, beta-blockers, verapamil, and diltiazem. 

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

  • IV access

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of alcoholic liver disease is being taken up for cholecystectomy. Which anesthetic agent would be ideal for this patient?
questions.solution:
The anesthetic agent that is ideal for a patient with liver disease is sevoflurane.

Sevoflurane is a fluorinated volatile anesthetic and is an ideal induction agent (has a rapid recovery profile and is not irritating to airways). 

The hepatic effects of volatile anesthetics are caused by alterations in liver perfusion. Hepatic arterial buffer response (HABR) is an autoregulatory mechanism of hepatic blood flow. When portal blood flow decreases due to decreased cardiac output or hypovolemia, the hepatic arterial blood flow increases in order to maintain total hepatic blood flow. This response is best preserved with sevoflurane and isoflurane. Thus, sevoflurane is not known to cause hepatotoxicity. 

Other options:

Option B: Halothane is a volatile anesthetic that has been used for maintenance but it can cause fulminant hepatic necrosis known as halothane hepatitis. 

Option C: Midazolam is an intravenous anesthetic. Its elimination is reduced in liver disease leading to an increased sedating effect.

Option D: Dexmedetomidine is also an intravenous anesthetic that has reduced elimination in patients with liver dysfunction.

questions.text: Which layer of the epidermis do keratinocytes originate from?
questions.solution:
Keratinocytes are derived from stem cells present in the stratum basale, which is marked as layer "4" in the given image.

The epidermis consists of two types of cells: keratinocytes (predominant) and non-keratinocytes (melanocytes, dendritic cells of Langerhans, Merkel cells).

The image shows the histological appearance of the epidermis of the skin. The structures marked are as follows:

  • 1 - Stratum corneum
  • 2 - Stratum granulosum
  • 3 - Stratum spinosum
  • 4 - Stratum basale

The above 4 layers are present in the thin hairy skin. 

The thick glabrous skin over the palms and the soles alone contains a clear homogenous 5th layer between the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum, called the stratum lucidum. 

The epidermis of the skin is made of stratified squamous keratinized epithelium and consists of the following layers. 

  • Stratum basale - It is the deepest layer of the epidermis and is made of a single layer of columnar cells that rest on a basal lamina. It contains stem cells that undergo mitosis to give rise to keratinocytes and is also called stratum germinativum. 
  • Stratum spinosum - Contains several layers of polygonal keratinocytes. These cells are connected to each other with the help of desmosomes. This is also called as prickle cell layer or Malpighian layer.
  • Stratum granulosum - These are made up of flattened cells that have deeply staining granules in their cytoplasm. They are characterized by the presence of deeply staining keratohyalin granules in the cytoplasm. The cells of this layer have Golgi-derived lamellar granules that undergo exocytosis and form a lipid-rich impermeable layer around the cells. This material plays a major role in the skin barrier against water loss.
  • Stratum lucidum - It lies superficial to the stratum granulosum. The cell boundaries are indistinct and this layer appears homogenous.
  • Stratum corneum - It is the most superficial layer of the epidermis. This layer is acellular. It is made up of flattened scale-like elements (squames) containing keratin filaments within a protein. The squames are held together by a glue-like material that contains lipids and carbohydrates. This layer is highly resistant to permeation by water due to its high water content.

The following image shows the layers of the epidermis.

questions.text: An elderly woman, with a history of type 2 DM for 15 years, was initially treated with oral hypoglycemic agents and then with insulin for the last 3 years. To assess the consequent renal involvement,  which of the following tests would you perform on her?
questions.solution:
A test for urine microalbumin can be performed on this patient to assess the consequent renal involvement of diabetes. It is useful for detecting diabetic nephropathy at its incipient diabetic kidney disease stage. Microalbuminuria is defined as the excretion of albumin in the range of 30–300 mg/24 hr urine.

Microalbuminuria occurs about 5-10 years after the incidence of diabetes (Type I and Type II). It cannot be detected in urine dipsticks and usually requires a radioimmunoassay. It is a major risk factor for cardiovascular events and death in patients with type 2 diabetes. In many patients with type 2 diabetes, microalbuminuria succumbs to cardiovascular events before they progress to proteinuria or renal failure. Albuminuria remains the single most important predictor of a faster decline in GFR.

Diabetic nephropathy occurs as a result of glomerular hyperperfusion and renal hypertrophy. The following sequence of changes are seen in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Increased GFR 
  • Incipient diabetic nephropathy - microalbuminuria (30–300 mg/day albumin)
  • Overt diabetic nephropathy - macroalbuminuria ( >300 mg/day albumin)
  • End-stage renal disease 

The characteristic lesion of diabetic nephropathy is nodular or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis, also called Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules. It is pathognomonic for this condition. The following image shows Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules.

Other non-specific findings seen on biopsy include glomerular basement membrane thickening (highly sensitive) and diffuse glomerulosclerosis (most common pattern) due to diffuse mesangial thickening.

Diabetic nephropathy can be prevented by strict glycemic control. Associated hypertension and dyslipidemia should be promptly treated. Drugs like ACE inhibitors and ARBs can reverse albuminuria and glomerular filtration rate. Hypoglycemic drugs like sulfonylureas and metformin should not be used in advanced renal disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old-lady with CKD presents with bilateral limb muscle weakness and fasciculations. On investigation, her serum potassium level was found to be 6 mEq/L. What is the likely mechanism to have caused her clinical features?

choices.text: Resting membrane potential of nerves is hyperpolarised
Resting membrane potential moved closer to the threshold potential
Resting membrane potential moved away from threshold potential

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly lady with CKD presenting with bilateral limb muscle weakness and fasciculations along with serum potassium levels of 6 mEq/L (normal levels: 3.5-5) is suggestive of hyperkalemia. Resting membrane potential moved closer to the threshold potential is the likely mechanism to have caused her clinical features. 

Resting membrane potential (RMP) is the difference in the electrical potentials between the cytoplasm of the cell and the extracellular space. 

At rest, there are more open K+ channels compared to Na+ channels, thus the membrane permeability of K+ is greater. As a result of this, the intracellular and extracellular K+ concentrations are the major determinants of the RMP. Furthermore, the RMP is close to the equilibrium potential of K+ in general. 

In hyperkalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is increased. Thus the RMP moves closer to the threshold to elicit an action potential leading to a more excitable nerve. The excitable nerve stimulates the muscle repeatedly causing fasciculations, exhaustion of muscle, and weakness.

In hypokalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is reduced. Thus the RMP is reduced and the neuron is hyperpolarized.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented to the emergency department with signs of shock. Upon further investigations, a diagnosis of a ruptured tubo-ovarian mass was made. At what stage of pelvic inflammatory disease is she in?
questions.solution:
The ruptured tubo-ovarian mass belongs to stage IV of pelvic inflammatory diseases. It usually presents with a sudden worsening of the patient's condition.

Tubo ovarian abscess is a complication of acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). It can be unilateral or bilateral and is characterized by dull or sharp abdominal pain. It is associated with other features like fever and an adnexal mass. On auscultation, a frictional rub can be heard throughout all quadrants of the abdomen which can be suggestive of a ruptured ovarian abscess. 

Treatment involves the administration of parenteral antibiotics till the patient has been afebrile for at least 24 hours. Following this, oral doxycycline with either metronidazole or clindamycin is given for 14 days. Ruptured abscess is treated surgically.

questions.text: A healthy woman with a normal pregnancy is being evaluated during her antenatal visit. Which of the following is likely to be seen in her thyroid profile?
questions.solution:
Free T3 (triiodothyronine), free T4 (thyroxine), and TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) levels remain normal during pregnancy. Therefore, normal free T3 levels are likely to be seen in the thyroid profile of a healthy woman with normal pregnancy.

Endocrine glands show physiological changes during pregnancy to meet the extra demands of the growing fetus. Maternal total T4 and T3 levels are increased during the early period of gestation due to stimulation of the thyroid gland by hCG (α-subunit of hCG is similar to TSH). TSH levels in the first trimester decline slightly (but remain in the normal range). The level of TSH is normal during the second and third trimesters.

The physiologically important free T4 and free T3 levels are unchanged due to the elevated levels of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG). Hence, pregnant women remain euthyroid.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions, would the following procedure be contraindicated?
questions.solution:
The given image is depictive of Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) or Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT). Malignancy developing from a wound (like Marjolin’s ulcer) is a contraindication for NPWT. 

Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) or NPWT is a therapeutic technique using a vacuum dressing to promote healing in acute and chronic wounds. The principle of VAC is an intermittent negative pressure of ~125 mmHg hastens debridement and formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds. The negative pressure removes the interstitial fluid to decrease the edema and also increases the blood flow. The principle is used in treating diabetic foot ulcers as well as stage III and IV pressure ulcers. It is useful for the same reason in traumatic wounds, flaps and grafts, and dehisced incisions.

Some of the contraindications of NPWT are:

  • Exposed vasculature or organ surfaces has an increased risk of leakage of blood following tissue erosion.
  • Non-enteric and unexplored fistulae can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
  • Necrotic tissue or eschar in the wound bed can exacerbate the non healing and necrosis. 
  • Inadequate debridement of devitalized soft tissue or bone increases the risk of infection.
  • The presence of an underlying malignancy due to its ability to propagate and metastasize.
  • Active osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man met with a minor accident, following which he developed difficulty in abducting his hip.  Which of the following is the most likely muscle to be affected?
questions.solution:
The muscle most likely to be affected in this case is the gluteus medius, which is responsible for the abduction of the hip joint.

The gluteus medius is a powerful abductor of the hip joint and is assisted by the gluteus minimus, tensor fascia lata, piriformis, and sartorius. Injury to the gluteus medius and minimus causes the sinking of the pelvis on the unsupported side when trying to stand on the affected limb (positive Trendelenberg sign). This produces a characteristic lurching gait.

Gluteus medius and minimus can be tested by medially rotating the thigh against resistance with the knee flexed.

Adduction of the hip joint is mainly caused by adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, and gracilis.

Flexion of the hip joint is mainly caused by psoas major, iliacus, rectus femoris and assisted by pectineus, tensor fascia lata, and sartorius.

Extension of the hip joint is caused by gluteus maximus, biceps femoris, semitendinosus, semimembranosus (hamstrings), and adductor magnus and assisted by the posterior fibers of gluteus medius. 

Other options:

Option A - Gluteus maximus produces extension of the hip joint.

Option B - Quadriceps femoris consists of four muscles (rectus femoris, vastus medialis, vastus lateralis, vastus intermedius) and produces extension of the knee joint.

Option C - Quadratus femoris produces lateral rotation of the thigh.

questions.text: The image below depicts the structure of the HIV virus. Which of the following genes determines the core and shell of the viral structure?
questions.solution:
The given image is the structure of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and the gag gene determines the core and shell of the HIV virus.

It is expressed as a precursor protein, p55. This precursor protein is cleaved into three proteins, p15, p18 and p24, which make up the viral core and shell. The major core antigen is p24 which can be detected in serum during the early stages of HIV infection before antibodies appear.

HIV has structural and non-structural genes: 

Structural genes are the genes coding for structural proteins. They are

  • Gag gene: Codes for core and shell protein p55, which is cleaved to p15, p18 and p24  
  • Env gene: Codes for envelope glycoprotein gp160 which is cleaved to gp120 and gp41
  • Pol gene: Codes for the enzymes polymerase, reverse transcriptase, protease and endonuclease

Non-structural and regulatory genes:

  • tat: Trans-activating gene
  • nef: Negative factor gene
  • rev: Regulator of virus gene
  • vif: Viral infectivity factor gene
  • vpu: (only in HIV-1) and vpx (only in HIV-2)
  • vpr: Stimulates only the promoter region of the virus
  • LTR: Long terminal repeat sequences

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with complaints of dribbling of urine on coughing or sneezing. A diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence was suspected. All the following tests can help in the diagnosis of this condition, except _____.
questions.solution:
All the above tests can help in the diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence, except the methylene blue 3 swab test. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done for genitourinary fistulae.

Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) is defined as a small involuntary leakage of urine with increased abdominal pressure in the absence of detrusor contraction. It occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction. It is generally due to hypermobility of the urethra, loss of posterior angle, or sphincteric dysfunction. The risk factors include older age, post-menopausal status, multiparity, obesity, smoking,  pregnancy and puerperium, and hereditary conditions which lead to loss of collagen tissue.

Tests done for GSI (Genuine stress incontinence) are:

  • Stress test (Option A): The patient is catheterized after she voids urine and the residual urine in the bladder is measured. Examining for objective evidence of a leak:
    • The patient is asked to squat over a preweighed absorbent pad and is asked to cough and strain.
    • The patient is placed in a lithotomy position and asked to cough and strain for further evidence of a leak.
  • Cotton swab stick test (Option B): A Q tip cotton swab is introduced into the urethra. Initially, the tip of the swab would be horizontal to the floor. Upon straining, in patients without GSI, the tip of the swab would not shift more than 10-15 degrees above the horizontal. In patients with GSI, the tip might go beyond 50-70 degrees from the horizontal.
  • Marshall and Bonney test (Option D): The region of the bladder neck is elevated. If there is no leakage of urine on straining, it indicates a favorable outcome following surgical repair.
  • Urethroscopy.
  • Urodynamic evaluation- cystometry, urethrocystometry, uroflowmetry, etc.

Management includes : 

  • Conservative approach: Kegel pelvic floor exercises, magnetic/electric stimulation for nerve injuries, estrogen cream for post-menopausal women, etc
  • Surgical management: The various surgeries include:
    • Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz and Pereyra Burch
    • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension
    • Slings
      • Tension-free sling
      • Transobturator type
    • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck

Methylene blue 3 swab test is used to diagnose genitourinary fistulae. Three cotton swabs are placed in the vagina—one at the vault, one in the middle, and one just above the introitus. The methylene blue dye is instilled into the bladder through a rubber catheter and the patient is asked to walk for about 5 minutes. She is then asked to lie down and the swabs are inspected. If the swabs are stained with urine and not with the dye, it is indicative of a ureteric fistula. If the lowermost swab is stained blue, it is indicative of a urethral fistula. If the lower 2 swabs are stained blue, it is indicative of a vesicovaginal fistula.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is diagnosed to have Stage II (A) Hodgkin's lymphoma. What staging system was most likely used to classify the tumor of this patient?
questions.solution:
Clinical staging of both Hodgkin and Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is done by Ann-Arbor classification. 

Option B: Masaoka staging is used for thymoma.

Option C: Modified Durie–Salmon staging is used for multiple myeloma.

Involvement of two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm alone (II)

or

III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm without (III) or with (IIIE) localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site

Diffuse involvement of one or more extra lymphatic organs or sites with or without lymphatic involvement 

All stages are further divided on the basis of the absence (A) or presence (B) of fever, night sweats and/or unexplained weight loss >10% of body weight.

questions.text:
Which among the following best describes sepsis?

SOFA - Sepsis-related Organ Failure Assessment

qSOFA - quick Sepsis-related Organ dysfunction Assessment

LODS - The Logistic Organ Dysfunction System score

SIRS - Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome score

choices.text: Suspected or documented infection with SIRS score ≥ 1
Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score  ≥ 1
Suspected or documented infection with LODS score ≥ 1

questions.solution:
Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2 best describes sepsis among the given options.

Sepsis is defined as, life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection.

To help in recognizing sepsis, Sepsis-3 clinical criteria have been used, which include:

  • Suspected infection  
  • Organ dysfunction which is assessed using the SOFA score - an increase of ≥ 2 points from the baseline of this score 

SOFA score ranges from 0 to 24 points and is divided across 6 organ systems. It includes:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

A simplified version of the SOFA score is known as the qSOFA score (Option C). It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is considered superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thus, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

Other scoring systems for sepsis:

Option A:

Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) is an exaggerated defence response of the body to a noxious stressor to localize and then eliminate the endogenous or exogenous source of the insult. SIRS is diagnosed when two of the following are present:

  • Hyperthermia (>38 Degree Celcius) or Hypothermia (<36 Degree Celcius)
  • Tachypnoea (>20/min) or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) of less than 32 mm Hg
  • Tachycardia (>90/min) 
  • White cell count >12 x 109/litre or <4 x 109/litre or >10% Band forms

 Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection. SIRS score is no longer recommended as is it not specific to infection.

Option D: LODS score is not recommended as it is complex and has too many variables.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing surgical resection of a large swelling as shown below.  The CT scan showed a lesion greater than 10 cm with thick septa and foci of nodular enhancement. Biopsy revealed mature adipose tissue infiltrating the adjacent structures.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with a CT scan showing a large lesion, thick septa, foci of nodular enhancement, and a biopsy revealing mature adipose tissue infiltrating the adjacent structures has the most likely diagnosis as liposarcoma.

It is the most common retroperitoneal sarcoma seen in the 5-6th decade. They present at late stages with non-specific symptoms. CT can be useful in diagnosis. 

Surgical resection of the tumor is the definitive treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Retroperitoneal teratoma is a germ cell tumor characterized by fat components, cystic areas, and calcifications in a CT. Surgical resection is the main treatment of choice.

Option B: Leiomyosarcoma is the second most common retroperitoneal tumor seen in 50-60 years of age. It is characterized by a bulk mass with necrosis, with or without hemorrhage.

Option D: Myxofibrosarcoma is seen in individuals with a mean age of 65 years. They have non-specific findings in imaging.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the pediatrician as shown below. On examination, the mass is painless, soft, and fluctuating. The slip sign is negative.  Which of the following will not form the treatment option for this child?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, brilliantly trans-illuminant, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma. Sistrunk operation is not done in cystic hygroma. It is a surgery done for a thyroglossal cyst. 

Cystic hygroma is a lymph-filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development. It is most commonly present in the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. Since the sac is filled with lymph, it is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly trans-illuminant.

Initially, the treatment includes aspiration of the contents. Later once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue, it is excised.

Single cysts are treated with sclerosing therapy. Commonly used sclerosants include OK–432, which is an inactive strain of group A Streptococcus pyogenes, pure ethanol, interferon alfa-2a, and doxycycline.

Complete excision is done in case of multiple cysts.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Meningocele

questions.text: A young male patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. The X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is ideal for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a transverse fracture of the patella, and the ideal management for this is tension-band wiring.

The patient presents with pain and swelling over the affected knee. Patellar tenderness and bruise over the front of the joint can be present. Crepitus may be felt in comminuted fractures. The patient cannot lift his leg in full extension(extension lag) due to the disruption of the extensor apparatus. Hemarthrosis can be associated.

Patellar fractures can be transverse, longitudinal, polar, or comminuted.

The radiological examination includes AP and lateral views. A skyline view of the patella is required in some cases of undisplaced fractures.

Management of patellar fractures: 

Undisplaced fractures: It is treated with a plaster cast extending from the groin to just above the malleoli, with the knee in full extension. This is called a cylinder cast (option A) and is usually left in place for a period of at least 3 weeks.

A transverse fracture is treated by a surgical procedure consisting of the reduction of the fragments known as tension-band wiring and K- wire fixation. This is followed by the repair of the extensor retinacula and physiotherapy.

Comminuted fractures are treated by open reduction and fixation. Patellectomy (option C) is the preferred option in this case as restoration of a smooth articular surface is difficult in this condition. Patella-saving operations are recently more performed with advancements in fixation techniques.

Longitudinal fractures usually have intact extensor apparatus. They can be treated with a cylinder cast or extension brace initially, followed by a range of motion.

Complications are knee stiffness, extensor weakness, and osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A  G2P1L1 woman at her 31st week of gestation comes for an antenatal checkup for the first time. On history, she remembers getting 2 tetanus shots during the antenatal period of the first pregnancy which was 2 years back. What action should be taken with regardsto tetanus immunization for this mother?

choices.text: Give a booster dose of Td
Give the first dose of Td now and the second dose before 36 weeks of gestation
Give tetanus antitoxin just before delivery

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a mother who has been immunized in the last pregnancy falling within the past three years, a booster dose of Td is given. 

Unimmunized pregnant women: Two doses of tetanus and adult Diphtheria (Td) should be given, the first as early as possible during pregnancy and the second at least a month later and at least 3 weeks before delivery. These doses may be given between 16-36 weeks of pregnancy.

Previously immunized pregnant women: A booster dose is considered sufficient as long as the patient has been immunized within the past 3 years. If the previous immunization was beyond three years, 2 doses of Td are administered 4 weeks apart. Ideally, Td-2 or booster doses are given before 36 weeks of pregnancy. Td is given to a woman in labor if she has not previously received Td.

The infants born to mothers who have not previously received 2 doses of tetanus toxoid have a high risk of neonatal tetanus. They can be protected by injection of antitoxin (heterologous serum, 750 IU) if it is administered within 6 hours of birth. 

Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. The MoHFW recommends the replacement of TT vaccine with Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5 ml is administered in the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

questions.text: A newborn baby has rashes over the face as shown below, microcephaly, bilateral cataracts, and sensory neural hearing loss. What is the most common type of cataract seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. The type of cataract seen in this condition is a nuclear pearly cataract. 

Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) occurs due to the transplacental transmission of the virus from an infected mother to the fetus. The transmissibility is highest in the first trimester (<11 weeks).

Affected babies present with a triad of:

  • Sensorineural deafness
  • Cataracts- nuclear pearly cataracts
  • Congenital heart disease- the most common is the patent ductus arteriosus.

Other important features are rashes over the body, salt and pepper retinopathy, and microcephaly. Some babies may develop meningoencephalitis following CRS.

It is diagnosed by the presence of IgM antibodies against rubella in the cord or neonatal blood. Administration of MMR vaccine in prepubertal and women who are about to get married can prevent the disease.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady with a known history of mitral stenosis presented with 8 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test. Which of the following is not true about labor and delivery in this case?

choices.text: Oxytocin is used to control hemorrhage

questions.solution:
From the given options, the false statement about the management of mitral valve stenosis is option D. 

Epidural analgesia is safe in most heart diseases and is not contraindicated.

Management during labor in heart diseases like mitral stenosis: 

Vaginal delivery is preferred over cesarean, and induction of labor is safe. Induction can be done with vaginal PGE2.

First stage of labor:

  • Lateral semirecumbent position
  • Oxygen administration (5 to 6 L/min)
  • Analgesia by epidural, combined epidural/spinal, or continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Fluids should not be infused at more than 75 mL/h
  • Prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial endocarditis during labor and 48 h after delivery
  • Central venous pressure monitoring

Second stage of labor:

  • No maternal pushing
  • Cut short second stage by forceps or ventouse under pudendal and/or perineal block anesthesia
  • Withhold IV ergometrine with the delivery of anterior shoulder

Third stage of labor:

  • Oxytocin by infusion

Cesarean delivery is reserved for obstetric indications such as:

  • Dilated aortic root >4cm
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Acute severe congestive heart failure
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis
  • Warfarin within 2 weeks of delivery
  • Emergency valve replacement immediately after delivery

questions.text: Which of the following salivary gland neoplasm is responsible for the given appearance in the Tc-99m radionuclide scan?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Warthin's tumor is the salivary gland tumor that appears as a hot spot on the technetium-99m scan as shown in the image.

Because of the high mitochondrial content within oncocytes, the oncocyte-rich Warthin's tumor and oncocytomas incorporate technetium-99m and appear as hot spots on radionuclide scans.

Warthins tumor or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum is the second most common benign tumor of the parotid gland. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a slow-growing, benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor and involves the lower pole of the parotid gland. It usually occurs unilaterally.

Treatment is superficial parotidectomy.

Grossly, they appear as round to oval encapsulated masses, 2-5 cm in diameter, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

The image below shows the gross appearance of Warthin's tumor. Note the well-encapsulated mass.

Histologically, Warthin's tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with a columnar luminal layer and a cuboidal layer. 


Other options:

Only a minority of salivary gland tumors show uptake on 99Tc scintigraphy. They include:

  • Warthins tumor
  • Oncocytoma of salivary glands

Tc-99m radionuclide scan is not done for pleomorphic adenoma, mucoepidermoid carcinoma, and adenoid cystic carcinoma as they show variable uptake. 

Option A: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms and it most commonly involves the parotid gland (in about 60% of the cases). These are benign and mixed tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. They present in the buccal cavity, parotid, or submandibular area as a painless, slow-growing, mobile mass.

Histopathology:

Grossly, the tumor is rounded and well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm in the greatest dimension. They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate. The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma (image given below).

Microscopic features include the epithelial elements which resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells and these are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells. They are dispersed within a background of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles are seen in histopathology. The image is shown below.

Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a malignant tumor that involves minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells resemble swiss cheese due to an organized cribriform growth pattern. The image is shown below.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is a life-threatening complication that should be monitored in the first 24 hours in a patient who underwent thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
The life-threatening complication that should be monitored in the first 24 hours after surgery is hematoma formation.

Hematoma formation in the neck postoperatively is most commonly seen in the first 6 hours and in 20 percent of individuals between 6-24 hours. The risk factors for this are male sex, increasing age, bilateral surgery, Grave's disease, and anticoagulation.

The manifestations are due to compression on the trachea leading to airway compromise. It includes pain, oozing from the incision, ecchymosis, swelling, and, stridor. 

Avoiding tight closure of strap muscles will allow the hematoma to drain into the surrounding tissue. 

If a hematoma occurs:

  • The incision holding the three layers of the thyroidectomy bed (skin, platysma, and strap muscles) must be opened to allow for maximal decompression.
  • Endotracheal intubation is performed to maintain airway patency. 

Other options: 

Option A: Unilateral superior laryngeal nerve can occur as a complication of thyroid surgery. This will lead to a change in voice power and range. It is not life-threatening. 

Option B: Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve can also be injured in thyroid surgery. They are asymptomatic but in a few may cause hoarseness of voice and don't need any treatment.

Option D: Parathyroid insufficiency occurs due to the removal of the parathyroids or infarction due to damage to the parathyroid end arteries. Patients usually present 2-5 days after the surgery with hypocalcemia. 

Note: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy can also occur postoperatively. It causes dyspnoea and stridor but the voice is good. These cases required emergency tracheostomy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman who did not receive any vaccination prior to conception presented with coryza, maculopapular rash over the trunk, and fever during her first trimester of pregnancy. Following birth, the newborn presented with bilateral cataracts and a patent ductus arteriosus. What could be the possible infection that the mother suffered from?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history the diagnosis in the newborn is congenital rubella syndrome and the mother suffered from rubella infection. 

Maternal rubella is a viral infection that is subclinical in almost half of the cases. However, the mother is at risk of transmitting the virus to the fetus during the first trimester of pregnancy which causes congenital rubella syndrome in the child. The illness is usually mild and the patient presents with maculopapular rash starting on the face and progressing to the trunk and extremities. The incubation period of the infection is from 12 to 23 days. The virus is isolated upto 2 weeks after the onset of rashes in urine, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid. 

In the fetus, the infection presents as congenital rubella syndrome and the features include bilateral cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and congenital heart disease, more commonly patent ductus arteriosus.  

Other options:

Option A: Toxoplasma infection occurs due to the consumption of uncooked meat and is characterized by muscle pain, headache and lymphadenopathy which is not present in this patient. The fetus will have a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications.

Option B: Parvovirus infection is characterized by erythroderma with red rashes giving an appearance of a slapped cheek. The main defect in the fetus is anemia.

Option C: Infection with varicella virus is characterized by pruritic vesicular rashes. The fetus can develop fetal varicella syndrome characterized by chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, limb hypoplasia, growth restriction, cerebral atrophy, and cicatricial skin lesions.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient presents to your clinic with complaints of mildly itchy, multiple rash-like lesions on the back since two weeks. He says that it was preceded by a single large patchy lesion on his lower back. An image of the physical examination findings is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is pityriasis rosea, which has typical collarette scales. A collarette scale is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion.

Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting disease, probably infective in origin, affecting mainly children and young adults. It is characterized by a distinctive skin eruption and minimal constitutional symptoms. It is also called pityriasis circinata et maculata of Vidal.

The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch. Christmas tree pattern along cleavage lines with the peripheral collarette of scale producing the hanging curtain sign is also seen. 

Note: Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated stratum corneum.

questions.text: A male patient who lost his job recently became irritable and had a sad mood for most of the time. Thinking about the future made him worried and he felt irritated towards his family members. He occasionally went out for watching movies with his friends and was able to enjoy but on returning home he felt similar symptoms. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sad and irritable mood following a loss of job recently and impairment in the social functioning point to a probable diagnosis of adjustment disorder. 

Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to a stressful event. Stressors may be:

  • Single like loss of job or divorce 
  • Multiple like the death of a parent together with the loss of a job 
  • Recurrent like seasonal business difficulties

Diagnosing criteria for adjustment disorder include:

  • Development of emotional or behavioral response within 3 months of the onset of the stressor
  • The symptoms or behavior are clinically significant, where, any one of the following are met - 
    • The response is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor
    • Significant impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning
  • Stress-related disturbance does not meet the criteria for another mental disorder or exacerbation of pre-existing mental disorder
  • The symptoms do not represent normal bereavement
  • Once the stressor is terminated, the symptoms do not persist for more than an additional 6 months

Treatment:

  • Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice
  • Pharmacotherapy- anxiolytic or antidepressant medications 

Others options: 

Option A: Generalized anxiety disorder is excessive worry and anxiety with respect to several activities or events for most days during at least 6 months period. 

Option C: Mixed anxiety with depression is diagnosed when there are subsyndromal symptoms of both anxiety and depression along with autonomic symptoms such as tremors, palpitation, dry mouth, and sensation of churning in the stomach. 

Option D: Atypical depression is a type of depression characterized by mood reactivity, which is brightening of the mood in response to positive events, significant weight gain or increase in appetite; hypersomnia, leaden paralysis, and/or interpersonal rejection sensitivity, resulting in sig­nificant social or occupational impairment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman had diabetes mellitus that was not controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. She was started on short-acting insulin to prevent post-prandial glycemia. Which of the following drug would have been used?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, insulin aspart is a short-acting insulin that has better control of meal time hyperglycemia and lower rates of postprandial hypoglycemic events. 

The short-acting insulin analogs are absorbed more rapidly from subcutaneous sites and should be injected 15 min or less before a meal. When used to treat glycemia after meals, the short-acting analogs have lower rates of hypoglycemia and improved A1c levels. It has rapid absorption and a shorter duration of action due to instantaneous dissociation into monomers. Short-acting insulin analogs are:

  • Insulin lispro is identical to human insulin except at positions B28 and B29.
  • Insulin aspart is formed by the replacement of proline at B28 with aspartic acid, reducing self-association.
  • Insulin glulisine is formed when glutamic acid replaces lysine at B29 and lysine replaces asparagine at B3.

Regular insulin has slow absorption following subcutaneous injection and should be injected 30–45 min before a meal. 

Short-acting insulins are used in the management of diabetes mellitus, diabetic ketoacidosis (regular insulin) and in non-ketotic hyperosmolar hyperglycemic coma.

questions.text: Which of the following part of the nephron is the site of maximum water reabsorption?
questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), marked as "1" in the above image of the nephron is the site of maximum water reabsorption.

The structures marked in the image are as follows:

  1. PCT
  2. Distal convoluted tubule (DCT)
  3. Loop of Henle
  4. Collecting duct

PCT reabsorbs about 67% of the filtered water. Isosmotic reabsorption occurs in the PCT i.e. the amount of solute and water reabsorbed are coupled and are proportional to each other. Here the solute that is reabsorbed along with the water is Na+. So 67% of both flitered Na+ and water are reabosrbed in the PCT. 

These large amounts of Na+ and water reabsorption is essential in maintaining the ECF volume. 

In addition to the isosmotic reabsorption, the water reabsorption in the PCT also occurs through the active water channels known as aquaporin-1.

questions.text: Among the following, what is the initial fluid of choice for treating diarrhea in an infant who has normal weight for length with rotavirus infection?
questions.solution:
Low osmolarity ORS is the initial fluid of choice for treating diarrhea in an infant who has normal weight for length with rotavirus infection. 

The loss of sodium stool in rotavirus infection is around 50-70 mmol/L, which can be replenished by low osmolarity ORS with a sodium concentration of 75 mmol/L. It is also called WHO-reduced osmolarity ORS.

The low osmolarity of the ORS in the intestinal lumen as compared to the blood facilitate absorption of fluid and hence the electrolytes due to the solvent drag.

Studies have shown that low osmolarity ORS causes reduction in stool output, decrease in vomiting, and decrease in the use of unscheduled intravenous fluids without increasing the risk of hyponatremia.

ReSoMal is given to severely malnourished children.
