questions.text: Which of the following movements is being tested in the picture given below?
questions.solution:
External rotation of hip is being tested in the given image.

Rotatory movements of the hip joint can be measured with the knee flexed or extended. However, more precise measurements are obtained when the rotation is tested with the flexed knee. The procedure involves the following steps.

  • The patient is made to lie supine.
  • The examiner holds the knee with one hand and ankle with the other hand.
  • The knee and hip are flexed to 90 degrees.
  • Rotation movement is produced at the hip joint by stabilising the knee and moving the leg as the lever.
  • If the hip is rotated such that the leg moves medially, external rotation of the hip occurs.
  • If the hip is rotated such that the leg moves laterally, internal rotation of the hip occurs.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is diagnosed with primary open-angle glaucoma and is started on latanoprost. It lowers the intraocular pressure mainly by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue. It lowers intraocular pressure (IOP) mainly by increasing the uveoscleral outflow. 

Prostaglandin analogs are the preferred drugs used in the management of primary open-angle glaucoma. They have largely replaced beta blockers because of fewer systemic side effects (like an exaggeration of bronchoconstriction in asthma), once-daily dosing, and increased potency in lowering the IOP. Commonly used prostaglandin analogs are latanoprost,travoprost, bimatoprost, and tafluprost. 

The common ocular side effects are conjunctival hyperemia, eyelash thickening, and iris hyperpigmentation. They can increase the incidence of cystoid macular edema following cataract surgery. They can aggravate anterior uveitis and herpetic keratitis.

Alpha receptor agonists like epinephrine, apraclonidine, and brimonidine also increase the uveoscleral outflow.

Other options:

Option A: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, alpha-receptor stimulators, and beta-blockers reduce IOP by decreasing aqueous production. 

Options C and D: Cholinergic agonists cause the contraction of the ciliary muscles, which increases the trabecular outflow by releasing the pupillary block. In angle-closure glaucoma, cholinergic agents open the angle by contraction of the sphincter pupillae pulling the iris away from the trabecula (releasing the pupillary block).

questions.text: A patient who sustained a talar fracture before 6 weeks now came for follow-up. His  X-Ray shows the presence of Hawkin's Sign.  What does this indicate?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of talus is likely
Avascular necrosis of calcaneum is unlikely
Avascular necrosis of talus is unlikely
Avascular necrosis of calcaneum is likely

questions.solution:
A patient who has sustained a talar fracture before 6 weeks and now showing Hawkin's sign in an X-ray of talus indicates avascular necrosis of talus is unlikely to develop.

Avascular necrosis/osteonecrosis is a complication that occurs following the fracture of the neck of the talus. It is seen in the body of the talus.

The earliest radiograph finding is the increased density of the avascular segment whereas the rest of the talus has become porotic due to disuse. Hawkin's sign indicates that the dome of the talus has become osteoporotic, implying it has a blood supply. This is looked at 6-8 weeks after the injury. 

If there is a dense segment of the talus bone after a few weeks of the talus fracture, it means there is an avascular segment. This is the earliest X-ray sign of avascular necrosis of the body of the talus. 

Weight-bearing should be delayed. Arthrodesis of the ankle is recommended when there is flattening or fragmentation of the talus. It can also be done when the pain and disability are marked. 

The X-ray below shows the presence of subchondral lucency or Hawkin's sign.

questions.text:
A patient, who is known to have familial hypercholesterolemia, is on atorvastatin and ezetimibe. However, his cholesterol levels are still unacceptably high. To reduce the risk of a major cardiovascular event, an additional monoclonal antibody, which is a PCSK9 inhibitor, is added to his regimen. They act by reducing the level of which of the following?

PCSK9 - Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9
questions.solution:
PCSK9 inhibitors act by reducing the level of LDL cholesterol.

PCSK9 is a serine protease that causes lysosomal degradation of the LDL receptors present on the surface of the hepatocytes. Monoclonal antibodies directed against PCSK9 such as alirocumab and evolocumab counter this and cause the persistence of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. This leads to more LDL uptake from the circulation, bringing down the LDL-cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are indicated only as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who have elevated LDL-cholesterol levels despite being on maximum statin therapy.

Familial hypercholesterolemia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to mutations that reduce the functioning of LDL receptors, the most common being a mutation in the LDLR gene itself. Physical findings present in some of the patients include tendon xanthomas (especially involving the Achilles tendons) and corneal arcus. These patients may have a myocardial infarction at a young age. Diagnosis is usually established based on biochemical tests. LDL cholesterol >190 mg/dL or total serum cholesterol >300 mg/dL without any secondary etiology should point to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia. Homozygotes for the disease might have total serum cholesterol even up to 1000 mg/dL. 

Treatment includes restriction of saturated and trans fats in the diet and high-intensity statin therapy. If adequate control is not achieved with statins alone, a cholesterol absorption inhibitor (Ezetimibe) or a PCSK9 inhibitor (Alirocumab, Evolocumab) can be added to the treatment.

questions.text: All of the following local anesthetics have a long duration of action, except ______.
questions.solution:
All the given options have a long duration of action except lidocaine, which has an intermediate duration of action.

Lidocaine is a local anesthetic that is widely used wherever an agent with an intermediate duration of action is needed. When given along with epinephrine, lidocaine's action is prolonged because of decreased absorption. 

Tetracaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine are long-acting local anesthetics.

Local anesthetics are agents that cause a reversible loss of sensory/motor paralysis in a restricted area. Clinically, they can be used for:

  • topical - direct application of the aqueous solution to mucous membranes
  • infiltration - direct injection of agent to tissue
  • field block - subcutaneous injection to anesthetize region distal to the injection
  • nerve block - injection directly onto peripheral nerves/ nerve plexus 
  • intravenous (Bier's block) - relies on vasculature to anesthetize nerve trunk and endings
  • spinal - injected into CSF in lumbar space
  • epidural - injected into epidural space

questions.text: A patient who is known to have squamous cell carcinoma of the left lung was admitted to the ward for chemotherapy. He suddenly has massive hemoptysis. How should he be ideally positioned to prevent asphyxiation of the non-bleeding lung?

choices.text: Lateral decubitus with left side up
Lateral decubitus with left side down

questions.solution:
This patient with massive hemoptysis should be ideally positioned in lateral decubitus with the left side (affected side) down to prevent asphyxiation of the non-bleeding lung.

A blood loss of 400mL over 24 hours or expectorating 100-150mL of blood at a time is considered life-threatening and called massive hemoptysis. Bronchogenic carcinoma of any histology is one of the common causes of massive and nonmassive hemoptysis. Squamous cell carcinomas can erode into major pulmonary vessels and cause massive hemoptysis. 

During massive or life-threatening hemoptysis, the goals of management include,

  • Protect non-bleeding lung and respiratory stabilization
  • Locate the site of bleeding
  • Control bleeding
  • Treat the underlying cause and prevent a recurrence

If the side of bleeding is known, the patient should be positioned with the bleeding side down so that gravitational force keeps blood from the nonbleeding lung. For example, in this patient who has a left-sided lung carcinoma (so presumably the bleeding would be on the left side), during hemoptysis, the patient should be kept in a lateral decubitus position with the left side down to prevent bleeding onto the right lung.

Chest X-ray is the first investigation done. Locating the bleeding can be done with CT angiography that localizes the site of active extravasation followed by rigid or flexible bronchoscopy.

Since most cases of massive hemoptysis occur from bronchial circulation, bronchial artery embolization is the procedure of choice for control of bleeding. Surgical resection of the involved airway and blood vessel can also be done but carries a high risk of mortality.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought with complaints of generalized edema. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria. The serum albumin level is 2.4 g/dL. He responded within 2 weeks of treatment with prednisone. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children
All children require renal biospy for diagnosis
Majority of children achieve complete remission with steroids

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of minimal change in the disease type of nephrotic syndrome. In this condition, all children do not require renal biopsy for diagnosis.  

Minimal change disease is the most common cause (Option A) of nephrotic syndrome in children. It is more common in males and appears between 2 to 6 years of age. It is known as minimal change because, on renal biopsy, the glomerulus appears normal under light microscopy and shows no deposits in immunofluorescence. However, on electron microscopy, uniform and diffuse effacement of podocyte foot processes can be seen.

Clinically, the child presents with a history of edema that is initially noted around the eyes and gradually progresses into generalised edema. Hypertension and hematuria are uncommon.

Diagnosis can be made by urinalysis, which shows proteinuria ranging from 3+ to 4+ protein on urine dipstick and a spot urine protein/creatinine ratio (PCR) of >2. The urinary protein principally contains albumin; hence, it is known as selective proteinuria (Option B). Serum albumin levels are <2.5 g/dL, and there is an increase in serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels. 

Most children will respond to corticosteroid (prednisone/prednisolone) treatment and will achieve complete remission (Option D) (urine PCR <0.2 or <1+ protein on urine dipstick) within the initial 2-3 weeks of therapy. Failure to achieve remission after 6 weeks of steroids is known as steroid resistance. These patients require further evaluation, and only then is renal biopsy required. The usual cause of steroid resistance is focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).

questions.text: A 35-year-old presents with spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Diet history reveals chronic consumption of Khesari dal before the onset of this paralysis. This condition is caused by which of the following toxic compounds?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with spastic paralysis and dietary history of consumption of Khesari dal is suggestive of lathyrism. This condition is caused by the toxic compound beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA).

Lathyrism is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus. It is a paralyzing disease in humans and animals. In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system and another variant is osteolathyrism causing skeletal deformities. A proper dietary history will reveal chronic consumption of this pulse in large quantities. Neurolathyrism is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. 

The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing it from the pulses, by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. This method is called the steeping method. Parboiling can be done in large-scale operations. Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

Note- Aflatoxin is a metabolite produced by Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus. Aflatoxin toxicity presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, convulsions, and signs of acute liver injury. Long-term exposure can result in growth retardation, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: While using the base exchange process to reduce the hardness level of the large water supply in a locality, purified water with zero hardness levels was produced. Which of the following should be done next?

choices.text: Water should be mixed with a part of raw water
Water must be passed under UV light for 12 hours
Water must be passed through Ultrafilters

questions.solution:
Following the base exchange process, a part of raw water is mixed with the purified water to have the required hardness. This is because water with zero hardness level is corrosive. The base exchange process using Permutit (a complex compound of sodium, aluminum, and silica) removes both temporary and permanent hardness.

Related Pearl: Hardness of Water

  • Hardness is the soap destroying power of water or the amount of dissolved calcium and magnesium in water.
  • It is most commonly caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium, but their nitrates and chlorides can also cause hardness.
  • Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.
  • 1 mEq/L of an ion that produces hardness is equal to 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) in 1 litre of water.
Classification Level of hardness (mEq/l) Amount of ion producing hardness (mg/l)
Soft water Less than 1 Less than 50
Moderately hard 1 – 3 50 – 150
Hard water 3 – 6 150 – 300
Very hard water Over 6 More than 300
  • Drinking water must be moderately hard
  • Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/L (150 mg/litre)
  • Removal of hardness:
    • Boiling: 
      • This removes temporary hardness by expelling carbon dioxide and precipitating insoluble calcium carbonate. It would be expensive to do this on a large scale.
    • Addition of lime: 
      • This removes temporary hardness and also reduces magnesium. Lime absorbs carbon dioxide and precipitates insoluble calcium carbonate. In Clark’s method of softening water, lime is used.
    • Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash): removes both temporary and permanent hardness.
    • Base exchange process:
      • This removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used on a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica. When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with amnesia. Which of the following will not be impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Name of pet bird growing up

questions.solution:
The ability to drive a bicycle is not impaired in this patient.

The ability to drive a bicycle is a non-declarative memory and this type of memory is preserved in amnesia.

Non-declarative memory includes:

  • Skill learning
  • Habit learning
  • Simple forms of conditioning

Declarative memory supports the conscious recollection of facts and events. For example:

  • Memory for routes, lists, faces, melodies, objects
  • Memory for other verbal and nonverbal material

The memory of the melody of his favorite song, the name of pet bird growing up and route navigation are all types of declarative memory. This is impaired in amnesia.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: All of the following caspases are involved in apoptosis, except _____.
questions.solution:
Caspase 11 is not involved in apoptosis.

Caspases are cysteine proteases that cleave the proteins at the aspartic acid residue. The activation of caspases plays a key role in the process of apoptosis. Caspases involved in apoptosis are :

  • The mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway of apoptosis involves caspase 9.
  • The death receptor or extrinsic pathway of apoptosis involves caspase 8 and caspase 10.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the emergency with an incessant cry, abdominal distension, and passing blood-stained stools.  A donut-shaped mass was visualized in the right hypochondrium on ultrasonography. On performing barium studies, which sign would be consistent with the diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of an infant with incessant crying, abdominal distension, and blood-stained stools with a doughnut sign on ultrasonography is suggestive of intussusception. On performing barium studies, coiled spring appearance is consistent with the diagnosis of this condition. 

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. 

Causes of intussusception are:

  • Idiopathic - most common cause in children
  • Pathological lead points such as enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch, lymphoma, intestinal polyp, leiomyomas, etc.
  • Meckel's diverticulum
  • A recent upper GI or respiratory infection, rotavirus vaccination has also shown some association with intussusception in children.

The characteristic clinical triad includes:

  • Pain
  • Palpable sausage-shaped mass
  • Red currant jelly stools

USG findings in intussusception include:

  • Target sign/ doughnut sign/ bull's eye sign - This is seen in axial view/transverse plane on ultrasonography. The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic (mucosa and muscularis) with hypoechogenic bands (submucosa).
  • Pseudo kidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel:
    • Edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma 
    • Mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Barium contrast shows a coiled spring appearance with barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space. Plain radiograph may show a meniscus sign i.e. soft tissue mass contrasting the bowel that is air-filled. 

Treatment: Reduction of intussusception should be done immediately after the diagnosis. Radiologic hydrostatic reduction has a high success rate in ileocolic intussusception. Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis or perforation, peritonitis, and multiple recurrences.

Other options:

Options A and D: Pseudo kidney sign and target sign are ultrasonographic findings of instussuception. 

The ultrasonography image below shows pseudo kidney sign and target sign:

 

Option B: The corkscrew pattern is pathognomic of midgut volvulus on upper GI studies. It represents the duodenum and jejunum spiralling around the mesenteric vessels.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents to the hospital with complaints of vaginal bleeding and mild abdominal pain. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. Pelvic examination reveals a 10-12 week, non-tender uterus. Urine hCG is positive. A pelvic ultrasonogram is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

LMP-last menstrual period 

hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasonogram showing characteristic snow storm appearance are suggestive of a complete hydatiform mole. Suction curettage will be the appropriate management for this patient.

The snowstorm appearance is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces but without a fetus and amnionic sac. Combined with a raised hCG and a uterus larger than the date of pregnancy, the diagnosis of a complete hydatidiform mole is made.

Management of a complete mole is by suction curettage, which effectively removes the molar tissue from the patient.

Preoperative cervical dilatation with an osmotic agent is recommended if the cervix is minimally dilated. With large moles, adequate anesthesia, sufficient intravenous access, and blood-banking support are important. Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied.

Other options:

Option A: Expectant management is not appropriate in the case of the complete mole as patients may develop complications.

Option B: Methotrexate therapy can be used to treat a persistent or metastatic complete mole.

Option D: Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their families.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with an acute facial weakness of the lower left part following a stroke. On examination, the following finding is noted. There is no limb weakness or any associated sensory loss. Which part of the internal capsule is most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, symptoms like facial weakness in the lower part of the left side of the face and deviation of the tongue to the left side, are suggestive of a lesion in the corticobulbar fibers of facial nerve nuclei and hypoglossal nerve nuclei that pass through the genu of the internal capsule.

All cranial motor nuclei receive bilateral corticonuclear connections, except the facial nucleus supplying the lower part of the face, and the hypoglossal nucleus supplying the genioglossus muscle. Hence a lesion of these fibers causes contralateral clinical manifestations.

The internal capsule is a white matter structure situated in the inferomedial part of each cerebral hemisphere. It is a type of projection fibers that are composed of ascending and descending nerve fibers connecting the cerebrum to the brainstem and spinal cord. Parts of the internal capsule include the anterior limb, genu, posterior limb, retrolentiform, and sublentiform part. Tracts that course through the genu include superior thalamic radiation fibers and corticobulbar tract fibers.

The internal capsule is prone to cerebrovascular accidents due to the small diameter of the supplying perforating arteries. This may present as ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke and is most often associated with high blood pressure. As the genu contains corticobulbar tract fibers, lesions at this site are likely to cause face and tongue weakness.

Other options

Option A: Retrolentiform part of the internal capsule carries fibers mainly from optic radiation. A lesion here produces homonymous hemianopia, superior quadrantanopia, or inferior quadrantanopia.

Option B: Anterior limb of the internal capsule carries fronto-pontine fibers. A lesion here produces psychiatric symptoms.

Option C: Posterior limb of the internal capsule carries cortico-spinal motor fibers in the anterior part and the lesion here produces contralateral hemiparesis. The posterior part of the posterior limb of the internal capsule carries sensory fibers and lesions here may produce contralateral hemisensory deficits.

questions.text: In which of the following structures do the sperms exhibit tail movements that lead to a forward-progression type of motility?
questions.solution:
The part marked C that is the tail of the epididymis which is responsible for the rapid forward progression of the sperms. 

The motility of sperm plays an important role in the process of fertilization. Sperms acquire their motility and mature in the epididymis.

The head of the epididymis has sperms with high amplitude and low-frequency tail movements. This type of tail motility causes subtle motion of the sperms.

The tail of the epididymis has sperms that exhibit low amplitude and high-frequency tail movements. Sperms with this type of tail motility result in a rapid forward progression and aid in fertilization.

The epididymis has three parts: 

  1. Head- receives the immature spermatozoa from the superior pole of the testis through the efferent ducts.
  2. Body- efferent ducts from the head open into the tubules of the epididymis. These tubules coalesce forming a single, highly coiled tubule. The wall of the body contains smooth muscles which propel the sperms towards the tail during ejaculation.
  3. Tail- the coiled tubule passes through the tail and continues as the vas deferens.

 

The cystic degeneration of epididymis can result in epididymal cysts.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of a hypernasal voice. In which of the following conditions will this not be expected?
questions.solution:
A hypernasal voice is known as rhinolalia aperta, and it will not be expected in adenoids. 

Adenoids cause blockage of the nose or nasal cavity, leading to a change in a voice called rhinolalia clausa. 

Rhinolalia aperta is also known as hypernasality of voice. This is caused due to failure of the nasopharynx to cut off from the oropharynx or abnormal communication between the oral and nasal cavities. It is seen when certain words that have little nasal resonance are resonated through the nose. 

Causes of rhinolalia aperta include velopharyngeal insufficiency, congenitally short soft palate, large nasopharynx, cleft or paralysis of the soft palate, post-adenoidectomy, and oro-nasal fistula.

Rhinolalia clausa/closed rhinolalia is characterized by hyponasality of voice. This implies reduced or absence of normal resonance of nasal consonants 'm', 'n', 'ng' etc. This finding is due to the obstruction in the nasal cavity or nasopharynx. 

Causes of rhinolalia clausa include common cold, nasal allergy, nasal polypi, adenoids, and nasopharyngeal mass.

questions.text:
A middle-aged male patient comes with complaints of generalized weakness and palpitations. ECG showed ST depression and QT prolongation. He was diagnosed to have hypokalaemia and started on potassium supplementation. However, the patient's symptoms persisted. What is the most likely cause of treatment failure?

ECG - Electrocardiography
questions.solution:
In a patient with hypokalemia, the most likely cause of treatment failure is hypomagnesemia. 

Hypomagnesemia leads to reduced cellular uptake as well as increased renal secretion of potassium by the distal nephron, causing treatment refractoriness.

Hypokalemia occurs when the plasma concentration of potassium is less than 3.5 mM. It can occur due to:

  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Beta-2 agonistic drugs
  • Insulin
  • Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis
  • Total parenteral nutrition
  • Hypothermia
  • Magnesium deficiency
  • Diuretics (except potassium-sparing agents)
  • Mineralocorticoid excess
  • Renal tubular syndromes (Gitelmen's, Bartter's, and Liddle's syndrome)

Hypokalemia causes life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias. ECG shows broad flat T waves, ST depression, and QT prolongation that is most marked when serum K+ <2.7 mmol/L (shown below). 

It also causes weakness and paralysis. Paralysis of intestinal smooth muscles can cause intestinal ileus. Sodium chloride and bicarbonate retention lead to metabolic alkalosis. Other functional effects include polyuria, phosphaturia, and hypocitraturia.

Oral potassium supplementation is the mainstay of treatment (IV supplementation is reserved for severe complications such as paralysis and arrhythmias). Hypomagnesemia should also be looked for and treated. 

Other options:

Option B- The clinical features of hyponatremia are predominantly neurological as a result of the development of cerebral edema. Patients usually present with nausea, headache, vomiting, seizure, brainstem herniation, and coma.

Option C- The most notable clinical features of hypermagnesemia are vasodilation and neuromuscular blockade. Early signs include hypotension refractory to vasopressors and volume expansion.

Option D-  The clinical features of hypernatremia are neurological. The most frequent manifestation is altered mental status that ranges from confusion and lethargy to deep coma.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presents with pinpoint ecchymoses around the hair follicles and multiple episodes of epistaxis. On examination, he has nodules as seen in the image given below, which are tender on palpation. All of the following radiological signs could be seen in this patient, except ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of perifollicular hemorrhages and the image showing scorbutic rosary are suggestive of scurvy. The radiological sign cupping and fraying is not seen in this patient. It is seen in rickets. 

Radiological signs in scurvy include:

  • White line of Frankel: Calcified cartilage at metaphyses
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelkan spur: Lateral prolongation of the white line, which is present at the cortical ends
  • Wimberger ring sign: Circular, opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline. Hence, deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in generalized bleeding tendencies.

Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include:

  • Petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points
  • Epistaxis
  • Gum bleeding
  • Perifollicular hemorrhages

Other manifestations are: 

  • Poor wound and fracture healing
  • Hyperkeratosis of hair follicles
  • Arthralgia and muscle weakness
  • Defective osteoid formation
  • Costo-chondral separation leading to the formation of sharply angulated tender nodules or scorbutic rosary

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A patient who presented with significant weight loss was started on parenteral nutrition, following which, he developed refeeding syndrome. What is the maximum nutritional support that should be started to prevent this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario of refeeding syndrome, maximum nutritional support of 10 kcal/kg per day is recommended to prevent this condition from occurring.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially lethal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients.

The patient is considered to be at risk of developing refeeding syndrome with either one or more of the following: 

  • BMI <16 kg/m2
  • Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3–6 months 
  • Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days 
  • Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding 

With excessive refeeding, there is an increased release of insulin due to the metabolic shift from fat to carbohydrate substrate. As a result, there is an increase in the cellular uptake of electrolytes including phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium. Hence metabolic abnormalities are seen which include hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, and hypocalcemia.

These electrolyte disorders thereby result in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, respiratory dysfunction, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Nutritional support should be started at a maximum of 10 kcal/kg per day, with the goal of gradually increasing levels to meet full needs within 4-7 days. Treatment includes the correction of underlying electrolyte abnormalities and nutritional support with supplementary thiamine, vitamin B, multivitamins and trace elements.

questions.text: A young patient presented with symptoms of bronchial asthma and cromolyn sodium was prescribed. It should be administered by which of the following routes?
questions.solution:
Cromolyn sodium (Sodium cromoglycate) is administered through the inhalation route as an aerosol, through a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) in bronchial asthma.

Sodium cromoglycate is a mast cell stabilizer, which inhibits the degranulation of mast cells and restricts the release of inflammatory cytokines. It prevents bronchoconstriction but does not act as a direct bronchodilator and hence cannot be used once bronchoconstriction is established or during an asthmatic attack. 

It is not absorbed orally. It is administered through the inhalation route for the treatment of bronchial asthma. It can also be used in the treatment of allergic conjunctivitis as a topical application.

The therapeutic benefit develops slowly over 2-4 weeks and lasts 1- 2 weeks after discontinuation of the drug. Its use has declined due to the widespread usage of inhaled corticosteroids.

questions.text: The given instrument is designed to measure ______.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a dry and wet hygrometer and is designed to measure humidity. 

It consists of 2 similar thermometers beside each other. The dry bulb thermometer measures the dry bulb air temperature, and the wet bulb thermometer is kept moist with a wet muslin cloth covered over it. When both the temperature readings are equal, it signifies there is 100% saturation of the atmosphere with moisture. After obtaining both the readings, the relative humidity is calculated using psychrometric charts.

Other options:

Option A - Air velocity is calculated using anemometers. It consists of 4 hemispherical cups, attached to 2 crossed metal arms. The velocity of the wind is indicated on a counter called a cyclometer, placed on the anemometer. Kata thermometers are used as anemometers for low air velocities. 

Option C - Air pressure/Atmospheric pressure is measured using barometers.

Option D -  Air Quality Index (AQI) is complex air quality data of various pollutants that are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature, and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location. 

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A ten-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of his hands after playing football. He has a history of similar episodes of dactylitis in the past and also frequently complains of fatigue. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following drugs is used in reducing the frequency of these episodes?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with multiple episodes of dactylitis along with the shrunken spleen on imaging is suggestive of sickle cell disease. Hydroxyurea is used in reducing the frequency of these episodes. 

Hydroxyurea is a myelosuppressive agent and is safe and well-tolerated in children >5 years of age. It has also been used safely in infants. It is effective in reducing the frequency of painful episodes, decreasing the rate of hospitalization, and the requirement for blood transfusion. 

Manifestations of sickle cell anemia include:

  • Splenic manifestations - 
    • Loss of splenic function and shrinkage due to repeated splenic micro-infarcts 
    • Acute splenic sequestration due to venous obstruction, necessitating emergency transfusion/splenectomy
  • Hand-foot syndrome with painful infarction of the digits and dactylitis due to vaso-occlusion
  • Acute chest syndrome having radiodensity on chest radiograph along with fever, respiratory distress, hypoxia, cough, and chest pain
  • Isostenuria due to renal papillary necrosis 
  • Cerebrovascular strokes
  • Chronic lower leg ulcers
  • Priapism in males

Other options:

Option A: Hydrocodone is an opioid analgesic is used in the treatment of pain crises in sickle cell anemia.

Option B: Corticosteroids are one of the first-line therapies for acute idiopathic thrombocytic purpura (ITP) with risk factors for bleeding.

Option C: Ruxolitinib is a JAK2 inhibitor used in the treatment of polycythemia vera.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male patient successfully underwent elective CABG 3 days before. He is now acutely confused with a temperature of 102°F, SpO2 of 92%, and has also developed purulent sputum. CBC shows leukocytosis. Chest X-ray shows a new right-sided infiltrate. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

CABG - Coronary artery bypass-graft

SpO2- Oxygen saturation

CBC - Complete blood count

CTPA -  CT pulmonary angiogram

choices.text: Perform lung biopsy and start antibiotics after culture results
Start treatment as per hospital's local antibiogram for nosocomial pneumonia
Perform CTPA to rule out pulmonary embolism
Administer antipyretics and observe the patient

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of nosocomial pneumonia and the next best step in managing this patient is to start antibiotics as per the hospital's local antibiogram for nosocomial pneumonia.

Pneumonia is a lung parenchymal infection that can be community-acquired or nosocomial. Nosocomial pneumonia can be hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Treatment should be started as soon as possible due to the high mortality rate. Empirical antibiotics are first given and narrowed to specific antibiotics after the finalized culture reports. The initial empirical treatment is based on each hospital's local antibiogram (profile of antimicrobial susceptibility). This is done to guide the optimal choice of antibiotics and reduce the risk of creating antibiotic resistance and exposing the sick patient to unnecessary drugs. 

HAP occurs > 48 hours after admission to the hospital. The diagnosis should be made after excluding the possibility of any infections present at the time of admission. VAP is diagnosed when clinical features and positive respiratory samples consistent with pneumonia develop >48 hours after endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation.

Clinical diagnosis is made by clinical and radiological findings:

  • 2 or more clinical findings of:
    • fever
    • purulent sputum
    • worsening respiratory status
    • leukocytosis
  • 1 or more new/progressive lung opacities on chest imaging

The most common organisms responsible for HAP are Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Klebsiella pneumoniae. VAP is also associated with Acinetobacter species. VAP can be prevented by reducing the duration of intubation and preferring non-invasive ventilation methods.

questions.text:
Which of the given clinical findings are consistent with a diagnosis of class III hemorrhagic shock?

PR- Pulse rate; BP- Blood pressure
questions.solution:
A pulse rate of 126 bpm and decreased blood pressure of 80/50 mmHg fall under class III hemorrhagic shock.

Patients with hemorrhagic shock are classified based on their clinical signs and symptoms. According to this classification- a person with a pulse rate i.e PR >120 and decreased BP (blood pressure) falls under class III. Other features include an anxious or confused state, decreased pulse pressure, a respiratory rate (RR) between 30-40/min, and a urine output of 5-15 mL/hr. These patients can be replaced with crystalloids and blood. The blood loss is 30-40% in these patients.

Other options:

Option A: This comes under class I as the pulse rate is below 100 bpm and blood pressure is normal. Features include slight anxiety, normal pulse pressure, RR 14-20/min, and urine output >30 mL/hr. Crystalloids are useful.

Option C: This comes under class IV as the pulse rate is above 140 bpm and blood pressure is decreased. Confusion/ lethargy, decreased pulse pressure, RR >35/min, and negligible urine are seen. Crystalloids and blood transfusion are useful for these patients. 

Option D: This comes under class II as the pulse rate is between 100-120 bpm and blood pressure is normal. The patients falling under this class are mildly anxious with decreased pulse pressure, RR 20-30/min, and urine output of 20-30 mL/hr. Crystalloids are given to these patients.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presents with a 5x4x3cm lump in the right breast. It is hard in consistency and is fixed to the skin. On examination, there are fixed and matted axillary lymph nodes in the left and right axilla. Mammography reveals the presence of microcalcifications with irregular spiculated margins. A tru-cut biopsy is performed which shows ductal carcinoma. What is the staging of the tumor as per the recent AJCC classification?
questions.solution:
A contralateral lymph node involvement is considered metastasis. The presence of metastasis classifies the tumor under stage IV.

The TNM status in the above scenario is:

  • Tumor: Skin involvement over the breast- peau d'orange appearance classifies this as stage T4b.
  • Nodes: Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes come under N2A.
  • Metastasis: Contralateral lymph node involvement (Here, mass is on the right breast and axillary lymph nodes on the left side are involved) is considered as M1.

Some important considerations while staging a breast tumor:

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is considered. For example, if a mass is 6*2cm in size, 6cm is taken into account and it comes under T3 (>5cm).
  • Any skin involvement other than those mentioned under T4b and T4d is not considered for staging. Thus, skin changes like dimpling of skin or nipple retraction are not considered for staging.
  • Supraclavicular lymph node involvement indicates N3c.
  • Metastasis to any contralateral lymph node or metastasis to any lymph node other than those mentioned in N staging is considered distant metastasis (M1). Thus, the involvement of the cervical lymph node (ipsilateral or contralateral) would be considered a distant metastasis.
  • If two masses are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger mass.

questions.text: A primigravid woman in her 36th week of gestation presented with progressive jaundice, abdominal pain, and vomiting. Investigations revealed abnormal liver function tests pointing towards a diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
A deficiency of fetal long-chain 3-hydroxy acyl CoA dehydrogenase (LCHAD) is involved in the pathogenesis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

Acute fatty liver is a common cause of acute liver failure in pregnancy. It usually occurs in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly in the third trimester. It occurs either due to poor placental mitochondrial function or due to a fetal deficiency of long-chain acyl coenzyme A dehydrogenase (LCHAD).

The patients present with persistent nausea and vomiting, progressive jaundice, and epigastric pain. Features like hypoglycemia, hypertension, proteinuria, and edema can also be present. Symptoms may progress to fulminant hepatic failure with encephalopathy, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.

Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. There is hemolysis, with decreased platelets and fibrinogen. Elevated d-dimer is seen. Microscopy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.

The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. Trial of labor by induction or delivery by Cesarean is done. Intensive supportive measures including blood transfusion should be provided.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 35 weeks of gestation with Rh-negative pregnancy undergoes the following analysis. The amniotic fluid bilirubin levels plotted fall in zone 3. Which of the following indicates the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Pregnancy can be continued till term

questions.solution:
The graph shown in the above image is Liley's chart. As the amniotic fluid bilirubin levels fall in zone 3, it indicates that the fetus is severely affected and requires immediate delivery.

Liley's chart helps in the estimation of hemolysis severity and indirect assessment of anemia. Amnionic fluid bilirubin is measured by a spectrophotometer and is demonstrable as a change in optical density absorbance at 450 nm—ΔOD450.

The chart is divided into 3 zones: 

Liley’s zone I (low zone): Rh-negative fetus or fetus is unlikely to be affected and the pregnancy can be continued till term.

Liley’s zone II (mid zone): Indicates fetal anemia.

  • Repeat amniocentesis after 2 weeks → value upward→ cordocentesis→ hematocrit <30%→ intrauterine transfusion to raise hematocrit 40–45%.
  • Preterm delivery may be needed after 34 weeks.

Liley’s zone III (high zone): Indicates severely affected fetus and death is imminent.

  • If Pregnancy >34 weeks → delivery.
  • If Pregnancy <34 weeks → cordocentesis → hematocrit < 30% → intrauterine transfusion to raise hematocrit 40–45%.
  • Preterm delivery may be needed after 34 weeks

questions.text: A test for reducing sugars is being performed on several urine samples. The reagent used for this test consists of all of the following, except ________.
questions.solution:
The test being performed is Benedict's test and Benedict's reagent contains all the above contents, except sodium hydroxide.

Benedict’s test is used to detect reducing sugars. It tests positive for all monosaccharides and most disaccharides except sucrose.

Composition of Benedict’s reagent:

  • Copper sulfate- provides the source of cupric (Cu2+) ions
  • Sodium citrate- complexes with cupric (Cu2+) ions to prevent its deterioration to cuprous ions spontaneously
  • Sodium carbonate- provides an alkaline pH

Principle: All monosaccharides and reducing disaccharides contain a free functional aldehyde or ketone group. When heated in the presence of an alkali, they are converted to enediols, which reduce the cupric compounds (Cu2+) present in Benedict's reagent to an insoluble precipitate of red cuprous oxide (Cu2O).

Substances giving a positive reaction on Benedict’s test:

  • All monosaccharides such as glucose, galactose, fructose, pentoses
  • Reducing disaccharides such as lactose and maltose
  • Glucuronic acid, homogentisic acid, and ascorbic acid

The color of the precipitate gives a rough idea of the amount of sugar present in urine:

Color of the precipitate Amount of reducing sugar
Green 0.5%
Yellow 1%
Orange 1.5%
Red 2%

Hence, it is a semi-quantitative test.

questions.text: A chronic substance user was brought with complaints of depression, hypersomnia, and craving. History revealed that he had not been consuming the said substance for the past few days. What is the likely substance that was being consumed in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of cocaine withdrawal symptoms.

Cocaine withdrawal is a triphasic syndrome that presents after the sudden stoppage of chronic cocaine use. The phases are as follows - 

  1. Crash phase (9 hours-4 days): Anorexia, depression, excessive craving, hypersomnia, fatigue.
  2. Normal mood, anxiety, and anhedonia (4-7 days)
  3. Extinction phase (7-10 days): Absence of withdrawal symptoms but increased susceptibility to relapse.

Treatment for withdrawal includes bromocriptine and amantadine. They are useful in reducing cocaine cravings.

Other options:

Option A: Shakes, hallucinations, and agitation are symptoms of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. They occur 12-24 hours following alcohol intake. Other features include nausea, vomiting, malaise, anxiety, depression, and headache. 

Delirium tremens begin 72 to 96 hours after the last drink. It is due to the long-continued action of the poison on the brain. It occurs in chronic alcoholics due to temporary excess, sudden withdrawal of alcohol, shock after receiving an injury, such as fracture of a bone, or from acute infection, such as pneumonia, influenza, erysipelas, etc.

Option C: Profuse sweating, diarrhea, and piloerection (gooseflesh) are symptoms of opioid withdrawal. They are associated with nausea, vomiting, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, muscle cramps, and generalized body aches. These symptoms manifest about 12-24 hours after the stoppage and recede within 7-10 days of last use.

Option D: Synesthesia or seeing smells and hearing colors and flashback phenomenon (emotional and psychological experiences of the previous LSD) are features of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) intoxication. Other features include dry mouth, dilated pupils, tachycardia, hypertension, mood changes, visual hallucinations, alterations in time perceptions, vision, and hearing. Side effects are psychosis, depression, panic attacks, and schizophrenic episodes.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presented with painful lesions on one side of his chest. What is the causative organism of the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a painful rash following dermatomal distribution is suggestive of shingles or herpes zoster, caused by the varicella-zoster virus.

It is characterized by a unilateral vesicular dermatomal eruption associated with severe pain. It is more common in old age typically after 50 years of age.

The pathogenesis is mainly due to the reactivation of the latent varicella zoster virus. 

Clinical features include unilateral rash and confined to the area supplied by a single sensory ganglion. The most common sites involved are D3 to L2 dermatomes. It can also involve the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve. Pain and paresthesia can be seen for weeks or months. Other features such as lower motor neuron paralysis and, meningoencephalitis can occur rarely.

Ramsay Hunt syndrome refers to the involvement of the facial nerve. It is characterized by eruptions on the tympanic membrane, external auditory meatus, and ipsilateral facial palsy.

Diagnosis of shingles is mainly a clinical diagnosis.

Other options:

Option B: Herpes simplex virus can cause various manifestations. It includes cutaneous lesions on the cheeks, around the mouth/forehead, buttocks, eczema herpeticum, gingivostomatitis, pharyngitis, corneal blindness, encephalitis, and urethritis. Lesions do not follow a dermatomal distribution.

Option C: Cytomegalovirus can cause congenital infection which is characterized by generalized infection, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, thrombocytopenic purpura, and hemolytic anemia.  In infants, it can cause an inclusion disease when born to mothers infected during pregnancy. It can occur as post-transfusion mononucleosis in children following the transfusion of infected blood. 

Option D: Ebstein Barr virus can cause infectious mononucleosis. It is characterized by fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and peripheral smear showing abnormal mononuclear cells. A rash may develop in some patients who are treated with ampicillin.

questions.text: A child presents with painful swelling of the parotid glands as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Salivary gland involvement is limited to the parotids
The patient is not infectious prior to clinical parotid enlargement
Mumps orchitis frequently leads to infertility

questions.solution:
In the given scenario the image of a child presenting with painful swelling of the parotid glands suggests the diagnosis of mumps. Meningoencephalitis can precede parotitis is true regarding mumps. 

Meningoencephalitis classically manifests 5 days after parotitis, however, it can occur before, or along with parotitis.

Other options:

Option A: Mumps virus may involve salivary glands (parotid, submandibular), CNS, pancreas, and testes.

Option B: The virus appears in saliva 7 days before to 7 days after the appearance of parotid swelling. The maximum period of infectivity is 1-2 days before 5 days after the onset of parotid swelling.  

Option D: Mumps orchitis may lead to atrophy of the testes but sterility is rare even with bilateral involvement.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man living in the UK is planning to travel to India. His doctor advises him to take the typhoral vaccine. Which of the following days are included in the schedule?
questions.solution:
Days 1, 3, and 5 are included in the schedule of typhoral vaccine, if day 1 is the first dose of the vaccine. In other words, it should be given on alternate days.

Typhoral vaccine is a live oral typhoid vaccine containing a mutated Salmonella typhi Ty21a. This strain lacks the enzyme UDP- galactose- 4 epimerases. It initiates an infection after ingestion, but the strain is self-destructible. Hence does not cause a serious illness.  

The schedule is 3 doses on alternate days, i.e., on the 1st, 3rd, and 5th day. The capsules are enteric coated and taken an hour before food. No antibiotic should be taken during the schedule.

questions.text: A police officer has brought the following bullets to you for forensic examination as they were recovered while investigating a crime scene. What is the type of bullet shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The bullet shown in the given image possesses crossed grooves at its tips, which indicates that it is a dum-dum bullet.

Dum-dum bullets are not entirely covered by a jacket; an area near the nose is left uncovered to expose the core. These bullets are designed to expand upon hitting a target. This expansion increases the bullet's diameter, causing a larger wound channel.

Other options:

Option A: A souvenir bullet is one that has been lodged in the body for a long time, with no fresh bleeding around it, and is surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. 

Option B: Tracer bullets (shown in the image below) leave a visible trace while in flight, which allows the gunner to observe its trajectory. 

Option D: Tandem bullet phenomenon occurs when two bullets are expelled with a single shot; it is seen in the case of firearms that have remained unused or exposed to high temperature and humidity. 

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

From left to right : Blank with frangible wooden bullet, ball, tracer and incendiary bullets

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee and ankle joints for the past week. He has a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago. On examination, he has conjunctivitis and the following skin lesions are seen. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with acute arthritis and conjunctivitis following a recent infection and the given image showing keratoderma blennorrhagica point to the diagnosis of reactive arthritis or Reiter's syndrome. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) is non-purulent arthritis following enteric or urogenital infection. It occurs most commonly in the age group 18-40 years and is associated with HLA-B27. Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, and Chlamydia trachomatis.

It is characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. Patients develop arthritis which is asymmetric and additive, involving large weight-bearing joints like the knee and ankle.

Extraarticular manifestations of reactive arthritis include:

  • Keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles.
  • Oral ulcers: superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic.
  • Circinate balanitis refers to vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis.

Other options:

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis is commonly seen in young adults. It has a strong association with the HLA-B27 genetic marker. Patients will present with lower lumbar back pain which is insidious in onset. It is accompanied by low-back morning stiffness that improves with activity.

 

 

X-ray showing the characteristic bamboo-spine appearance in ankylosing spondylitis:

 

Option B: Psoriatic arthritis is an asymmetrical oligoarthritis. It is associated with nail pitting, onycholysis, dactylitis, and enthesitis. There is pronounced telescoping of the digits. Axial involvement may also occur.

Radiological features include:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity at the distal interphalangeal joint, as shown in the image below.
  • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation known as whiskering.

 

Option C: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis usually presents with swelling and pain in the small joints of the hands. Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are commonly involved.

Related Pearl: Uveitis Associated with HLA B-27-associated Arthritis

  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Reiter’s syndrome
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) (previously known as juvenile rheumatoid arthritis)

questions.text: A primigravida came with complaints of lower abdominal pain radiating to the groin at 35 weeks of gestation. However, on examination, there was no dilatation of the cervix. Which of the following features if present would make false labor pain the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
False labor pain is relieved by enema or sedatives. 

False labor pain (also known as spurious labor pain or Braxton Hicks contractions) is seen more in primigravidae than in parous women. It usually appears prior to the onset of true labor pain by 1 or 2 weeks in primigravidae and by a few days in multiparae. It is due to cervical and lower uterine stretching with simultaneous irritation of the neighboring ganglia.

The following table gives the comparison between true and false labor pains:

Property True labor pain False labor pain
Character Painful Dull
Location Front of the abdomen and radiates towards the thighs Lower abdomen and groin
Uterine consistency Progressive hardening No hardening
Intervals Occurs at regular intervals Absent
Contractions Progressive increase in frequency, duration, and intensity Absent
Show Present Absent
Bag of waters Formed Absent
Progressive effacement and dilatation Present Absent
Descent of Presenting part Present  Absent
Relief by enema or sedatives Absent Present

 

With the onset of labor, cervical mucous plug along with blood is expelled which is known as show.

The membranes get detached easily due to the stretch of the lower uterine segment and the lower pole of fetal membranes containing the liquor amnii become unsupported and bulge into the cervical canal in response to the cervical dilatation. This is called a bag of waters.

During uterine contraction, the bag becomes tense and convex in response to the rise in intra-amniotic pressure and after the contractions pass, the bulging disappears completely. This is almost a certain sign of the onset of labor.

questions.text: A 60 year-old-woman comes with complaints of sudden onset blindness of the right eye, with throbbing headache in the right temporal region associated with jaw claudication. On examination, a thickened tender cord-like structure can be felt in the temple. Temporal artery biopsy shows the following. Which among the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Lesions are distributed throughout the entire length of the artery
Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation
T cell infiltrates are predominantly CD8+
Fragmentation is seen in external elastic lamina

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histology image is suggestive of giant cell/temporal arteritis. Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation.

Giant cell/temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the arteries of the head. It is seen in people over 50 years of age.

It can affect the following arteries:

  • Superficial temporal artery: Intense facial pain or headache along the course of the artery
  • Ophthalmic arteries: Sudden and permanent diplopia or blindness
  • Aorta: Giant-cell aortitis
  • Vertebral arteries

A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis. However, a negative biopsy cannot exclude the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis because the lesions are focally distributed, leaving long segments of the artery normal. Hence, the biopsy sample may be taken from the normal part of the artery, leading to a false-negative report. For the same reason, an adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.

Biopsy findings of giant cell arteritis include:

  • Classic lesions are primarily medial granulomatous inflammation.
  • These lesions involve the internal elastic lamina, leading to elastic lamina fragmentation.
  • There is intimal thickening that reduces the luminal diameter.
  • There is an infiltrate with T cells (CD4+ > CD8+), macrophages, and multinucleated giant cells (75% of specimens).

The image below shows giant cell arteritis with intimal thickening and internal elastic lamina fragmentation:

 

Corticosteroids and anti-TNF therapies are used for treatment.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of frequent episodes of gingival bleeding along with numerous petechiae on the leg. The platelet count is 50,000/microliter and the peripheral smear shows large platelets with normal morphology. Other laboratory investigations are normal. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is an autoimmune mediated condition
Antibodies are directed against platelet factor 4
There are increased number of megakaryocytes in bone marrow
The treatment is by administering I.V. immunoglobin

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). The false statement is that the antibodies are directed against platelet factor 4. Antibodies against platelet factor 4 are seen in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

ITP is an autoimmune disorder caused by antiplatelet antibodies that destroy platelets. The antibodies are directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. It can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary, associated with SLE, Hepatitis C, and HIV.

Acute ITP is usually seen in children, while chronic ITP occurs commonly in adults. Clinically, the patient may present with a history of easy bruising, gingival bleeding, petechiae, and ecchymoses. 

Investigations show isolated thrombocytopenia. Peripheral smear may show large platelets with normal morphology and bone marrow shows an increase in megakaryocytes (non-specific findings of thrombopoiesis). 

Initial treatment includes administering steroids and IVIg (intravenous immunoglobulin). TPO (thrombopoietin) receptor agonists, romiplostim and eltrombopag, are effective in increasing platelet counts in patients not responding to traditional treatment. Spleen is a major site for the removal of opsonized (targeted) platelets, and so, splenectomy remains a treatment option in severe thrombocytopenia and refractory cases.

Note- Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is an autoimmune condition, seen after the administration of heparin. It is more common with unfractionated heparin compared to low molecular weight heparins. This condition is not associated with bleeding. On the contrary, it is associated with thrombosis.

Related Pearl: Idiopathic/Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

It is characterized by

  • Isolated thrombocytopenia—the presence of antibody against platelet membrane glycoprotein and subsequent destruction in reticuloendothelial system
  • Normal bone marrow—normal or even increased number of megakaryocytes
  • Absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia.

III. Sequestration - The spleen normally sequesters 30% to 35% of platelets. This can rise to 80% to 90% when the spleen is enlarged, producing moderate degrees of thrombocytopenia.

IV. Dilution - Transfusions

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to the emergency room with difficulty breathing and chest pain. On examination, tachycardia, edema of the lower limbs, and elevated jugular venous pressure were noted. He was given an intravenous infusion of a natriuretic peptide that acts on membrane-bound guanylyl cyclase. Identify the drug administered.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of heart failure and the drug administered is nesiritide.  

Nesiritide is a recombinant natriuretic peptide acting on membrane-bound guanylyl cyclase. It is used in the management of heart failure. 

Natriuretic peptides: 

  • Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP): released from atrial storage granules in response to increase in intravascular volume. It reduces blood pressure.  
  • Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP): released from ventricular tissue in response to volume overload. It reduces blood pressure and is also known to reduce cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis.  
  • C- type natriuretic peptide (CNP): synthesized in the brain and endothelial tissues and stimulates the growth of long bones. 

The other drugs mentioned are also used in the management of heart failure. Furosemide is a loop diuretic that acts on the thick ascending loop of Henle, inhibiting the Na+K+Cl- channel. Sodium nitroprusside and nitroglycerine are vasodilators that act by releasing nitric oxide (NO). NO acts on soluble guanylyl cyclase leading to vasodilation.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is used in polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and is heat stable and obtained from bacteria?
questions.solution:
Taq polymerase is used in PCR. It is heat stable and is obtained from the bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus. It lacks a proofreading activity.

DNA synthesis in PCR is catalyzed by a heat-stable DNA polymerase. It is purified from thermophilic bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus, organisms that grow at 70 to 80°C. Thermostable DNA polymerases withstand short incubations at over 90°, temperatures required to completely denature DNA.

The technique of PCR:

Denaturation- sample DNA strands are separated by heating at 95℃ for 15 seconds to 2 minutes.

Annealing- the primers, added in vast excess, are allowed to anneal to the DNA (typically 50–75°C). The primers hybridize with their complementary single-stranded DNA.

Extension- each strand is copied by a Taq polymerase, starting at the primer sites in the presence of all four nucleotides (dNTPs) at 72℃.

The image given below shows the steps involved in PCR.


The image given below shows the resources required for PCR:


Other options:

Option A: DNA polymerase III is involved in the replication. This enzyme binds to template DNA to synthesize DNA in the 5' to 3' direction at the replication fork.

Option B: Endonuclease is involved in the replication. The mismatched base during replication is identified and removed by the endonuclease activity.

Option D: DNA gyrase is involved in the replication. It unwinds the DNA and relieves supercoils during replication. They act on the closed circular DNA of bacteria.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. On examination, high-pitched bowel sounds were heard. An  X-ray erect abdomen is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an X-ray showing gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and multiple air-fluid levels indicating small bowel obstruction is suggestive of gallstone ileus.

Gallstone ileus is a condition caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a mechanical blockage. Big gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to biliary-enteric fistula formation. The condition is characterized by a triad of features known as Rigler’s triad. It comprises small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and atypical mineral shadow on the abdominal radiographs (ectopic gall stone).

Penumobilia refers to the presence of air within the biliary tree which suggest that there is an abnormal communication between the intestine and the biliary tract. Other conditions associated with pneumobilia include incompetent sphincter of Oddi and biliary-enteric anastomosis.

CT scan is helpful in the diagnosis.

Gall stone ileus is managed by

  • Milking the stone proximally away from the site of impaction
  • Crushing the stone
  • Removal of the stone.\

The surgical procedures that can be performed are: simple enterolithotomy, enterolithotomy, cholecystectomy, and fistula closure (one-stage procedure) and enterolithotomy with cholecystectomy performed later (two-stage procedure).

Given below is a plain X-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia).

Option A: Cecal volvulus presents with features of obstruction. Ischaemia can be seen and the midline or a left-sided swelling can be present. On radiograph, it will show a dilated and air-filled cecum. Other clinical features such as dilated small bowel and absence of gas in the distal colon are seen. 

Option B: In large bowel obstruction, the presence of haustrations is a feature. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

Option C: Crohn's disease on small bowel enema shows narrowing of involved areas and is often irregular. Features include colicky postprandial abdominal pain, diarrhea, and palpable and tender right iliac fossa mass. Other less common features like fever, anemia and weight loss can be seen.

questions.text: A minor surgery was planned for a 60 year-old-man. His preoperative serological tests showed Anti-HBsAg positive. All other serological markers were negative. What is the probable treatment required?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, anti-HBsAg alone is positive, which is seen in immunized individuals. The patient does not require any treatment.

The presence of anti-HBs can imply recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection, as well as successful vaccination against hepatitis B. In a patient who is fully immunized against hepatitis B:

  • HBsAg- negative

Antiviral drugs such as tenofovir and entecavir can be initiated when there is HBsAg positivity with evidence of cirrhosis, abnormal ALT (Alanine transaminase), and HBV DNA titer >20,000 IU/mL.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not used for gluconeogenesis by the body?
questions.solution:
Leucine and lysine are the only purely ketogenic amino acids. These two amino acids yield only acetyl-CoA on oxidation (ketogenesis), and hence, they cannot be used for gluconeogenesis.

Four other amino acids give rise to both acetyl-CoA and intermediates. Therefore, they can be used for both ketogenesis and gluconeogenesis. They are:

  1. Phenylalanine
  2. Isoleucine
  3. Tyrosine
  4. Tryptophan

questions.text: Surgical staging in a woman with endometrial carcinoma reveals an invasion of less than 50% thickness of the myometrium. No other structures are involved. Histopathological examination shows grade 3 endometrial carcinoma. Which of the following is done after surgery?
questions.solution:
The patient has stage IA, grade 3 endometrial carcinoma as less than 50% of the myometrium is invaded. It should be managed with postoperative radiotherapy/brachytherapy. 

Post-operative pelvic radiotherapy is advocated for stages IA (grade 3), IA2, IB, and II. Radiotherapy along with chemotherapy provides a better result. A dose of 6000 cGy is used for a period of 6 weeks. Post-operative radiotherapy is given based on three factors: grade of the tumor, histology of the tumor, and depth of the tumor.

Radiotherapy as the main mode of treatment is used in stages III and IV when the tumors are inoperable. Chemotherapy is also given in stage III, while palliative radiotherapy is used in stage IV.

1 The glandular pattern is maintained with cellular atypia
2 Some glands show a papillary pattern and are solid
3 Glands are solid with a loss of architecture and stroma is scant
