questions.text: A 56-year-old male sustained a fracture of the neck of femur and he was planned for replacement surgery. Identify the prosthesis in the given image:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Austin-Moore prosthesis. The Austin-Moore prosthesis is used for hemiarthroplasty in the neck of femur fracture in elderly individuals. 

The Austin-Moore prosthesis has a head, neck, and stem. The stem has a hole to which the hook of the extractor can be attached. It helps in removing the prosthesis. There are two fenestrations in the stem which are for bone growth and fixing the prosthesis. It can be used without cement since its usage makes the removal difficult. 

The below image shows Austin Moore's prosthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Thompson prosthesis is used in hemiarthroplasty to replace the head of the femur. It is specially indicated in cases where the neck of the femur is absorbed. It can be used with or without cement.

The below image shows the radiograph image of Thompson's prosthesis.

Option C: Charnley's prosthesis is a total hip prosthesis used to replace the acetabulum and the head of the femur. it contains a polyethylene acetabulum cup and a steel head with a diameter of 22 mm. The radiograph image is shown below.

Option D: Muller's prosthesis is also a total hip prosthesis but the size of the head differs (32 mm) and the stem is available in different thicknesses.

questions.text: A young woman presented with ocular pain, photophobia, and blurred vision in her left eye for 10 days. She explains that her symptoms started after she had slept without removing her contact lenses. Her left eye is shown in the image below. Intra-ocular pressure is normal in both eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows localized bulging of the cornea surrounded by a white cicatricial ring suggestive of descemetocele. 

Descemetocele (Keratocele) is a localized bulging of Descemet's membrane. Patients with regular use of contact lenses are at higher risk of developing keratitis. Infections from the organisms like pneumococci, pseudomonas, and other septic organisms destroy all the layers of the cornea except for Descemet's membrane. However, this membrane alone is not able to support the intraocular pressure and therefore herniates. Patients will complain of pain, photophobia, and blurred vision.

The bulging membrane may persist surrounded by a white cicatricial ring or may rupture. It presents with severe pain and is a sign of impending perforation.

 

Other options:

Option A: Healed corneal ulcer will have a visual impairment and irregular opacity on the cornea.

The below image shows healed corneal ulcer.

 

Option C: In perforated corneal ulcers, patients complain of sudden gushing of hot fluid out of the eyes. Following this pain suddenly reduces. On examination, there is corneal opacity, prolapse of the iris, anterior dislocation of the lens, and reduced intraocular pressure.

Option D: Mooren's ulcer is a superficial ulcer that may occur due to autoimmune diseases. It starts as patches of grey infiltrates at the corneal margin. The ulcer then progresses to the whole of cornea.

Below image shows Mooren's ulcer in the periphery of the cornea.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with progressive ataxia and symptoms of increased intracranial tension, including headaches and vomiting. MR spectroscopy is performed, as shown below. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy showing a choline peak is diagnostic of glioma. Creatinine levels are decreased on MR spectroscopy in patients with glioma.

MR spectroscopy is a non-invasive means of obtaining metabolic information. The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

Other options:

Option B: Tuberculoma shows a lipid peak in MR spectroscopy.  

Option C: In Canavan disease, there is a marked increase in N-acetyl aspartate. Its concentration decreases with insults to the brain such as neoplasm, infarct, or abscess. N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) which is the most prominent resonance in a proton spectrum, is accepted as a normal neuronal functional marker.

Option D: Increased choline reflects increased membrane synthesis and/or an increased number of cells, as seen in lymphoma. However, lymphomas of the nervous system are very rare and seen in immunodeficient states like HIV.

questions.text: A middle-aged alcoholic man presented with complaints of fever, productive cough with foul-smelling sputum. On examination, he had poor oral hygiene and clubbing was present. His chest radiograph is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of alcoholism presenting with fever, productive cough with foul-smelling sputum, clubbing, and the radiograph showing a cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level in the right lung suggests a diagnosis of lung abscess.

Lung abscess occurs following microbial infection and is characterized by necrosis and cavitation. It is broadly divided into two categories:

  • Primary lung abscess usually occurs without underlying systemic or pulmonary conditions, typically in the posterior upper lobes and superior lower lobes of the lungs. The right lung is more commonly affected due to its less angulated bronchus. They are polymicrobial including anaerobes and microaerophilic streptococci. Aspiration is a major risk factor, hence alcoholic patients are at higher risk.

  • Secondary lung abscess usually occurs in the presence of an underlying lung or systemic condition. The location of the abscess varies with the underlying condition. Generally, they occur due to a broad bacterial spectrum including Pseudomonas aeruginosa and other gram-negative rods.

Clinical features include fever, night sweats, productive cough with foul-smelling sputum, and chest pain. Physical examination usually reveals poor dentition/gingival disease, and digital clubbing. Amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds can be heard on auscultation.

Chest X-ray features of lung abscess include a lung cavity with an air-fluid level and a thick and irregular cavity wall with surrounding pulmonary infiltrate.

Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive than chest radiography and is used to detect small cavities.

Clindamycin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, or moxifloxacin can be administered for primary lung abscesses. Antibiotics for secondary lung abscesses are prescribed according to the pathogen identified. 

Other options:

Option B: Bronchiectasis is characterized by local and irreversible dilatation of bronchi. Chest x-ray reveals tram-track appearance. CT shows signet ring sign (internal diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery), tree-in-bud pattern (thickened secretions), and tram track sign (due to lack of peripheral tapering of bronchus).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of prosthetic valve surgery comes to the clinic for evaluation of fever. On examination, a new-onset systolic murmur is heard in the mitral region and dark-red petechiae are seen in the nail beds of his hand. The following finding is seen on fundoscopy. Which of the following can be most likely seen in this condition?

choices.text: Fish-mouth stenosis of the mitral valve
Multiple, large, friable vegetations on heart valves

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fever with a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region in a patient who underwent prosthetic valve surgery, along with the fundoscopy finding of Roth's spots (exudative hemorrhagic lesions), is strongly suggestive of infective endocarditis. 

Clinical features of left-sided endocarditis include fever with chills, anorexia, weight loss, malaise, headache, night sweats, abdominal pain, and arthralgias. Cardiac murmurs, valvular insufficiency, and heart failure may also be present.

Peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:

  • Petechiae are common but nonspecific findings.
  • Purulent purpura
  • Osler nodes are tender subcutaneous nodules that are usually found on the distal pads of the digits.
  • Janeway lesions are non-tender maculae on the palms and soles.
  • Roth spots are relatively rare retinal hemorrhages with small, clear centers.
  • Splinter hemorrhages are seen in the nails of this patient. Subungual splinter hemorrhages are classically identified as dark-red, linear petechiae in the nail bed. 
  • Splenic and cerebral abscess

Diagnosis is made using modified Duke's criteria and treatment is done using long-term (6 weeks or more) antibiotic therapy and/or valve replacement

Other options:

Option A: Fish-mouth or “buttonhole” stenoses as seen in rheumatic mitral stenosis due to calcification and fibrous bridging across the valvular commissures.

The image below shows the fish-mouth appearance seen in mitral stenosis:

 

Option B: Brown atrophy can be seen in the liver and heart. It occurs due to the accumulation of a brown pigment called lipochrome or lipofuscin in large amounts due to normal aging process.

Option D: Calcified masses on the outflow surfaces of the cusps of aortic valves are seen in calcific aortic stenosis.

The given clinical scenario and the barium study showing the 'string' sign are suggestive of ileocaecal tuberculosis. 

Intestinal tuberculosis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis either secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis or by M.bovine as a primary GI infection.

The ileocaecal junction is the most common site of tuberculosis in the gastrointestinal tract. The liver, spleen, and peritoneum may also be involved in the abdomen.

Ieocaecal tuberculosis can be ulcerative or hyperplastic.

Patients typically present with cough, evening rise in temperature, weight loss, malaise, abdominal pain with distension, and alternating diarrhea and constipation. On palpation, the abdomen feels doughy and a mass may be palpated in the right iliac fossa.

Barium meal follow-through study findings in ileocaecal tuberculosis include:

  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum, known as string sign, and ileocaecal junction
  • Gooseneck ileum 
  • The ileocaecal angle becomes obtuse
  • Caecum appears pulled up and hepatic flexure is pulled down
  • Conical caecum
  • Fleischner sign- refers to a widely gaping, thickened, patulous ileocaecal valve and a narrowed, ulcerated terminal ileum

Treatment includes anti-tubercular therapy and nutritional support. Surgery may be indicated in complications like intestinal obstruction, perforation, hemorrhage, intra-abdominal abscess formation, or fistula formation.

Option B: Apple core sign is characteristically seen in the barium enema of carcinoma colon as shown below.

Option C: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows the string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below.

Option D: The image below shows the lead-pipe appearance of the colon on the barium enema. This finding is seen in ulcerative colitis due to the loss of haustra in the diseased colonic segment.

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever, myalgia, and severe arthralgia was diagnosed  with Chikungunya. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the vector of the underlying condition?

choices.text: Larvae rest parallel to water surface.
Wings are unspotted in adult stage.
It mostly breeds in stagnant water.

questions.solution:
Chikungunya is a viral illness transmitted by the vector Aedes mosquito. The incorrect statement about Aedes is that larvae rest parallel to the water surface. Its larvae have a siphon tube and are suspended with the head downwards, at an angle to the water surface.

The Aedes mosquitoes act as vectors for dengue, chikungunya, rift valley fever, and yellow fever. Due to the banded or striped character of their legs, they are also known as tiger mosquitoes. It mainly breeds in artificial accumulation/stagnant water in and around human dwellings such as water in flower pots, coconut shells, tree holes, and broken bottles. They lay the eggs singly, and the eggs are cigar-shaped. The adult mosquitoes have their wings unspotted with a hunched back body at rest. They can only fly smaller distances usually less than 100 meters. This helps in its eradication.

Aedes aegypti index, i.e., the ratio between the number of houses in an area where breeding of Aedes are found and the total number of houses examined in that area. This index is kept at zero at all ports.

Chikungunya is a viral infection caused by the Chikungunya virus which is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. The incubation period is from 4 to 7 days. Clinical features of the disease include joint ache (most common feature), fever, myalgia, anorexia, coffee-colored vomiting, cutaneous rashes, conjunctivitis, and adenopathy. Sometimes, post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation may be present at the site of rashes.

The disease can be diagnosed by serological methods such as enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and RT-PCR. Treatment is supportive management and fluid replacement.

Note: The disease lacks specific antiviral treatment and has ineffective modes of prevention. In light of this, the FDA has approved the first commercially available vaccine- IXCHIQ to prevent the disease caused by the virus.

questions.text: A 20-year-old lady presents with patchy hair loss, characterized by short broken strands as shown below. No abnormalities of the skin or scalp are present. Biopsy shows perifollicular haemorrhage. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of patchy hair loss characterized by short broken strands, as shown in the image, and the biopsy showing perifollicular hemorrhage point to a probable diagnosis of trichotillomania.

Trichotillomania:

  • Classified under obsessive-compulsive and related disorder
  • Irresistible urge to pluck the hair
  • Seen more commonly in females
  • Varying lengths of hair inside the area of hair loss
  • Hair is never completely lost in the patch
  • Orentreich/Friar Tuck/Tonsure sign: Loss of central area (easier to pull) and sparing of margins of the scalp.
  • Dermoscopy shows decreased hair density, short vellus hair, broken hair with different shaft lengths, coiled hairs, short vellus hair, trichoptilosis, and sparse yellow dots, which may contain black dots and no exclamation mark hair.
  • HPE:-
    • No inflammation
    • Perifollicular haemorrhage - due to plucking
    • intraepithelial and perifollicular haemorrhages and intrafollicular pigment casts

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a rare type of hemolytic anemia that developed after a viral infection and is associated with the presence of Donath-Landsteiner antibodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario of a rare hemolytic anemia that develops after a viral infection and is associated with Donath-Landsteiner antibodies suggests paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH).

PCH is a cold hemolysin type of hemolysis caused by IgG autoantibodies (Donath Landsteiner antibodies) directed against the P blood group antigen and brings about complement-mediated hemolysis. It presents as intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria and most cases are seen in children following viral infections. It may be seen in association with tertiary syphilis or as a complication of certain infections such as Mycoplasma pneumonia, flu, measles, and mumps.

In PCH, the direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test will be positive for complement only. It is characterized by the presence of the Donath-Landsteiner antibody. It is a unique antibody with anti-P specificity at 4°C. Hence, it binds to the RBC at 4°C. However, it causes complement-mediated lysis at 37°C.

It is a self-limiting condition (recovery within 1 month) but blood transfusion is required for the control of anemia.  

Immuno-hemolytic anemias are of 3 types:

Other options:

Option A: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a disease that results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), which is required for the synthesis of phosphatidylinositol glycan (PIG). It is chronic hemolytic anemia that is characterized by intravascular hemolysis. Apart from hemolysis, other features like pancytopenia and venous thrombosis are also seen. Patients may present with the passage of blood in urine, recurrent abdominal pain, and anemia which is normal-macrocytic.

Option C: March hemoglobinuria is an acute and self-imposed condition in which the RBCs lose their deformability and succumb to wear and tear leading to intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.

Option D: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia disorders are characterized by microvascular lesions due to the deposition of platelets and fibrin causing luminal narrowing. This causes shear stress that injures passing RBCs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with myocardial infarction and was planned for urgent percutaneous coronary intervention. Bivalirudin was used as an anticoagulant in this patient. Which of the following statements is true about the drug used?

choices.text: It is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor
Antidote of bivalirudin toxicity is protamine
No dose adjustments required in renal failure patients
It is contraindicated in heparin induced thrombocytopenia

questions.solution:
Bivalirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor administered only parenterally. 

It is a synthetic polypeptide that can be used in patients undergoing PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary bypass surgery for STEMI and NSTEMI as an anticoagulant along with antiplatelet drugs like aspirin. It is a specific, reversible direct thrombin inhibitor with quick onset and short-lasting anticoagulant action. It is administered intravenously. Bleeding is an important adverse effect of this drug.

Protamine does not antagonize bivalirudin's action, and there is no specific antidote to it (option B). Bivalirudin undergoes renal excretion and proteolysis, and thus, dose adjustments may be needed in patients with renal impairment (option C). It is often indicated in the treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) (option D).

questions.text: A middle-aged sandblasting factory worker presents with hemoptysis and a productive cough. Chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis. Which of the following occupational diseases is associated with an increased risk of developing this condition?
questions.solution:
Silicosis is associated with an increased risk of developing tuberculosis.

Patients with silicosis are more prone to develop tuberculosis, a condition called silico-tuberculosis. This is because silica causes dysfunction of the alveolar macrophages. Patients are also at greater risk of atypical mycobacteria, and fungal infections. Due to this increased risk of tuberculosis, the recommended treatment of latent tuberculosis in silicosis patients is longer.

Silicosis is a form of pneumoconiosis which is a cause of permanent disability and mortality. It occurs in people working in sandblasting, pottery, and ceramics industry, mining, and construction work. It occurs due to the inhalation of silica dust. The patient presents with cough, exertional dyspnea, and chest pain. 

In simple silicosis, the chest X-ray shows small rounded opacities in the upper lobes, and there is no impairment in lung function. When there is progressive nodular fibrosis, irregular masses >1 cm are seen, referred to as complicated silicosis. When these masses enlarge further, it is called progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) and is associated with significant impairment of lung function.

Eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes and crazy paving pattern may be seen on HRCT.

As there is no effective treatment for this condition, prevention should be done by rigorous dusting measures and regular examination of the workers. Silicosis is categorized as a notifiable disease under the Factories Act, 1948. 

Other options:

Option A: Asbestosis is a form of pneumoconiosis occurring in asbestos industry workers mainly involving the basal lobes. It can be associated with mesothelioma, a form of lung malignancy on long-term exposure.

Option C: Anthracosis is also known as coal worker's pneumonia and occurs in people working with coal dust. It tends to cause pulmonary fibrosis. 

Option D: Siderosis occurs due to prolonged exposure to iron deposits.

questions.text:
An HIV-positive female patient presents with fever and dry cough for 4 weeks. Her chest X-ray is given below and her CD4+ T cell count is 150 cells/ microliter. A lung biopsy was done that showed foamy alveolar infiltrates and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates on H & E staining. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?

H & E - hematoxylin and eosin
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, chest x-ray findings of diffuse interstitial infiltrate and H & E staining findings are suggestive of pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii and co-trimoxazole is the drug of choice for treatment as well as prophylaxis.

Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus that is found in patients having a CD4+ T cell count <200/µL.

The clinical picture is non-specific with complaints of indolent course of fever, cough, pleuritic pain, and unexplained weight loss. Lab and radiographic findings are also non-specific and show an increase in lactate dehydrogenase levels and symmetric, perihilar, and diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates, respectively. 

Hematoxylin and eosin staining of lung tissue showing foamy alveolar infiltrates and a mononuclear interstitial infiltrate is pathognomonic for P. jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). Demonstration of the organism in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid is 100% specific and sensitive for PCP in patients with HIV. 

 

Methenamine silver stain showing black-colored cyst wall of Pneumocystis jirovecii

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole combination (commonly known as co-trimoxazole) is the treatment of choice for PCP, and it is administered for 21 days, followed by a course for secondary prophylaxis. Concomitantly, glucocorticoids should also be administered to reduce pulmonary inflammation.

Patients who are susceptible to PCP are also given co-trimoxazole as prophylaxis. For patients who are unable to tolerate co-trimoxazole, IV pentamidine is the drug of choice.

Prophylaxis is indicated for other opportunistic infections like Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection, if CD4 counts fall below 50 cells/µL; Coccidioides, if CD count is <250/µL; and Cryptococcus, when the CD count is <100/µL.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man diagnosed with primary sclerosing cholangitis presents with progressive worsening of jaundice and pruritus for one month. MRCP done showed a dominant stricture at the hilum with a hepatic mass adjacent to the stricture. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: ERCP with brushings of the bile duct for cytology
Ultrasound-guided percutaneous biopsy of the mass

questions.solution:
In the above scenario, a patient with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) presents with pruritis, jaundice, and ascites that are suggestive of obstructive jaundice. Cholangiocarcinoma should be ruled out in case of a suspected mass in the biliary tract that is causing the obstruction. Hence the next best step would be to perform an endoscopic inspection with biliary brush cytology. 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is an autoimmune condition characterized by inflammatory strictures involving the intra and extra-hepatic biliary tree. It is a progressive condition that leads to secondary biliary cirrhosis.

The common age group of primary sclerosing cholangitis is 30-45 years. Men are affected twice as commonly as women. 2/3rd of these cases are associated with ulcerative colitis. It is also associated with Riedel’s thyroiditis and retroperitoneal fibrosis. There is also a strong predisposition to cholangiocarcinoma, gall bladder carcinoma, and colorectal carcinoma. Thus, annual screening for these cancers is mandatory. 

Clinical features of a patient with PSC include:

  • Intermittent jaundice
  • Fatigue
  • Weight loss
  • Pruritus
  • Abdominal pain

Liver function tests show a cholestatic pattern with an elevation of ALP and GGT and smaller rises in the aminotransferases. Bilirubin values may be variable.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERCP) is a gold standard in diagnosis and shows multiple dilatations and strictures (beading) of both intra- and extra-hepatic biliary tree.

Currently, there is no known effective medical therapy. Surgical management involving resection of extrahepatic biliary tree and hepaticojejunostomy has shown reasonable effects. For patients with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option.

The below image shows a cholangiogram of primary sclerosing cholangitis. There are diffuse strictures of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilatation of the areas in between:

Option A: Imaging studies to differentiate the biliary strictures from either inflammation or malignancy is not reliable. They are also not sensitive to detecting the mass and hence, are not indicated to diagnose cholangiocarcinoma. 

Option B: Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage is done as a part of palliative treatment in unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. This is done to relieve obstructive features like jaundice and pruritis. 

Option D: Ultrasound-guided percutaneous biopsy of the mass is not done as it increases the risk of bile duct injuries and biliary leak.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple itchy lesions as shown below. KOH stain revealed the presence of pencil-shaped macroconidia. The hair shaft also shows endothrix and the nails are also involved. Which of the following is likely to be the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario (involvement of the hair and nails) and microscopic examination showing characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia point toward a Trichophyton infection.

The given image shows alopecia with multiple black dots, which is seen in dermatophytosis. Dermatophytes involve only the superficial cornified layer of skin, sparing the dermis. It should be differentiated from dermatomycosis which is the cutaneous involvement of systemic fungi.

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children. Clinical features of tinea capitis are patchy hair loss, scaling, tender lymphadenopathy, and in severe cases, there might be pustules and crusting of the affected area.

Dermatophytes are of three types:

  • Trichophyton: Involves skin, hair, and nails; microconidia > macroconidia
  • Microsporum: Involves skin and hair; macroconidia > microconidia
  • Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails; only macroconidia

Tinea capitis is of two types—endothrix and ectothrix.

  • As the name suggests, endothrix causes infection inside the hair shaft and ectothrix causes infection outside the shaft.
  • Trichophyton tonsurans, Trichophyton violaceum, Trichophyton schoenleinii, Trichophyton yaoundei, and Trichophyton soudanense cause endothrix type of tinea capitis.
  • Remember: TV is always kept inside the house (ENDO) — so T. tonsurans and T. violaceum cause endothrix
  • Microsporum audouinii, Microsporum canis, Microsporum equinnum, and Microsporum ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.
  • Favus is caused by T. schoenleinii.

Sporothrix does not cause superficial mycoses.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with severe abdominal pain. It began in the periumbilical area 10 hours ago and later migrated to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. She has had intermittent nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever since the pain began. Her last menstrual period was 28 days ago. Examination reveals tachycardia and positive Rovsing's sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is acute appendicitis. 

The symptom of migrating abdominal pain from the periumbilical area to the right iliac fossa is classic for appendicitis. It begins as generalized visceral irritation and then changes to localized somatic pain in the right iliac fossa. In addition, this patient has a positive Rovsing's sign, which is pain in the right iliac fossa when left iliac fossa is deeply palpated.

The abdominal pain also causes nausea and vomiting as is seen in this patient. Other nonspecific signs of appendicitis include low-grade fever, abdominal tenderness, guarding, and rebound tenderness. McBurney's point depicting the area of maximal tenderness will also support a diagnosis of appendicitis. 

The Alvarado (MANTRELS) Score
Symptoms Score
Migratory right iliac fossa pain 1
Anorexia 1
Nausea and vomiting 1
Signs  
Tenderness (right iliac fossa) 2
Rebound tenderness 1
Elevated temperature 1
Laboratory  
Leucocytosis 2
Shift to the left 1
Total 10

A score of more than 7 is strongly predictive of acute appendicitis. If the score is 5-6, then an ultrasound or contrast-enhanced CT should be performed to confirm. 

Other options: 

Option B - Ruptured ectopic pregnancy would have pain that begins on one side and does not migrate. There would also have a history of a missed menstrual period while this patient is due for her period soon. A urine pregnancy test and an ultrasound would confirm the diagnosis. 

Option C - Acute diverticulitis is more common in patients over the age of 60. In addition, diverticulitis is more likely to happen on the left side as it usually occurs in the sigmoid area. A CT scan would help in diagnosis. 

Option D - Torsion ovary presents with severe pain and a tender palpable mass in the hypogastrium arising from the pelvis. Pelvic ultrasound should be done.

questions.text: A young man, who is a known alcoholic, complains of difficulty maintaining balance while turning. On examination, you note an abnormal gait, as shown below. What is the cause for this abnormality?
questions.solution:
Cerebellar ataxia, otherwise known as cerebellar gait ataxia, is the likely cause of this abnormality. Here, the patient is seen attempting tandem walking and displays improper heel-toe coordination, erratic foot placement, and truncal swaying.

Cerebellar gait ataxia leads to walking with a wide base of support, lurching strides, lateral instability of the trunk, and erratic foot placement. There is a loss of balance when attempting to walk on a narrow base. A difficulty to maintain balance when turning occurs as an early feature. Falling occurs as a late feature.

Causes of cerebellar ataxia include stroke, alcohol, trauma, tumor, hereditary cerebellar degeneration, Wilson's disease, and neurodegenerative disorders like multiple-system atrophy (MSA). 

Other options:

Option A: Patients with sensory ataxia walk unsteadily with multiple falls, on a narrow base, and tend to look down while walking. They lose balance on walking with their eyes closed or in the dark. Joint sense and vibration sense are diminished. Dorsal column lesions of the spinal cord result in sensory ataxia. Vitamin B12 deficiency is a treatable cause of sensory ataxia.

Option C: Frontal gait is a shuffling, freezing gait that includes a wide base of support, a short stride, shuffling along the floor, and difficulty with starts and turns. Many patients exhibit difficulty with gait initiation which is descriptively characterized as the “slipping clutch” syndrome or gait ignition failure. It is commonly seen in the elderly.

Option D: Spastic gait is characterized by stiffness in the legs, and a tendency to circumduct and scuff the feet. It is associated with an imbalance in muscle tone. Upper motor neuron signs can also be seen. Lesions in the corticospinal tract result in spastic gait.

questions.text: A 23-year-old student attempted suicide by hanging. He was taken to the hospital but declared as brought dead. His non-circulating heart was planned for transplant to a recipient. Which category of non-beating heart donors would this patient fall into as per the modified Maastricht classification?
questions.solution:
The patient would fall under category-I as per the modified Maastricht classification.

Modified Maastricht classification includes 5 categories of non-heart-beating donors in which categories I, II and V are uncontrolled while III, IV are controlled.  A non-heart-beating organ donation is when the organs are taken from a donor who was declared dead because of cessation of cardiac activity.

The categories of non-heart-beating donors are:

Uncontrolled- transplant team not present or prepared 

  • Category I- includes victims found dead at the scene of accidents and suicide. It includes the scenario where resuscitation when done is pointless (e.g. fatal cervical spine fracture).
  • Category II- donors are mostly victims of sudden cardiac or cerebral catastrophe. They are resuscitated in the ambulance and brought to emergency departments or they might have died in the department. Isolated brain injury, anoxia,  stroke, and victims of major trauma who died soon after hospital admission also fall under this category. 
  • Category V- Unexpected cardiac arrest during intensive care - Uncontrolled

Controlled- transplant team present and prepared 

  • Category III- encompasses dying patients in an intensive care unit. These are the patients prone to cardiac arrest and the treatment has been decided to stop by the clinicians and not commence resuscitation for various reasons.
  • Category IV- includes patients who suffer unexpected cardiac arrest during or after the estimation of brain death.

questions.text:
Arterial blood gas analysis of a person with liver disease reveals the following results. What type of metabolic and/or respiratory abnormality is likely to be present?

PaCO2= 35

HCO3- = 32

pH = 7.5

Anion gap = 16

Na+ = 140

K+ = 4.0

Cl-= 91

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis and compensatory respiratory acidosis
Metabolic acidosis and compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis and simultaneous respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The given arterial blood gas (ABG) result shows metabolic alkalosis plus respiratory alkalosis.

ABG analysis is done to assess disturbances of the normal acid-base homeostasis. It is calculated using the following steps:

Step 1: Determine if acidemia or alkalemia is present. Acidemia is a blood pH below 7.35 and alkalemia is a blood pH above 7.45. 

The ABG given here shows a pH of 7.5 which is above the limit of 7.45. Thus there is alkalemia.

pH = 7.5 Increased  Normal - 7.35 to 7.45
PCO2 = 35 Normal  Normal - 35 to 45 mmHg
HCO3- = 32 Increased  Normal - 20 to 28 mEq/L

Step 2: Look for the cause of acidemia/alkalemia. Acidosis is the pathological process that causes an increase in hydrogen ions. Alkalosis is the pathological process that causes a decrease in hydrogen ions. 

Here, the value of HCO3- is 32 (increase in bicarbonate ions). PCO2 is within normal limits. Thus, the primary acid-base disorder is metabolic alkalosis. 

During a simple metabolic disorder, you would expect there to be respiratory compensation (and vice versa). 

The expected respiratory compensation during metabolic alkalosis is : PCO2 = (HCO3- ) + 15 or PCO2 increases by 6 mmHg for each 10mEq/L increase in HCO3- .  

Thus, the expected increase in PCO2 should be 32 + 15  = 47 mmHg. However, the PCO2 here is only 35 mmHg and hence there is no respiratory compensation.

Step 3: Since CO2 is 35, which is below the compensatory values, it suggests that there is a simultaneous respiratory alkalosis.

Thus the ABG above shows a mixed disorder of metabolic alkalosis with simultaneous respiratory alkalosis.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy was diagnosed with Hemophilus influenza meningitis. The initial treatment plan was to start on ampicillin but later was shifted to ceftriaxone due to resistance to the former drug. What could be the probable mechanism of resistance?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of resistance to ampicillin (β-lactam antibiotic) in the case of Haemophilus influenzae infection is through the degradation of antibiotics by the production of beta-lactamase enzymes.

Beta-lactamases are enzymes produced by certain bacteria that cause hydrolysis of the β-lactam ring in β-lactam antibiotics, making them inactive. Some isolates of Haemophilus influenzae produce beta-lactamase, rendering them resistant to ampicillin. However, these strains are still sensitive to second and third-generation cephalosporins. In the case of β-lactamase-negative ampicillin-resistant strains, resistance is due to the presence of altered penicillin-binding proteins.

The resistance to penicillins and other beta-lactam antibiotics can be conferred through one of the following four mechanisms:

  • Inactivation of antibiotic by lactamases
  • Modification of target PBPs (Penicillin-binding proteins)
  • Impaired penetration of drug to target PBPs
  • Antibiotic efflux

Other options:

Option A: Drug incorporation is the mechanism by which the microorganism starts becoming resistant to the drug and eventually develops strains that require the presence of the antibiotic itself. This mechanism is seen in enterococcus which becomes resistant to vancomycin on prolonged usage. 

Option B: Drug efflux mechanisms are due to the overexpression of the drug efflux pumps by the microbes leading to the expulsion of the antibiotic drug. This mechanism of resistance is more commonly seen in anti-malarial drugs leading to the emergence of drug-resistant Plasmodium falciparum.

Option C: Binding to the 50s ribosomal unit is the mechanism of action of oxazolidinone by which protein synthesis is inhibited. This class of drugs is active against various gram-positive organisms including methicillin-resistant staphylococci, and vancomycin-resistant Staphylococci.

questions.text: In a patient with an acute exacerbation of asthma with severely compromised lung function who is not responsive to nebulized beta-2 agonists, which of the following is the steroid of choice for systemic use?
questions.solution:
The steroid of choice for systemic use in this above clinical scenario where there is an acute exacerbation of asthma (especially when the lung function is <30% predicted and there is no improvement with a nebulized β2 agonist) is hydrocortisone. 

Hydrocortisone has the most rapid onset (5–6 hours after administration), compared to 8 hours with prednisolone. It is given at a dose of 4 mg/kg initially, followed by a maintenance dose of 3 mg/kg every 6 hours. Intravenous therapy is usually given until a satisfactory response is obtained, and then it is replaced with oral prednisolone.

Mechanism of action of corticosteroids in an acute asthma attack:

  • Increases responsiveness to beta-2 agonists
  • Decreases mucous secretion
  • Decreases inflammatory cell response.

Steroids increase the transcription of beta-2 receptor genes and hence, increased responsiveness to beta-2 agonists. Beta-2 agonists, on the other hand, increase the effect of steroids by enhancing the action of glucocorticoid receptors. Theophylline increases the effects of steroids by activating the enzyme histone deacetylase, which is the target for steroids as well.

questions.text: An elderly gentleman presents with weight loss, the passage of dark-colored urine, and pale putty stools. On examination, you note a yellowish discoloration of the skin. Which of the following is likely to be elevated in the serum?
questions.solution:
This case scenario is suggestive of obstructive jaundice in which conjugated bilirubin levels in the serum will be elevated.

Yellowish discolouration of the skin (jaundice), weight loss, dark-coloured urine (bilirubinuria), and pale stools are all indicative of obstructive jaundice.

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia refers to the increase in serum conjugated or direct bilirubin levels. It usually occurs due to impaired excretion of bilirubin due to obstructive biliary pathology or hereditary syndromes. The diagnosis can be made by elevation of serum direct bilirubin levels, hepatic enzymes (Alkaline phosphatase specifically raised in cholestasis) and absent urinary urobilinogen. Obstruction of biliary ducts may be intrahepatic or extrahepatic and can be localised by imaging techniques.  

Bilirubin is the breakdown product of heme metabolism which is formed in the reticuloendothelial cells of the liver. It is insoluble in water and is known as unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. It is transported to the liver after binding to albumin, where it undergoes conjugation with glucuronic acid. The final product is known as conjugated bilirubin (direct bilirubin) which drains into the duodenum. On reaching the colon, the unconjugated form is acted upon by bacterial beta glucuronidases and reduced into colorless urobilinogen. Almost 90% is excreted through faeces as stercobilinogen, and the remaining will undergo enterohepatic cycling. A small fraction of this escapes hepatic uptake and will be excreted in the urine as urobilinogen.

Normally, urine bilirubin is absent. However, in obstructive jaundice, bilirubin cannot drain to the intestine to be converted into urobilinogen. Thus, fecal urobilinogen becomes absent, which gives the characteristic steatorrhea. The presence of urine bilirubin is an indication of post-hepatic obstruction and presents as cola/dark-colored urine. Increase bilirubin deposition in the skin, resulting in yellowish discoloration and may lead to pruritus.

Serum bilirubin can be measured using the van den Bergh reaction. The bilirubin is exposed to diazotized sulfanilic acid with/without alcohol and total and direct bilirubin levels are measured respectively. Indirect bilirubin levels would be the difference between the two values.

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a case-control study and employs matching to select controls similar to the cases. Which of the following types of bias is likely to be reduced as a result?
questions.solution:
Matching controls to be similar to the cases is likely to reduce confounding bias or bias due to confounding factors.

A confounding factor is one that is related to both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. Irrespective of being associated with the exposure under study, the confounding factor might itself serve as a risk factor for the disease. Hence, the elimination of these confounding factors is essential before carrying out a case-control study. 

Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (such as a case-control study), is the process where the participants in two groups (cases and controls in this case) are matched based on factors that are known to influence the outcome of disease (such as age, gender, race, etc.) to stop the potential confounders from distorting the results.

Other strategies to eliminate confounding factors include randomization, stratified randomization, and restriction.

Other options:
Option A - Recall bias in case-control studies occurs because history recollection is better in the case group as they have a stronger exposure than the control group. This bias can be reduced by decreasing the recall period as much as possible.

Option C - Selection bias is a type of sampling bias that occurs because of the nonrandom allocation of subjects such that the study population is not representative of the target population. The best way to reduce this is by randomization to create groups with similar distributions of known and unknown variables. 

Option D - Interviewer bias is a type of bias that occurs because the interviewer is aware of the case group and the hypothesis being tested, which can influence interviews and analysis. This can be reduced by blinding to reduce their influence on interviews and interpretation of outcomes.

questions.text: Gall bladder develops from _____.
questions.solution:
Gall bladder develops from pars cystica.

Development of extrahepatic biliary apparatus: 

The hepatic bud divides into pars hepatica and pars cystica:

  • Pars hepatica further divides into the right and left branches, which give rise to the right and left hepatic ducts
  • Pars cystica gives rise to the gallbladder and cystic duct

Common bile duct develops from the narrow part of the hepatic bud between pars cystica and the duodenal part of the foregut. 

Other options:

Option A: Septum transversum- The structures derived from this septum include the fibrous capsule of Glisson, sinusoids, and Kupffer cells of the liver. It also gives rise to the central tendon of the diaphragm and ventral mesentery, which further gives rise to the lesser omentum and falciform ligament.

Option C: The common hepatic duct develops from the undivided part of pars hepatica, distal to the origin of pars cystica.

Option D: Dorsal mesogastrium gives rise to the greater omentum.

questions.text: The following image depicts a biotechnology process. Choose the false statement regarding it.

choices.text: Hybrid cells lack the enzyme hypoxanthine phosphoribosyl transferase
Specific antibody-producing cells are integrated with myeloma cells
Hybrid cells are cultured in HAT medium

questions.solution:
The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology. Myeloma cells (not hybrid cells) are deficient in the enzyme HPRT (Hypoxanthine phosphoribosyl transferase).

Monoclonal antibodies refer to the antibodies produced by a group of lymphocytes that produce antibodies against a single antigen. These antibodies are produced by hybridoma technology. 

In this technology, the B-lymphocytes of mice spleen are immunized with an antigen to produce specific antibody. These specific antibody-producing B lymphocytes are then fused with myeloma cells that can multiply indefinitely.

The myeloma cells are deficient in the hypoxanthine-guanine-phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) gene and do not produce immunoglobulins. Therefore, the resulting hybrid cell is producing antibodies against a single antigen indefinitely. These hybrid cells are cultured in a HAT medium (containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine) and the monoclonal antibodies are obtained.

questions.text: A term infant with a birth weight of 3.2 kg develops jaundice at day 2 of life. It first appeared on the sclera and progressed to the trunk with a total bilirubin of 11mg/dL by day 4. He was managed with the following procedure. Choose the incorrect option regarding this procedure.

choices.text: 460–490 nm wavelength of light is used in this procedure.
Loose stools and dehydration are common complications.
Bronze baby syndrome is a contraindication for this procedure.
Irreversible structural isomerization is the most important mechanism.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal jaundice and the procedure shown in the image is phototherapy. The incorrect option regarding the procedure is that bronze baby syndrome is a contraindication for this procedure. 

Bronze baby syndrome is a complication associated with phototherapy. It is a dark, grayish-brown skin discoloration seen in infants with direct hyperbilirubinemia undergoing phototherapy. Phototherapy can be continued in such cases if required. Porphyria is a contraindication for phototherapy.

Complications associated with phototherapy include: 

  • Loose stools
  • Erythematous macular rash
  • Purpuric rash associated with transient porphyrinemia
  • Overheating
  • Dehydration (increased insensible water loss, diarrhea)
  • Hypothermia from exposure

The most effective wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinemia ranges from 460–490 nm (blue-green light). It is more effective than blue light (430 to 470 nm) due to the following reasons:

  • It converts bilirubin to harmless forms.
  • Its longer wavelength (460 to 490 nm) enhances skin penetration
  • Pure blue light can mask cyanosis in an infant

Clinical jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are reduced by exposure to the high intensity of light in the visible spectrum by 3 mechanisms:

  • Irreversible structural isomerization: Most important mechanism; acts by forming lumirubin from native bilirubin. It is then excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state
  • Reversible photo-isomerization: Converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation
  • Photo-oxidation: minor method

Phototherapy can be discontinued once two TSB (total serum bilirubin) values 12 hours apart fall below current age-specific cut-offs.

Sn-mesoporphyrin (SnMP), a synthetic metalloporphyrin is a potential alternative medical therapy for neonatal jaundice. It acts by competitive inhibition of the conversion of heme protein to biliverdin by heme oxygenase. A single intramuscular dose on the 1st day of life reduces the need for subsequent phototherapy. Complication from metalloporphyrins includes transient erythema if the infant is receiving phototherapy

Assessing the level of jaundice: 

Kramer described dermal staining of bilirubin. It is used as a clinical guide in assessing the level of jaundice.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops a fever, oliguria, periorbital edema, and smoky cola-colored urine  2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. Which of the following findings are most likely to be seen in the renal biopsy?

choices.text: Focal glomerular sclerosis on light microscopy
Hypercellular glomeruli with influx of leukocytes on light microscopy
Tram track appearance on PAS staining

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of fever, oliguria, periorbital edema, and smoky cola-colored are suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). The classic histologic picture of this disease shows hypercellular glomeruli with the influx of leucocytes (endocapillary proliferation).

PSGN is caused by immune complexes containing streptococcal antigens (M protein of cell wall) and specific antibodies. It is more commonly seen in children and they typically present with malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and hematuria (smoky or cola-colored urine) 1 to 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. The patients may also have mild proteinuria, periorbital edema, and mild to moderate hypertension.

In adults, the disease is more severe and the presentation and onset are atypical with features such as the sudden appearance of hypertension or edema, frequently with an elevation of BUN (blood urea nitrogen).

The characteristic electron microscopic findings are discrete, amorphous, electron-dense deposits called subepithelial humps (presumably representing the antigen-antibody complexes) and the presence of subendothelial deposits. 

Elevated titers of antibodies against many streptococcal antigens and a decrease in serum complement levels are also seen.

In 95% of the children, this disease is self-limiting. However, in some children and a large number of adults (40%), it may progress to a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis.

Other options:

Option A: Focal glomerular sclerosis on light microscopy is characteristically seen in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. It is primarily idiopathic but can occur in association with some conditions like HIV, heroin nephropathy, and morbid obesity. It presents as nephrotic syndrome in children and adults

Option C: Podocyte effacement is characteristically seen with minimal change disease. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

Option D: Tram track appearance on PAS staining is seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: You see a child with delayed development of speech as part of a health visit in a local school. The otoscopic appearance of the ear is shown below. Hearing loss of 20 dB is detected in audiometric tests. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image suggest a diagnosis of serous otitis media. 

The golden yellow discoloration of the tympanic membrane is caused by the clear watery straw-colored effusion filling the middle ear. Since the fluid is clear, one can see the structures of the middle ear quite clearly on otoscopy.

Patients having serous otitis media will have hearing loss that rarely exceeds 40 dB. This deafness can pass unnoticed, and maybe accidentally discovered during audiometric screening tests. Because of hearing loss, the development of speech is delayed or defective.

Otoscopic findings in serous otitis media:

  • Fluid level and air bubbles are seen when fluid is thin and the tympanic membrane transparent.
  • In chronic cases, the fluid becomes very sticky. Hence, the name glue ear. 
  • The tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with a loss of light reflex.
  • The mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in the right knee for the past few months. On examination, there is tenderness in the affected part with a reduced range of motion. A radiographic study revealed a solitary lytic lesion at the distal end of the femur and the microscopic appearance of the lesion is shown below. Which of the following is not an x-ray finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and microscopic appearance are suggestive of osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor and they are purely radiolucent.

Microscopically they are composed of mononuclear cells with macrophages. They are more common between the age of 20-40 and typically affect the metaphyses of long bones with a preponderance for the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius and proximal humerus.

Important X-ray features of a GCT:

  • A solitary, possibly lobulated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Eccentric location, most often subchondral
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex
  • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance
  • No calcification within the tumor
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

 

 

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like distal ulna, clavicle, proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

questions.text: A patient with a glioblastoma multiforme is started on mannitol as palliative therapy. Which of the following statements is false regarding its diuretic action?
questions.solution:
Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. These drugs do not cause much change in the GFR.

Osmotic diuretics cause extraction of fluid from the intracellular compartment resulting in the expansion of the extracellular compartment. The renal blood flow increases and renin release is inhibited. An increase in renal medullary blood flow removes NaCl and urea from the renal medulla thus reducing medullary tonicity. There is not much change in the total GFR.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic man is being evaluated for intracranial pathology on a contrast enhanced CT scan.  His lab reports showed a GFR of 50mg/dL. So the radiologist decided to use a suitable water-soluble contrast. Which of the following contrast agents would be preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is an elderly diabetic with GFR<60 mg/dL. Iohexol would be preferred to reduce the risk of contrast nephropathy. 

Iohexol is a non-ionic, low-osmolar water-soluble contrast agent. These contrast agents produce fewer abnormalities in the renal blood flow, thus causing less endothelial damage.

Water-soluble iodinated contrast agents are classified based on the osmolarity:

  • Low-osmolar - iohexol
  • Iso-osmolar - a subtype of low-osmolar contrast agent. example - iodixanol
  • High-osmolar - gastrograffin

Contrast nephropathy (CIN) is defined as a rise in serum creatinine by 0.5 mg/dl within 48-72 hours of intravenous contrast administration. Some risk factors include:

  • Older age
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Congestive heart failure
  • ST-elevation myocardial infarction

Prevention of CIN: Adequate hydration with normal saline or administration of sodium bicarbonate before and after the procedure. 

Other options:

Option B: Gadolinium is a contrast agent used in MRI, whereas the patient in the given scenario is undergoing CT. 

Option C: Gastrograffin is a high-osmolar water-soluble contrast agent. 

Option D: Lipoidol is a water-insoluble agent used for sclerotherapy or hysterosalpingography.

questions.text: On which chromosome are HLA genes located?
questions.solution:
The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on a short arm of chromosome 6 (6p).

The function of MHC molecules is to display peptide fragments of protein antigens for recognition by antigen-specific T cells. In humans, the MHC molecules are called human leukocyte antigens (HLA) because they were initially detected on leukocytes by the binding of antibodies. The combination of HLA alleles in each individual is called the HLA haplotype.

The HLA system is highly polymorphic. Each individual’s HLA alleles differ from the other. It has to be checked before organ transplantation.

questions.text: A patient complains of a foamy discharge from both eyes for two weeks associated with irritation and discomfort. The patient’s left eye is shown in the image below. How is this condition treated?
questions.solution:
The image and the history suggest angular conjunctivitis and the condition is treated using topical tetracycline.

Angular conjunctivitis is caused typically by Moraxella lacunata and Staphylococcus aureus (rare cause).

The nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis are the usual sources of infection. It spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs.

It is characterized by the inflammation and reddening of the inner and outer canthi with the excoriation of the skin. There is a collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles. There is discomfort and irritation of the eyes. Tetracycline ointment is used in management.

questions.text: A 26-year-old nursing mother presents with pain in her left breast. She has had difficulty with breastfeeding previously, and now examination reveals that her left breast is warm, red, swollen, and painful to palpation. Her temperature is 38.3 degrees and the WBC count is 13000/mm3. What is the first line of treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of pain, redness, warmth, and tenderness in the breast, along with fever and leucocytosis is suggestive of mastitis. Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers.

Mastitis refers to infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The infection is usually unilateral, with the source of infection being the bacteria residing in the infant's nose and throat. The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus, which can be cultured from breast milk. The symptoms appear in the 3rd or 4th week postpartum. Predisposing factors include fissures, abrasions, or cracks in the nipple. 

The first line of treatment is dicloxacillin, 500 mg orally, 4 times a day for 10-14 days. Other beta lactamase-resistant penicillins that are recommended include cloxacillin and flucloxacillin. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.

If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing staphylococci or if resistant organisms are suspected while awaiting the culture results, then vancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given. 

Breastfeeding should be continued. Sometimes the infant may not nurse on the inflamed breast due to engorgement and edema, which makes the areola harder to grip. Pumping alleviates this. When nursing bilaterally, suckling is best started on the uninvolved breast. This allows let-down to commence before moving to the tender breast.

In HIV patients with mastitis or breast abscess, even in resource-poor countries, it is recommended to stop feeding from the infected breast because HIV RNA levels increase in affected breast milk. These levels return to baseline after symptoms resolve.

The first image below shows mastitis and the second image shows a breast abscess.

questions.text:
The suture application shown in the given image will be most useful in the management of which of the following conditions?

(PPH- Postpartum hemorrhage)

choices.text: PPH caused due to  HELLP syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a B-lynch suture. It is most useful in the management of PPH caused due to polyhydramnios.

It is a technique to control severe atonic postpartum hemorrhage, which can occur as a result of polyhydramnios. B-lynch suture involves the use of vertical brace sutures, which oppose the anterior and posterior walls of the uterus. This leads to compression of the fundus and the lower uterine segment, thereby controlling the hemorrhage.

Predisposing factors for PPH are:

  • Atonic PPH:
    • Grand multipara
    • Previous history of PPH
    • Overdistented uterus: multifetal gestation, polyhydramnios, macrosomia
    • Precipitate labor, prolonged labor
    • Uterine malformations, fibroid uterus
    • Labor induction or augmentation with oxytocin
    • Placental anomalies: Placenta previa/ accreta/ increta/ percreta/ abruptio placenta
  • Traumatic PPH:
    • Instrumental deliveries
    • Episiotomy
  • PPH due to Coagulopathy:
    • Sepsis
    • IUD
    • HELLP syndrome

For PPH due to Coagulopathy - transfusion of blood products such as Fresh frozen plasma, cryoprecipitate, platelet concenterate is given.

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the mineral deficient in this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is seen with zinc deficiency. 
Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremors, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, and night blindness. Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities, perianal, perigenital, and perioral regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

Other options:

Option A- Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. The lesion in the neck is characteristic of Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in pellagra. The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).

 

Option C- Deficiency of riboflavin can present as anemia, corneal vascularization, mucocutaneous lesions, and personality changes. Milk and other dairy products are important dietary sources.

Option D- Copper deficiency leads to anemia, growth retardation, defective keratinization and pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia and mental retardation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with increasing tiredness, bone aches, and bruising on his legs. Bone marrow aspirate shows the presence of characteristic cells as shown in the image below. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely to be detected?
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks known as faggot cells. This is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3) or AML associated with PML-RARɑ fusion gene or t(15;17).

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is a type of AML.

Clinical features include anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia, most notably fatigue, fever, and spontaneous mucosal and cutaneous bleeding.

Bone marrow aspirate will show neoplastic promyelocytes with abnormally coarse and numerous azurophilic granules. 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia has a very good prognosis and is curable. The treatment of choice is all-trans-retinoic acid and arsenic trioxide.

Other options:

Option A: Inversion 16 is associated with AML M4 (myelomonocytic) and has a good prognosis.

Option C: Inversion 3 is associated with AML M7 (megakaryoblastic) and has a bad prognosis.

Option D: t(8;21) is associated with AML M2 (blasts with maturation) and has a good prognosis.

questions.text: A patient with an established diagnosis of peptic ulcer disease is started on omeprazole. Which type of cell membrane transport is inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
Primary active transport type of cell membrane transport is inhibited by this drug. Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor that blocks the H+-K+ ATPase. The proton pump is an example of primary active transport. 

Primary active transport is an active transport mechanism that obtains energy from the hydrolysis of ATP to transport molecules against an electrochemical gradient. The transportation of the molecules mainly depends on the carrier proteins.

Important examples of primary active transport: 

  • Sodium-potassium ATPase
  • Proton pump
  • Calcium ATPase

Proton pumps: These are essential for the primary active transport of hydrogen ions. These pumps are mainly present in gastric glands of the stomach and late distal tubules and cortical collecting ducts of the kidney. 

The main function of proton pumps in the parietal cells of the stomach is to secrete gastric acid. The gastric mucosa has abundant mitochondria and this provides the ATPase that is required for the primary active transport of hydrogen ions. 

At rest, the proton pumps lie within the cells in stacks of membrane compartments called tubulovesicles. During the active phase secretion, these tubulovesicles fuse to form canaliculi. This fusion increases the apical membrane of the cells and positions the proton pumps to begin the acid secretion. 

Proton-pump inhibitors like omeprazole form thiophilic sulfenamide cation that irreversibly binds and inactivates the enzyme H+-K+ ATPase. 

Other options: 

Option A: In simple diffusion, the molecules pass directly through the cell membrane along the concentration gradient. It does not require energy and is not carrier-mediated. Examples include the movement of water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen across the cell membrane. 

Option B: In secondary active transport, the transport of sodium is coupled to the transport of other substances against the concentration gradient. Examples include sodium co-transport of glucose and amino acids with sodium and sodium counter-transport of calcium and hydrogen ions. 

Option C: In facilitated diffusion, the molecules are transported via carrier-mediated proteins along the concentration gradient. This transport does not require energy. Examples include the transport of glucose through GLUT (insulin-mediated transport of glucose via GLUT 4).

questions.text: An offense registered under which of the following IPC sections dealing with sexual offenses is bailable?
questions.solution:
Section 376B dealing with sexual intercourse by the husband upon his wife, without her consent, during separation is cognizable (only on a complaint of the victim) and bailable.

Punishment is imprisonment for not less than 2 years, which may extend to 7 years and with a fine.

Other options:

Option A: 376D deals with a woman being raped by one or more people in a group with common intention and shall be punished for imprisonment not less than 20 years and can go for a lifetime. 

Option B: 376A deals with a person committing an offense of rape and inflicting injury which causes death or causes the woman to be in a persistent vegetative state.

Option D: 376C deals with sexual intercourse by a person in authority (police officer, public servant, member of armed forces, management or staff of a jail, remand home or other places of custody and management or staff of a hospital) induces or seduces any female inmate of such jail, remand home, place or institution to have sexual intercourse with him, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offense of rape.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who visited North America presents with low-grade fever, chest pain, cough, and hemoptysis. Radiological examination of the chest reveals cavity formation with lung abscess. Culture from the abscess at 37°C, shows the appearance given in the image. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of travel to North America suggests the diagnosis of pulmonary blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces fungi. 

Blastomycosis is a chronic infection caused by a dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. It is characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions in the lungs and skin. It is most common in North America and is also called North American Blastomycosis.

Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores in contaminated soil.

Blastomycosis can present in three forms:

  • Pulmonary infection - can be asymptomatic, focal or diffuse consolidation, military lesions or abscess formation. 
  • Disseminated disease - can lead to multiple abscesses and has high fatality.
  • Cutaneous disease over the skin of the face. Lesions may be a papule, around which secondary nodules develop and coalesce to form elevated ulcerative lesions. 

B. dermatitidis when cultured at 37°C shows thick-walled round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud.

Localized lesions are effectively managed with itraconazole for 6 months. Invasive or severe cases are treated with amphotericin B.

Other options:

Option B- Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus causing histoplasmosis. Infection is acquired by inhalation. Most infections are asymptomatic but infection of the reticuloendothelial system manifests as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anemia and it is highly fatal. 

Option C- Coccidiodes immitis is also a dimorphic fungus causing coccidiomycosis. Infection is acquired through inhalation of dust-containing spores of the fungus. Mostly they are asymptomatic and a self-limiting influenza-like fever termed valley fever or desert rheumatism develops in some individuals. The infection leads to lifetime immunity. 

Option D- Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis is again a dimorphic fungus causing paracoccidioidomycosis also termed South American blastomycosis. Infection is initially acquired by the inhalation of spores causing primary pulmonary infection. It spreads to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin, and lymphatics by hematogenous spread resulting in ulcerative granulomas of the buccal and nasal mucosa. 

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A pharmacologist is doing a study to assess the effect of a  new cholesterol–lowering drug, by measuring and recording the serum cholesterol levels. The study included 15 obese women and 10 non-obese women. Which test would they perform to compare the results obtained?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the Student t-test would be performed to compare the results obtained. As we are comparing two groups of obese and non-obese women for a quantitative variable (serum cholesterol level), the unpaired/Student t-test can be specifically used in this case.

Other options:

Option A: ANOVA is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and, here, the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

Option B: Chi-square test is used to differentiate proportions in two or more groups and assess the significance. 

Option D: Fischer's test is used to differentiate proportions in two or more groups to assess for independence. It exactly assesses small-sized samples (if the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5).

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of the following is best suited for the management of genital warts in a pregnant lady?
questions.solution:
Cryotherapy is considered relatively safe in pregnancy, while fluorouracil, podophyllin, and podophyllotoxin are contraindicated.

Cryotherapy treatment is physician-administered. Dimethyl ether spray, carbon dioxide snow, and liquid nitrogen all produce cold thermal damage to the skin. Liquid nitrogen produces the coldest freeze and is commonly used in practice. It is applied using a cotton wool bud or a cryospray until a rim of iced tissue (seen as a white discoloration) develops around the wart. The freeze is maintained for 5–30 seconds depending on the size and site of the wart. Scarring is unlikely with freezing times under 30 seconds. The main disadvantage of freezing is pain.

Genital warts

Genital warts/ venereal warts/ condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vulva. They are most commonly caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11. The growths may be discrete or coalesce to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is favored by vaginal discharge, the use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy.

HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin. These abnormal epithelial cells are called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo.

Diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine blue. The skin with abnormal nuclei retains the blue dye. These abnormal areas are then biopsied for histopathological examination.

Treatment: 

  • Local application of podophyllin 25% in alcohol or podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin or podophyllin cream
  • 25% trichloroacetic acid plus 5% fluorouracil
  • Diathermy loop, laser ablation, cryotherapy for larger lesions
  • Surgical excision
  • Interferon ointment or local injection

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida who was admitted to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation was planned for induction of labor using the device shown below. Which of the following medications is present in this device?
questions.solution:
The obstetric device shown in the above image is of cervidil vaginal insert. It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone.

A cervidil vaginal insert is a thin, flat, rectangular polymeric wafer held within a small, white mesh polyester sac. It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone (PGE2) released at a rate of 0.3 mg/hour. The sac has a long attached tail to allow easy removal from the vagina.

Following insertion, the woman should remain recumbent for at least 2 hours. The insert is removed after 12 hours or with labor onset and at least 30 minutes before the administration of oxytocin.

It is used for cervical ripening prior to induction. A possible side effect of dinoprostone is uterine tachysystole.
