questions.text: While undergoing contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) of the abdomen, a patient develops urticaria, dizziness, bronchospasm, and hypotension 10 minutes after the administration of the iodinated radiocontrast dye. This is the first time that the patient is undergoing a CECT and an anaphylactoid reaction was suspected. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: It involves degranulation of mast cells.
It can occur on first exposure
It is most commonly caused by NSAIDs.

questions.solution:
The clinical features of urticaria, dizziness, bronchospasm, and hypotension a short while after administration of the iodinated radiocontrast dye on first exposure are suggestive of an idiosyncratic anaphylactoid reaction. Anaphylactoid reactions are not IgE mediated.

These reactions are caused by direct degranulation of the mast cells or basophils, which causes the release of mediators. Unlike the classic anaphylaxis, which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid reaction can occur even on the first exposure.

The most common agents that can cause an anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.

Non-IgE-mediated mast cell activation in response to certain drugs can not be clinically distinguished from classical IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reactions (anaphylaxis). However, non-IgE mediated reactions can occur with the first known exposure. This is because mast cells do not need sensitization by IgE.

Note: The term 'anaphylactoid reaction' is no longer recommended by the World Allergy Organization (WAO), and has been replaced by 'non-immunologic anaphylaxis.'

In 2014, WAO has introduced two new terms:

  • Immunologic anaphylaxis: It includes anaphylactic reactions mediated by IgE, IgG (in animals), and immune complex/complement-mediated reactions.
  • Non-immunologic anaphylaxis: It includes reactions caused by agents which cause massive degranulation of mast cells or basophils in the absence of immunoglobulin.

questions.text: A man who is a chronic alcoholic has abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and mucosal ulcers. Stool examination revealed the following. What is the causative organism for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with stool examination showing a large ovoid trophozoite with cilia all over the surface suggests balantidiasis, the causative organism for which is Balantidium coli. 

It is the only ciliated protozoan and is present as a commensal in the large intestine. It is mostly asymptomatic in healthy individuals. However, certain predisposing factors such as malnourishment, alcoholism, concurrent infection with Trichuris trichiura, or bacterial infection can cause clinical infection.

Clinical manifestations include mucosal ulcers, diarrhea, frank dysentery, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. 

Diagnosis is by stool examination, showing the presence of trophozoites in diarrheic feces and cysts in formed stools. Trophozoites are large in size, with a macronucleus and rapid-revolving motility, while cysts are round with a macronucleus.

The trophozoite is shown in the image below:

Treatment is with tetracycline 500 mg 4 times a day for 10 days. 

Other options:

Option A: Babesia infection causes babesiosis, which is a disease that resembles malaria. Diagnosis is by the examination of blood smears stained with Leishman or Giemsa stain, where Babesia appears as intraerythrocytic round, pyriform, or ring forms, like Plasmodium falciparum.

Option B: Cyclospora infection causes prolonged diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting which is more severe in immunocompromised individuals. On wet mount, oocysts are seen as red spheres when stained with acid-fast stain.

Option D: Isospora belli infection causes watery diarrhea that is self-limiting. The oocyst is not easily seen on stool-wet mounts. It may be visible after stool concentration and staining with acid-fast stain, as shown below.

Examination reveals a supracondylar fracture of the humerus with injury to the structure marked as '?' in the given image. Which of the following muscle actions is most likely to be affected?

questions.text: A child from Bihar has a fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and anemia. The organism shown below is found to be the causative vector of the underlying condition. Identify the vector.
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history and the image given in the question, the child is suffering from Kala-azar and the vector for kala-azar is the phlebotomine sandfly. 

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is an arthropod-borne protozoal infection. The causative vector is the female phlebotomine sandfly, Phlebotomus argentipes. Cutaneous leishmaniasis occurs due to the bite of P. papatasi and P. sergenti. Clinical features of visceral leishmaniasis include anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and fever. In cutaneous leishmaniasis, painful ulcers at the site of sandfly bite may be present. Ulcers around the margins of the mouth and nose may be present in the mucocutaneous variety. 

Preventive measures include the usage of residual insecticides such as DDT (resistant to P. papatasi in North Bihar) in endemic areas. Spraying of insecticides should be done up to a height of 6 feet and at the rate of 1-2 g per sq. meter. Personal protective measures such as the usage of repellent creams and protective nets should be encouraged. Sanitation is also important by eliminating breeding sites such as leftover organic matter, broken mud pots, burrows, and rubbish around the house. 

Other diseases transmitted by phlebotomus include oriental sore and sandfly fever.

Other options:

Option A: Culex mosquitoes are the vector for filariasis.

Option C: Anopheles mosquitoes are the vector for malaria.

Option D: Soft tick is the vector in diseases such as Q fever and relapsing fever. It is shown below.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen

questions.text: A 22-year-old girl enquires if there are any surgical options for the correction of her myopia. She does not wish to wear her glasses or switch to contact lenses. What is the minimum time frame for which her refractive error has to be stable before laser assisted in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK) can be considered?
questions.solution:
The patient's refractive error has to be stable for a minimum period of at least 1 year before undergoing laser-assisted in-situ keratomileusis. (LASIK).

Myopia also known as shortsightedness is a refractive error in which parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused in front of the retina with the accommodation at rest. 

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed using excimer laser. It is the commonly done surgery for myopia. Excimer laser beam reshapes the cornea by ablating the superficial stroma to a predetermined extent after lifting a flap of the cornea with a sharp microkeratome. 

Patient selection criteria:

  • In individuals aged 21 years and above.
  • In individuals who have a stable refractive error for at least 1 year.
  • In individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment.
  • In individuals in whom corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus have been ruled out.

Complications:

  • Tear instability (dry eye)
  • Wrinkling, distortion, or dislocation of the flap
  • Subepithelial haze with resultant glare, especially at night.
  • Persistent epithelial defects.
  • Epithelial ingrowth under the flap.
  • Diffuse lamellar keratitis (sands of the Sahara)
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Keratoconus

questions.text: Which of the following postmortem changes is not a feature of normal decomposition?
questions.solution:
Saponification or adipocere is a postmortem change which is not a feature of normal decomposition.

It is characterized by the formation of a waxy, greasy, and whitish substance with a sweet, rancid odor. it resembles the consistency of soap. The pattern of distribution includes areas of fatty tissues in the dead body. 

Adipocere consists primarily of fatty acids that are produced due to postmortem hydrolysis and the hydrogenation of body fats. It is a water-dependent process that involves the conversion of unsaturated liquid fats to saturated solid fats. 

Medicolegal importance is as follows:

  • It is the surest sign of death
  • It gives a rough estimate of the time since death and
  • The cause of death can be identified. In the face, the features are well preserved and therefore used in identification. 

Other options:

Option A: Right iliac fossa discoloration is the first external sign of decomposition, and is due to the action of C.welchii in the ileocecal portion of the gastrointestinal tract. Bacterially produced hydrogen sulfide combines with hemoglobin to give rise to sulphmethemoglobin which causes discoloration.

Option B: Subsequently, bacterial dissemination takes place through the blood vessels causing similar discoloration of the superficial blood vessels. A linear branching pattern is formed known as marbling.

Option C: The process of decomposition destroys the anatomic integrity of skin which leads to localized peeling known as skin slippage and loosening of skin of hands and feet known as degloving.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with frequent nosebleeds is brought to the OPD for a routine check-up.  He has a history of excessive bleeding during a dental procedure that he underwent recently.  A normal platelet count, prolonged BT, normal PT, and a prolonged aPTT are noted in his laboratory reports. Which of the following is the major source of the likely deficient factor?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of von-Willebrand disease. It is caused by a deficiency of the von-Willebrand factor. The major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor is endothelial cells. 

They are present within cytoplasmic vesicles called Weibel-Palade bodies.

Normal Platelet count, Prolonged BT, Normal PT, and Prolonged aPTT are seen in von-Willebrand disease. Factor VIII is found bound to the Von-Willebrand factor (vWF)  in the blood. Deficiency of vWF results in Factor VIII deficiency and prolongation of aPTT in this disease. Prolonged BT is due to abnormal platelet-mediated hemostasis.

vWF is also found in

  • Platelet granules (Less as compared to endothelial cells)
  • Subendothelium, where it binds to collagen

Von Willebrand disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder in humans. The bleeding tendency is usually mild and manifests during surgical or dental procedures. The most common presenting symptoms are spontaneous bleeding from mucous membranes (epistaxis), excessive bleeding from wounds, or menorrhagia.

It is usually transmitted as an autosomal dominant disorder, but rare autosomal recessive variants can be seen.

Three types are recognized, with phenotypic variations:

Type 1 and type 3 von-Willebrand disease are associated with quantitative defects in vWF.

Type 1 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a mild to moderate vWF deficiency, accounting for about 70% of all cases. It is associated with mild disease.

Type 3 disease is an autosomal disorder resulting in little to no vWF synthesis. Because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the circulation, factor VIII levels are also reduced in type 3 disease and the associated bleeding disorder is often severe.

Type 2 von-Willebrand disease is characterized by qualitative defects in vWF. Type 2A is the most common. It is inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder.

questions.text: An infant had otitis media for which he was given a course of antibiotics. A few days later, he developed fever, irritability, tender erythematous rash, and blisters followed by extensive peeling of the skin. It is shown below. There were no mucosal lesions. Which among the following is not true regarding the condition?

choices.text: Exfoliative toxin is responsible for the condition.
Peeling of outer layer of epidermis is seen.
Ritter's disease is the severe form in the newborn.
Pyrogenic exotoxin is responsible for the condition.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an infant with an infection focus (otitis media) that is followed by generalized peeling of the skin and a toxic state without any mucosal involvement is suggestive of staphylococcal scalded-skin syndrome (SSSS). Pyrogenic exotoxin, which is mainly responsible for toxic shock syndrome, is not related to the above condition.

SSSS is mainly due to exfoliative or epidermolytic toxin (option A) in which there is a separation of outer layers of the epidermis from the underlying tissues (option B).

A severe form of this disease in newborns is known as Ritter's syndrome. (option C) In older patients, the severe form is toxic epidermolysis. Milder forms are known as pemphigus neonatorum and bullous impetigo.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Staphylococcus

Staphylococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Furuncle/boil- Infection of the hair follicle.

The given image shows a furuncle:

 

b. Carbuncle: A cluster of several furuncles:

The given image shows a carbuncle:

 

c. Bullous impetigo: Results in large blisters called bullae, usually seen in areas with skin folds such as armpits, groin, buttocks, etc.

The given image shows ruptured bullous impetigo:

 

d. Cellulitis: It is a rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually associated with wounds, incisions, burns, etc.

The given image shows cellulitis following an abrasion. The red streaks indicate the involvement of the lymphatics:

 

e. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliating toxin that causes peeling of the skin.

The given image shows SSSS:

 

Note: The conditions shown above are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus. It is important to remember that they may also be caused by other bacteria. Cellulitis is more commonly caused by Streptococcus.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon is performing submucosal resection in a patient with a deviated nasal septum. As an intern posted in the department, you are asked about the various contraindications of this procedure. In which of the following patients, will the surgery not be contraindicated?

choices.text: A 20-year-old patient with acute respiratory infection
A 35-year-old patient with controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
In a 35-year-old patient with controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, submucosal resection (SMR) of the deviated nasal septum (DNS) is not contraindicated.

Contraindications of SMR surgery:

  • Patients within the age of 17 years- conservative surgery like septoplasty is preferred in such cases
  • Acute episode of respiratory infection
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Untreated or uncontrolled diabetes mellitus or hypertension

Surgery in a case of DNS is indicated when the condition causes recurrence of symptoms such as

  • Nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches
  • Sinusitis and otitis media due to obstruction to ventilation of paranasal sinuses and middle ear
  • Recurrent epistaxis from the septal spur
  • Sleep apnea or hypopnea syndrome

Indications for septoplasty:

  • Cosmetic correction of external nasal deformities, as a part of septorhinoplasty
  • Preliminary step in hypophysectomy (trans-septal trans-sphenoidal approach) or vidian neurectomy (trans-septal approach)
  • Approach to middle meatus or frontal recess in endoscopic sinus surgery when deviated septum obstructs the view and access to these areas
  • Access to endoscopic dacryocystorhinostomy operation in some cases.

Related Pearl: Nasal Septum

Septum proper is an osseocartilaginous framework made up of:

  • Septal or quadrilateral cartilage
  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer
  • Others – crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, rostrum of sphenoid, crest of palatine bones and the crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text: A 7-month-old male baby is brought to the emergency room with a history of recurrent lung infections. Further assessment reveals that though his cellular immunity is normal, there is negligible circulating IgG. His brother had the same disease and he died as a result of viral encephalitis but the IgG levels in both his parents and his sister are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of recurrent lung infections, the same disease in another male sibling and the presence of negligible IgG in presence of normal cellular immunity are suggestive of Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

The congenital disorder Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia occurs in male infants at 5 to 8 months of age, the period during which maternal immunoglobulins are depleted. It is caused by mutations in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase located on the long arm of the X chromosome, called Bruton tyrosine kinase (Btk)  which is the gene that encodes an enzyme critical to B-lymphocyte maturation). The patient(usually an infant) suffers from recurrent pyogenic infections associated with severe hypogammaglobulinemia and there is an absence of mature B cells in peripheral blood and plasma cells in the lymphoid tissues. 

The classic form of this disease has the following characteristics:

  • B-cells are absent or markedly decreased
  • Serum levels of all classes of immunoglobulins are decreased
  • Plasma cells are absent
  • Germinal centres of lymphoid organs are underdeveloped.

It is treated using replacement therapy with immunoglobulins.

Other options:

Option A: DiGeorge syndrome is a developmental disorder resulting in failure of development of the thymus gland and there is an absence of cell-mediated immunity.

Option B: Selective immunoglobulin A deficiency is commonly asymptomatic and symptomatic patients commonly present with diarrhoea and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. In addition, patients also have extremely low levels of both serum and secretory IgA.

Option C: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is also an X-linked genetic disease but is characterized by defects in both humoral and cellular immunity.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man with a mild cough tested COVID-19 positive and was advised home quarantine. Which of the following statements is true regarding biomedical waste management in this scenario?

choices.text: Tissues contaminated with his body fluids are to be collected in red bag
Water bottles and tetra packs used by him are considered biomedical waste
The masks used by him are to be collected in yellow bags
General waste bags are sprayed with 10% sodium hypochlorite solution prior to disposal

questions.solution:
The masks used by patients with COVID-19 are collected in yellow bags.

Waste from quarantine homes/camps or home-care facilities with COVID-19 patients are disposed of in the following manner:

  • General solid waste should comprise waste generated from the kitchen, packaging material, waste food material, waste papers, waste plastics, floor cleaning dust, etc. including left-over food, disposable utensils, water bottles, tetra packs that have been used by suspected quarantined persons and COVID-19 patients at homecare or home quarantine. These items are collected in securely tied bags and finally disposed of by urban local bodies. 
  • Waste containing contaminated water/blood of COVID-19 patients is collected in yellow bags.
  • The masks used by them are collected in yellow bags as well. They are placed in separate bins.
  • These bags are then handed over to Common Biomedical Waste Treatment Facility (CBWTF) waste collectors.
  • As a matter of caution, bags containing general waste may be sprayed with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution prior to disposal.

questions.text: Which of the following substances cannot cross the placental barrier?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ascorbic acid, iron, and IgG can cross the placenta and parathormone does not cross the placenta.

The placental membrane is a partition separating the maternal and fetal portions of the placenta. It acts as a protective barrier for the fetus and selectively allows the passage of nutrients to the fetus. Substances with a molecular weight of more than 500 daltons are not allowed to pass through the barrier. Substances crossing the placenta from the maternal to fetal blood first traverse the syncytiotrophoblast, the cytotropho­blast layer, the villous stroma, and finally, the fetal capillary wall. 

The syncytiotrophoblast actively or passively adjusts the amount and rate of substance transfer to the fetus. The fetal-facing basal cell membrane is the site of transfer to the intra-villous space.

questions.text: A patient is posted for surgery of a distal forearm fracture. Regional anesthesia was planned. The drug is injected intravenously into a tourniquet occluded limb. Which of the following is not true for the type of anesthesia being used here?

choices.text: Providing a bloodless field is difficult
Prilocaine is commonly used in this type of block
Exsanguination is done prior to tourniquet inflation
Bupivacaine is the drug of choice in this method

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the block being done is intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA) or the Bier's block. Bupivacaine is not the drug of choice in IVRA due to its severe local anesthetic side effects.

Bier's block is used to provide regional anesthesia for short surgical procedures (<60 minutes) of the limbs. It involves the intravenous administration of a local anesthetic into a tourniquet–occluded limb. Anesthesia sets in within 5 minutes. 

The limb is first raised above the heart level to drain venous blood. Then exsanguination is done by applying an Esmarch bandage, following which a tourniquet is applied proximally to the site of the operative procedure. The solution is injected and usually left in place for at least 25 minutes, after which the tourniquet is released incrementally. Drugs commonly used are lidocaine and prilocaine.

The patient is observed for any signs or symptoms of local anesthetic toxicity. The local anesthetic diffuses from the peripheral vascular bed to nonvascular tissue such as axons and nerve endings. The safety and efficacy of this procedure depend on the interruption of blood flow to the involved limb and the gradual release of the tourniquet. 

Complications following Bier's block are postoperative pain, difficulty in providing bloodless field, and in rare cases may lead to compartment syndrome due to increased pressure applied. Premature deflation of the tourniquet or increased dose of local anesthesia may lead to systemic toxicity.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with miosis, ptosis, and anhydrosis on the left side along with dysphagia, and dysarthria, and frequently falls towards the left side on walking. On examination, he was found to have a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the body and the left side of the face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient having left-sided Horner's syndrome, dysphagia, dysarthria, ataxia towards left and right-sided loss of pain and temperature is left-sided Wallenberg’s syndrome.

Wallenberg’s syndrome, otherwise known as the lateral medullary syndrome, is a type of ischemic stroke of the brainstem. The symptoms and the corresponding tracts affected are shown below: 

Tract affected Symptoms
Descending tract and nucleus of CN V  Ipsilateral impaired sensation over half of the face
IX and X CN Ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord(dysarthria), diminished gag reflex causing dysphagia
The nucleus of tractus solitarius Ipsilateral loss of taste
Vestibular nucleus   Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
Spinocerebellar tract Ipsilateral ataxia
Descending sympathetic tract Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (characterized by miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis (decreased sweating)
Lateral spinothalamic tract  Impaired pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body

It can be caused by occlusion of vessels like the vertebral artery, posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), Superior, middle, or inferior lateral medullary arteries. The most commonly involved are the vertebral artery and PICA.

Other options:

Dejerine syndrome is otherwise known as medial medullary syndrome. It occurs due to occlusion of the vertebral artery or its branch. There is paralysis of the ipsilateral tongue (face is spared) and contralateral limbs, as well as impaired tactile and proprioceptive sense of the contralateral half of the body.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought by his parents with complaints of diarrhea and dermatitis. The child had neutral aminoaciduria and a positive Obermeyer test result. Which of the following is the precursor of the vitamin that is deficient in the patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of pellagra secondary to Hartnup disease. The vitamin deficiency in this condition is niacin. The precursor of niacin is tryptophan.

Niacin/vitamin B3 is a constituent of NAD and NADP. Its deficiency occurs in a maize-based diet (maize is deficient in tryptophan), carcinoid syndrome (all the tryptophan is converted to serotonin), and Hartnup disease (defective absorption of tryptophan from intestine and kidney).

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra (3Ds):

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Dermatitis (Casal necklace)
  3. Dementia

The image below shows a Casal necklace—a ring-like rash seen around the neck caused by the deficiency of niacin.

Diagnosis of niacin deficiency secondary to Hartnup disease is based on neutral aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds detected by the Obermeyer test.

Nicotinic acid inhibits the flux of free fatty acids from adipose tissue; so the acetyl CoA pool is reduced; and hence serum cholesterol is lowered. In high doses, niacin is useful to reduce Lp(a) levels.

Niacin toxicity - Nicotinic acid when given orally or parenterally produces a transient vasodilatation of the cutaneous vessels and histamine release. The reaction is accompanied by itching, burning, and tingling. Intake of nicotinic acid in excess of 50 mg/day may lead to liver damage.

questions.text: A 56-year-old​ female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is carcinoma esophagus. The given barium study shows irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Carcinoma esophagus is one of the most common malignancies manifesting in mid to late adulthood. It can be squamous cell or adenocarcinoma.

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) affects the upper two-thirds of the esophagus while adenocarcinoma affects the lower third. Tobacco smoking and alcohol are the risk factors for SCC. Obesity and gastroesophageal reflux disease increase the risk of adenocarcinoma.

Dysphagia can be the most common presenting feature but may present late. Other features such as regurgitation, weight loss, vomiting, and odynophagia can be seen. Lymph node involvement indicates a poor prognosis.

Endoscopy is the first line of investigation done. CT is useful to rule out metastasis. Endoscopic ultrasonography is used to assess the depth of tumor invasion through the wall of the esophagus, adjacent organs, and lymph node metastasis.

Management options include radical esophagectomy, neoadjuvant chemotherapy, and palliative chemoradiation or endoscopic treatments.

Other options:

Option B: Diffuse esophageal spasm results in the corkscrew appearance of the esophagus on barium study, as shown below.

 Option C: Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a smooth submucosal mass. The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Option D: Esophageal webs occur in the upper and middle esophagus as a thin membrane that can be identified by contrast radiology. 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient, who is on chronic antiarrhythmic drug therapy, presents with hypotension, photosensitivity, and cold intolerance. He also complains of difficulty in getting up from the squatting position. Pulmonary function tests revealed a restrictive pattern of lung disease.  What is the most likely drug implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug implicated in this scenario is amiodarone. Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug.

Amiodarone is used to convert atrial fibrillation and to slow ventricular rate in the treatment of tachyarrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardias, paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), and recurrent VF. It is also used in the treatment of cardiac arrest if epinephrine therapy is not effective.

The clinical spectrum of hypotension; photosensitivity; cold intolerance, which is indicative of hypothyroidism; difficulty in getting up from the squatting position indicative of proximal muscle weakness; and restrictive pattern on PFT, which is indicative of pulmonary fibrosis are all side effects of amiodarone.

The other significant side effects of amiodarone include the following:

  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Optic neuritis
  • Abnormal liver function tests
  • Peripheral neuropathy

The below image shows skin pigmentation in a patient due to prolonged amiodarone therapy.

Other options:

Option A - The side effects of adenosine are short-lived due to rapid transport into the cell and deamination. The side effects seen are transient asystole, transient dyspnea, and rarely transient atrial fibrillation.

Option B - The side effects of digoxin are common and include GI symptoms, visual and cognitive dysfunction, and arrhythmias, typically atrial tachycardia with AV block. Other arrhythmias that can occur are ventricular bigeminy, bidirectional ventricular tachycardia—a rare entity—and AV junctional tachycardias.

Option C - The side effects of quinidine are diarrhea, diarrhea-induced hypokalemia, marked QT prolongation, and a high risk of torsades de pointes at therapeutic or subtherapeutic concentrations. Cinchonism is a syndrome associated with quinidine intake, which includes symptoms of headache and tinnitus.

questions.text: A pregnant woman underwent amniocentesis and the fetus was found to have Edward's Syndrome. According to the MTP Amendment Bill, 2021, within what period of gestation is the termination of pregnancy legal?
questions.solution:
According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, termination of pregnancy can be undertaken at any point of time when there are substantial fetal abnormalities.

Rajya Sabha passed this bill on 17th March 2021. Other features of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill:

  • Enhancing the upper gestation limit from 20 to 24 weeks for special categories of women which includes survivors of rape, victims of incest, and other vulnerable women (like differently-abled women, minors), etc.
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure.
  • Opinion of only one provider will be required up to 20 weeks of gestation and two providers for termination of pregnancy of 20-24 weeks.
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of an obstetrician, pediatrician, radiologist, and a person appointed by the state.
  • The upper gestation limit is not applicable in cases of substantial fetal abnormalities.
  • Name and other particulars of a woman whose pregnancy has been terminated shall not be revealed except to a person authorized in any law for the time being in force.
  • The ground of failure of contraceptives has been extended to women and their partners.

 

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient diagnosed with a urinary tract infection was prescribed an antibiotic that binds to the region marked by the arrow in the given image and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. Identify the drug given to this patient:
questions.solution:
From the clinical scenario, the drug given to the patient suffering from urinary tract infection is gentamicin. An antibiotic that binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis is an aminoglycoside and gentamicin is an aminoglycoside from the given options. 

Aminoglycosides like gentamicin act by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit. They also cause misreading of the mRNA. 

Aminoglycosides include streptomycin, gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin, and kanamycin. They are bactericidal and the killing is concentration dependant. 

They are used in the treatment of aerobic gram-negative bacterial infections such as urinary tract infections, mycobacterial infections, tularemia, respiratory infections in cystic fibrosis, and other pseudomonal infections. Anaerobic bacteria are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides because the transport of aminoglycosides across the cytoplasmic membrane requires oxygen.  

The adverse effects of aminoglycosides include-

  • Ototoxicity is characterized by irreversible high-frequency hearing loss and vestibular dysfunction. Streptomycin and gentamicin are the most vestibulotoxic. Amikacin, kanamycin, and neomycin mainly affect auditory functions. 
  • Nephrotoxicity due to damage to proximal tubular cells. Neomycin, tobramycin, and gentamicin are the most nephrotoxic.
  • Neuromuscular blockade due to inhibition of prejunctional release of acetylcholine and reduced sensitivity of the receptor to the neurotransmitter. The maximum blockade is by neomycin.

Resistance to aminoglycosides is typically due to drug inactivation by bacterial enzymes through acetylation, adenylation, or phosphorylation.  

Other options: 

Option A: Vancomycin is a glycopeptide that inhibits cell wall synthesis. It binds to terminal dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala of peptidoglycan to inhibit cell wall synthesis.

Options C and D: Clindamycin and chloramphenicol act by binding to the 50S subunit of the ribosome.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with complaints of limping, fever, and mild knee joint pain. His total leucocyte count was 55,000 cells/mm3 and ESR was elevated. An X-ray revealed bony ankylosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of septic arthritis.

Features include monoarticular joint involvement, limping, and fever. Hemogram shows elevated WBC count and ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate). Culture reveals Staphylococcus aureus in most cases in adults and Hemophilus influenza in children.  

Radiograph findings are fibrous ankylosis in early stages and bony ankylosis in late stages.

Treatment includes arthrotomy or joint drainage, immobilization, and radical treatment.

Other conditions where bony ankylosis is seen include:

• Ankylosing spondylitis 
• Rheumatoid arthritis

Other options:

Option A: Hemophilic arthritis is characterized by spontaneous bleeding following trivial trauma, joint tenderness, and acute hemarthrosis. In this condition, fibrous ankylosis is seen in the radiograph.

Option B: Osteoarthritis is characterized by pain and swelling of the joints. Crepitus can also be seen. It mainly affects the weight-bearing joints like the knee, hip, and spine. Radiologic features include loss of joint space, sclerosis, subchondral cysts, osteophytes, and loose bodies.

Option C: Gout has typical features of pain, swelling, and warmth of the first metatarsophalangeal joint. The radiograph is normal in the initial stages while it shows erosions, punched-out lesions, and sclerosis with preservation of joint space in late stages.

questions.text: A person has been bitten by the following snake. Which of the following options describe the symptoms seen classically in this snake bite?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows common krait, which is neurotoxic and shows classical symptoms such as muscle paralysis.

The neurotoxicity symptoms that would be seen in the patient include:

  • blurred vision
  • perioral paraesthesia
  • hyperacusis
  • dizziness
  • vertigo

Neurotoxicity effects are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase or they may wear off spontaneously in about a week.

Other options:

Option B: Systemic bleeding such as intravascular hemolysis, ecchymosis and incoagulable blood is seen in bites due to back fanged snakes.

Option C: Myoglobinuria is seen in poisoning due to sea snakes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old primigravida at 12 weeks of gestation has come to the hospital for a routine evaluation. Her maternal serum alfa-fetoprotein (MSAFP) levels are reduced. Ultrasound reveals increased nuchal translucency. Chorionic villus sampling shows a fetal karyotype of 47,XX,+21. The fetus is at the greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of reduced levels of MSAFP, increased nuchal translucency on ultrasound, and fetal karyotype of 47 XX,+21 is suggestive that the fetus has Down's syndrome. The fetus is at the greatest risk of developing duodenal atresia. 

Duodenal atresia is the most common gastrointestinal (GI) abnormality in Down’s syndrome. Infants present with bilious vomiting and show classic radiological double bubble sign. Patients with Down’s syndrome are also at increased risk of other GI abnormalities such as Hirschprung’s disease and celiac disease.

Other manifestations of Down’s syndrome include: 

  • Central nervous system abnormalities - hypotonia, developmental delay
  • Craniofacial abnormalities - flat face, brachycephaly, small nose, flat nasal bridge, epicanthal folds, speckled irises (Brushfield’s spots)
  • Cardiovascular abnormalities - endocardial cushion defects, atrial septal defects, ventricular septal defects
  • Musculoskeletal defects - atlantoaxial subluxation, short 5th digit with clinodactyly, single transverse palmar creases
  • Endocrinological abnormalities - congenital or acquired hypothyroidism, infertility
  • Hematologic abnormalities - transient myeloproliferative syndrome, acute lymphocytic leukemia
  • Respiratory system abnormalities - obstructive sleep apnea, frequent sinopulmonary infections

Other options:

  • Ventral wall defects such as omphalocele and gastroschisis and open neural tube defects are seen in association with elevated AFP levels. 
  • Pyloric stenosis is seen in association with Turner’s syndrome. It is caused by hypertrophy of the pylorus and presents with forceful non-bilious vomiting. It is not associated with Downs syndrome.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency with complaints of giddiness and palpitations. ECG revealed ventricular tachyarrhythmia and sotalol was given. All of the given statements regarding this are correct, except that ___.

choices.text: It is a non selective beta blocker
It prolongs action potential duration throughout the heart
It is excreted through bile following hepatic metabolism
Torsades de pointes occurs in low serum K+ concentration

questions.solution:
Among the given options, statement C is incorrect. Sotalol is excreted by the kidneys unchanged.

Sotalol is a non-selective beta-blocker with prominent class III action i.e, K+ channel blockade, thus causing prolonged cardiac action potentials and QT interval. It can cause torsades de pointes (dose-dependent), especially when the serum K+ concentration is low.

Sotalol is least likely to be present in the treatment charts as it is contraindicated in severe renal failure. It has low lipid solubility and is excreted primarily unchanged in the urine.

questions.text: A father has noticed that whenever his daughter drinks fruit juice, she has multiple episodes of vomiting. He reports to you that his daughter is allergic to fruit juice. After a thorough workup, she was diagnosed to have aldolase B deficiency. Which of the following substrate is accumulated in the blood?
questions.solution:
The substrate accumulated in the blood in aldolase B deficiency is fructose-1-phosphate. 

Aldolase B is also known as fructose-1-phosphate aldolase. It is involved in the breakdown of fructose-1-phosphate into glyceraldehyde and DHAP. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate and leads to hereditary fructose intolerance.

Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is due to a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B. It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism. This occurs when sucrose (containing fructose) is introduced into the diet of infants, usually around 6 months of age.

Defective aldolase B causes the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate. This will inhibit glycogen phosphorylase and cause accumulation of glycogen in the liver and associated hypoglycemia. Patients will present with vomiting, loss of appetite, and failure to thrive. Hepatomegaly and jaundice may occur. If liver damage progresses, death will occur. 

Reducing substance is seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test +).

Treatment is by the complete elimination of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet.

questions.text: The sleep disorder that occurs during REM sleep is __________
questions.solution:
Nightmares occur during REM sleep.

Nightmares are frightening or terrifying dreams that produce sympathetic stimulation and awakens the person. They occur in REM sleep and are usually associated with lengthy and complex dreams that gradually become more frightening. They commonly occur in children in the age group 3 to 6 years and are rare in adults. 

Night terrors (Option B) are characterized by abrupt arousal from sleep. They occur during stages 3 and 4 of NREM sleep.

The person who is aroused by nighmares usually remembers the dreams, whereas a person having nigh terrors cannot recall the dreams. 

Other options: 

Option A: Sleep walking occurs during NREM sleep. 

Option C: Bruxism most commonly occurs during stage 2 of NREM sleep. 

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: A middle-aged man complains of sudden painless loss of vision as if a curtain fell before his eyes. He also experiences flashes of light. On examination, pigments are found on the anterior vitreous like tobacco dusted over the posterior wall of the cornea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis from the clinical scenario is retinal detachment.

Retinal detachment is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). Retinal detachment is classified into the following depending upon the fluid accumulation:

  • Rhegmatogenous
  • Tractional
  • Exudative

Risk factors include myopia, previous intraocular surgery such as aphakia or pseudophakia, a family history of retinal detachment, and trauma.

Clinical features include sudden painless loss of vision, flashes of light or photopsia, floaters in the eye, and curtains in the field of vision.

Examination findings will reveal:

  • Normal or slightly low intraocular pressure
  • Marcus Gunn pupil (relative afferent pupillary defect)
  • Altered red reflex on the distant direct ophthalmoscope
  • Indirect ophthalmoscopy may show grey reflex of the freshly detached retina or breaks in the retina 
  • Vitreous pigments on the anterior vitreous (Shaffer sign)
  • Shifting fluid sign- Change in the position of the detached area with a change in gravity is the hallmark of exudative retinal detachment.

Management of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment includes sealing of retinal breaks, reducing the vitreous traction on the retina, and flattening of the retina by draining the subretinal fluid. Scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy, and pars plana vitrectomy can help in maintaining the chorioretinal apposition. 

Treating the cause helps in exudative retinal detachment. Enucleation can be done if intranuclear tumors are present.

Other options:

Option A- Stargardt disease is the most common type of macular dystrophy. It presents as decreased vision in the first or second decade of life. Fundus examination will show beaten bronze or snail-slime reflex in the macular area.

Option B- Macular edema is the collection of fluid in the macula. It occurs due to the leakage from dilated capillaries. Slit lamp examination will show loss of the foveal reflex and thickening at or around the macula. Fluorescein angiography is used to identify the areas of leakage.

Option C- Eales disease is the inflammation of peripheral retinal veins leading to recurrent retinal hemorrhages. Patients will have a sudden painless loss of vision and floaters. The examination will show hemorrhage and vascularisation of the retina.

Related Pearl: Causes of loss of vision

Features Cause

  • Massive vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal detachment involving macula
  • Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion

  • Methyl alcohol amblyopia
  • Non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion

  • Acute iridocyclitis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, myalgia, and enlarged lymph nodes over the groin. He gives a history of handling rodents as a part of his job. Fluid from the lymph node showed bipolar bacilli with Wayson's stain. The spreading  potential of the underlying disease is assessed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a man with buboes (enlarged groin nodes) and Wayson's stain showing bipolar bacilli are suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis, and the spreading potential of the disease is assessed by the Cheopis index. 

A plague is a zoonotic infection caused by Yersinia pestis and is usually transmitted by the bite of an infected rat flea. Rodent burrows serve as a favorable surface for the bacteria to grow and thus get transmitted by rat fleas. The most common vector that effectively spreads the infection is Xenopsylla cheopis. Flea indices are used to assess the density of the vector. One of the most specific indices is the Cheopis index. It is the measure of the average number of Xenopsylla cheopis per rat.  

There are three forms of plague: 

  1. Bubonic plague- Characterized by fever, chills, and buboes (more commonly in the groin and less commonly in the axilla) 
  2. Pneumonic plague- Occurs as a complication of septic plague or bubonic plague and bacilli can be isolated from sputum as well
  3. Septic plague - Occurs in an overwhelming infection leading to sudden onset sepsis

Investigations include the demonstration of bacillus from the samples of blood, sputum, and buboes. Yersinia is a coccobacillus that exhibits bipolar staining with Wayson's stain. Culture and serology can also be done.

Treatment should be started without awaiting investigations due to the high rate of mortality. Streptomycin is the drug of choice to treat plague, and it should be given intramuscularly in two doses (30 mg/kg). Other preventive measures include regular usage of rodenticides, proper application of effective insecticides, and disinfection. If a patient is suspected to have symptoms suggestive of plague, isolation is advised.

Related Pearl: Flea Indices

They are useful in measurements of density of fleas.

They include: 

  • Total flea index – it is the average number of fleas of all species per rat
  • Cheopis index - it is the average number of Xenopsylla cheopis species per rat,hence it is a specific flea index. It indicates the maximum explosiveness of the situation
  • Specific percentage of fleas – it is a precentage of different species of fleas that are found on rats.
  • Burrow index – It is the average  number of free living flea per species per rodent burrow.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.
